revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-02 22:36:50.000000000', 'message': "Remove nova.rpc.impl_carrot.

This module was marked as deprecated and scheduled for removal in Essex.
Remove it now that Folsom development is open.  nova.rpc.impl_kombu
should be used instead.

This patch also removes nova.testing.fake.rabbit, since as far as I can
tell, it isn't used anymore and was the last thing still using the
carrot dependency.

Change-Id: I8cfb2d09ee5eed439ec1d152261f7097faf08ad6
"}]
commit_message:
Remove nova.rpc.impl_carrot.

This module was marked as deprecated and scheduled for removal in Essex.
Remove it now that Folsom development is open.  nova.rpc.impl_kombu
should be used instead.

This patch also removes nova.testing.fake.rabbit, since as far as I can
tell, it isn't used anymore and was the last thing still using the
carrot dependency.

Change-Id: I8cfb2d09ee5eed439ec1d152261f7097faf08ad6

commit_message:
Compile BigInteger to INTEGER for sqlite

Fixes bug 966243

Ensure BigInteger does not map to BIGINT for an auto-created
sqlite registry DB, as this type is not supported by sqlite.

Change-Id: I61f44fbe50ea406d2d593f8f53cab5da3af2222a

commit_message:
volume.volumeId property used wrongly as .volume_id

Fixes bug 969162

Also, the created_at property was used as createdAt,
which lead to object reloading during template render
due to missing prop. See bug desc for more details.
Also, in the volume details template, the url link
for instance details was wrong - it was the link for
volume details instead.

Fixes Bug 971150

Change-Id: If5cfd515d0726a9ab85021b904a53e94b80205ea

subject: Prevent multiple modals/multiple form submissions via ajax.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 543, 'name': 'Tres Henry', 'username': 'tres'}, {'_account_id': 1205, 'name': 'Jake Dahn', 'email': 'jake.dahn@nebula.com', 'username': 'jakedahn'}, {'_account_id': 2135, 'name': 'Emma Grace Steimann', 'email': 'emmasteimann@gmail.com', 'username': 'emmasteimann'}, {'_account_id': 2458, 'name': 'John Postlethwait', 'email': 'john.postlethwait@nebula.com', 'username': 'john-postlethwait'}, {'_account_id': 2654, 'name': 'Andy Chong', 'email': 'andycjw@gmail.com', 'username': 'andycjw'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-26 02:38:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

what if there is modal creation inside modal?
this would prevent that from happening"}, {'account_id': 2458, 'date': '2012-03-27 02:31:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I think the most functionally appropriate way to go about this would be to disable the button when it is first clicked on with .attr('disabled', 'disabled'); (See here: http://api.jquery.com/attr/) That would ensure the button cannot be clicked anymore.

Using CSS classes for scripting behavior always makes me weary. Horizon already feels VERY bloated with CSS class application and usage."}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-03-27 19:13:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

(1 inline comment)

Yep. As has been stated, disabling the button it the way to handle this. Semantic HTML has solutions for all these problems.

Moreover, the handler needs to reset the button state whether it errors out or completes successfully.'}, {'account_id': 2135, 'date': '2012-03-30 23:24:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2458, 'date': '2012-03-30 23:26:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2135, 'date': '2012-03-30 23:29:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2458, 'date': '2012-03-30 23:43:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-04-02 07:47:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Mea culpa, the last round of advice turned out to be a dead-end too. This issue is actually more complicated than it seems:

Setting a "disabled" attribute works on button elements but not on links styled as buttons. So there would have to be two code-flows there, which is ugly.

However, I no longer think that disabling the button is even the right behavior, as it's a weird user experience to have the button suddenly change states and no longer allow clicking.

What we really want is to prevent the multiple requests from all completing and opening multiple modals, which means we need to cancel the previous ajax request. I'm gonna take a stab at a request that does that.'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-04-02 08:11:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2012-04-02 16:36:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 543, 'date': '2012-04-02 18:25:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-02 18:34:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3213/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-unittests/423/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-merge/419/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-pep8/578/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-02 18:34:58.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

[{'created': '2012-04-02 07:19:31.000000000', 'message': 'Improved keystone error handling in syspanel.

  * Added "AuthorizationFailure" to the recoverable errors list
    since keystoneclient raises it anytime it can't talk to
    keystone. Fixes bug 971249.

  * Used proper exception handling for the users index view.
    Fixed some tests that had been failiing but masked previously.
    Fixes bug 971250.

'}]
commit_message:
Improved keystone error handling in syspanel.

  * Added "AuthorizationFailure" to the recoverable errors list
    since keystoneclient raises it anytime it can't talk to
    keystone. Fixes bug 971249.

  * Used proper exception handling for the users index view.
    Fixed some tests that had been failiing but masked previously.
    Fixes bug 971250.

Change-Id: Iec8c1fc7bf8585a529fa15af55f807abc0f84d42

commit_message:
Updated RST docs on containers, fewer references to OVF format.

Updated the RST documentation that discusses container formats, since they
aren't really used right now.

Changed some examples from ovf to bare, since in most cases, users just upload
a bare image file.

Change-Id: I844d7827c3de4df6cdddb9b963cc2f236a3e6767

subject: rename the right index
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 1446, 'name': 'Bernhard M. Wiedemann', 'email': 'bmwiedemann@zq1.de', 'username': 'ubuntubmw'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-30 15:56:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

The problem is that bug 953159 is a bug specific to pgsql, which, as has been pointed out, we don't explicitly support.  The code you're changing does work correctly on the supported mysql database, and changing the name like this is likely to break it in the case of mysql."}, {'account_id': 1446, 'date': '2012-03-30 16:20:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I verified that the changed version works with both mysql and postgresql.
Also the bug is not specific to postgresql, but would likely occur with other databases that use indexes.
The old code tried to rename an index that was never created, because of this typo in this migrate file.
The reason, we submit this patch is that we want to explicitly support OpenStack with postgresql.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-30 16:37:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

OK, if you can confirm that this works with both databases, I'm OK with it.  However, you will need to add yourself to Authors before we can accept the patch…"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-30 18:50:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

lgtm. disappointed that our migration unit tests aren't set up in Jenkins properly to catch this sort of thing..."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-03-30 18:57:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

This fix seems like it might fix it in your case, but break it for someone else. Indexes aren't uniformly names across backends, so I bet this will make it work on postgres but break it on mysql. I *really* don't want to break mysql..."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-30 19:00:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hey, guys; make sure you read the preceding commentary.  We've already addressed the "does it break mysql?" question, and the only reason I still have a -1 on it is because jdsn is not in Authors.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-03-30 19:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Kevin: how could we have not caught this earlier when running migrations if it weren't correct for some backend? We would have seen the programmingerror in all cases, right?"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-30 19:09:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Honestly, I don't know.  Maybe this particular one simply fails silently.

ubuntubmw (or jdsn): Could you please re-run your test and show us the procedure you used and the results of your test?  If you can also address bcwaldon's question, that would be good."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-30 19:14:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It hasn't failed because the only backend that is currently tested by default is the SQLite database, which doesn't support renaming of indexes and has its own 006_sqlite_(up|down)grade.sql files... thus my comment before about our Jenkins job needing to include MySQL in that list of default tests"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-03-30 21:39:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Our devstack job runs these migrations on deploy, right?'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-30 23:26:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Brian, no, not that I'm aware of because Glance autocreates its schema when the registry server is installed and first starts..."}, {'account_id': 1446, 'date': '2012-03-31 18:19:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Today I took some hour to investigate Brian Waldon's question on why migrations worked with mysql. I enabled mysql's query-log, added several time.sleep(30) in this migration function and found that glance-manage db_sync finished within 4 seconds nevertheless. Reason was hinted in the query log:
registry/db/migrate_repo/versions/006_mysql_upgrade.sql: * This file is necessary because MySQL does not support renaming indexes.
So even including mysql in migration tests would not have caught this. But postgresql would."}, {'account_id': 1446, 'date': '2012-04-01 06:06:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1446, 'date': '2012-04-01 06:14:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Added required entry to Authors file and added some more explanation to the commit message.
In case you are wondering: I really wrote this, but since it took a bit longer to join the openstack-cla group, jdsn pushed it to get review started.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-02 15:00:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-02 15:41:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-02 15:52:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3205/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-merge/530/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-pep8/710/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-python26/222/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-python27/212/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-02 15:52:29.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
rename the right index

fixes bug 953159
This did not affect sqlite and mysql, because those can not rename indexes
and thus used a separate sql file to drop and create the right one.

Change-Id: Iab80a65464a591b732ecce4c00d04df50624e912

commit 155ef7daab08d7f3fb8f7838df1d715bf1dc2f3f

commit_message:
Ensure a functional database connection

Allow retrying database connection in get_engine() at an interval.  Resolves
the issue of nova components erroring at startup if a database connection is
unavailable, particularly at boot. Borrowed from a similar commit to glance,
(https://review.openstack.org/#change,5552).

This also fixes code duplication due to a half-backport of
commit 155ef7daab08d7f3fb8f7838df1d715bf1dc2f3f

Fixes Bug #959426 for nova.

Change-Id: Ifea94da8347714887c8cae02cc48288f3fa4fa7f

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-01 23:23:30.000000000', 'message': 'Instance Detail Missing Volume Attachment Info.

Django, apparently, does not use the same instance
of some values between the view and the template.
In this case, volume.attachments was being called
again, causing the extra key for the instance that
were added to attachments in the view to not be
available in this template, as it was a totally
different instance of the volume.attachments call.

Fixes Bug #971150

Change-Id: Id9eed1e4f7ee749a9ca15b7331ccc3a2b98d1276
'}, {'created': '2012-04-02 00:56:32.000000000', 'message': 'Instance Detail Missing Volume Attachment Info.

Django, apparently, does not use the same instance
of some values between the view and the template.
In this case, volume.attachments was being called
again, causing the extra key for the instance that
were added to attachments in the view to not be
available in this template, as it was a totally
different instance of the volume.attachments call.

Fixes Bug #971150

Change-Id: Id9eed1e4f7ee749a9ca15b7331ccc3a2b98d1276'}, {'created': '2012-04-02 00:58:48.000000000', 'message': "Instance Detail Missing Volume Attachment Info.

Nova re-does the request if keys are accessed on
the volumes that do not exist in it's cache. In
this case, it was causing key-values from the view
to be clobbered and inaccessible to the template.

Fixes Bug #971150

Change-Id: Id9eed1e4f7ee749a9ca15b7331ccc3a2b98d1276"}]
commit_message:
Instance Detail Missing Volume Attachment Info.

Nova re-does the request if keys are accessed on
the volumes that do not exist in it's cache. In
this case, it was causing key-values from the view
to be clobbered and inaccessible to the template.

Fixes Bug #971150

Change-Id: Id9eed1e4f7ee749a9ca15b7331ccc3a2b98d1276

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-31 00:01:08.000000000', 'message': 'Support timestamps as prefixes for traceback log lines.

Traceback lines in the log are now formatted to match other log
lines. So, instead of getting something like:

2012-03-26 14:53:26 ERROR nova.rpc.common [-] AMQP server on 10.55.58.1:5672 is unreachable: Socket closed. Trying again in 1 secon
ds.
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE: Traceback (most recent call last):
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE:   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/rpc/impl_kombu.py", line 446, in reconnect
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE:     self._connect()
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE:   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/rpc/impl_kombu.py", line 423, in _connect
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE:     self.connection.connect()
[snip]

You would get something like:

2012-03-26 14:53:26 ERROR nova.rpc.common [-] AMQP server on 10.55.58.1:5672 is unreachable: Socket closed. Trying again in 1 secon
ds.
2012-03-26 14:53:26 TRACE nova.rpc.common Traceback (most recent call last):
2012-03-26 14:53:26 TRACE nova.rpc.common   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/rpc/impl_kombu.py", line 446, in reconnect
2012-03-26 14:53:26 TRACE nova.rpc.common     self._connect()

commit_message:
Support timestamps as prefixes for traceback log lines.

Traceback lines in the log are now formatted to match other log
lines. So, instead of getting something like:

2012-03-26 14:53:26 ERROR nova.rpc.common [-] AMQP server on 10.55.58.1:5672 is unreachable: Socket closed. Trying again in 1 secon
ds.
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE: Traceback (most recent call last):
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE:   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/rpc/impl_kombu.py", line 446, in reconnect
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE:     self._connect()
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE:   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/rpc/impl_kombu.py", line 423, in _connect
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE:     self.connection.connect()
[snip]

You would get something like:

2012-03-26 14:53:26 ERROR nova.rpc.common [-] AMQP server on 10.55.58.1:5672 is unreachable: Socket closed. Trying again in 1 secon
ds.
2012-03-26 14:53:26 TRACE nova.rpc.common Traceback (most recent call last):
2012-03-26 14:53:26 TRACE nova.rpc.common   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/rpc/impl_kombu.py", line 446, in reconnect
2012-03-26 14:53:26 TRACE nova.rpc.common     self._connect()
2012-03-26 14:53:26 TRACE nova.rpc.common   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/rpc/impl_kombu.py", line 423, in _connect
2012-03-26 14:53:26 TRACE nova.rpc.common     self.connection.connect()
[snip]

This is tracked by bug 967842.

Change-Id: Ie017317f7e0b636016a220cb21a3543ab569dea5

commit_message:
Make kombu failures retry on IOError

Fixes bug 797770

Unfortunately if rabbit decides protocol negotiation is taking too long,
it will close the socket on us.  This ends up raising IOError with a
'socket closed' message.  This patch will catch IOError and re-try.

Change-Id: I9110c845b71118c0fad760d90e91c585e6db46ed

commit_message:
Make kombu failures retry on IOError

Fixes bug 797770

Unfortunately if rabbit decides protocol negotiation is taking too long,
it will close the socket on us.  This ends up raising IOError with a
'socket closed' message.  This patch will catch IOError and re-try.

Change-Id: I9110c845b71118c0fad760d90e91c585e6db46ed

[{'created': '2012-03-30 23:56:03.000000000', 'message': "Export user id as password to keystone when using noauth

Fixes bug #969208

When using noauth, a user's password is her user id (e.g. in novarc).

When we export to keystone, we should make sure the same credentials
keep working rather than effectively switching all the passwords to
random UUIDs which users would never have seen before.

Change-Id: Ie77c622ce1952d03e836bb64167184022a02e902
"}]
commit_message:
Export user id as password to keystone when using noauth

Fixes bug #969208

When using noauth, a user's password is her user id (e.g. in novarc).

When we export to keystone, we should make sure the same credentials
keep working rather than effectively switching all the passwords to
random UUIDs which users would never have seen before.

Change-Id: Ie77c622ce1952d03e836bb64167184022a02e902

commit_message:
bug 965335

Resolves unclear formatting of compute extensions documentation at
http://nova.openstack.org/api_ext/index.html

The rst extensions template has been updated to include extension name as
top level hierarchy, and demote all other content.

All existing documentation pages have been reformatted as per the updated
template.

The ext_aggreagates.rst file has also been added to index.rst.

Amendments:
 - Author added to Authors file
 - Typo in ext_volumes.rst fixed

Change-Id: Id67ef91a6e8eaaf4fba46abbd57759c77aaf8991

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-31 00:08:08.000000000', 'message': "Don't set instance ACTIVE until it's really active

Fixes bug 963656

Reverting a resize would end up setting the instance ACTIVE before the
driver had finished all of the work starting up the original instance.
If the instance is deleted quickly after the revert, a race condition
could occur between restarting the original instance and deleting it.

Change-Id: Iba26ad7d1bc1049137f94e13898be86698963fb3
"}]
commit_message:
Don't set instance ACTIVE until it's really active

Fixes bug 963656

Reverting a resize would end up setting the instance ACTIVE before the
driver had finished all of the work starting up the original instance.
If the instance is deleted quickly after the revert, a race condition
could occur between restarting the original instance and deleting it.

Change-Id: Iba26ad7d1bc1049137f94e13898be86698963fb3

commit_message:
A missing checksum does not mean the image is corrupt.

This is a logic error in the code. A missing checksum should not
imply that the image is corrupt. Note that corrupt images are only
logged, not removed, so there is no data loss for users with this
bug.

Change-Id: Ic644517d3b8e9646fe943e5cef485c4168ebb5b5

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-30 23:50:46.000000000', 'message': "Touch in use image files when they're checked.

It was intended that FLAGS.remove_unused_resized_minimum_age_seconds
would indicate the number of seconds a base file was unused before it
was removed. This however isn't true at the moment. Because instances
are COW mostly, this will be the time since the resize occurred,
which is normally instantly true once the image isn't being used any
more. This small patch corrects that by touching the base image during
check cycles which find it in use. Resolves bug 967845.

Change-Id: I75bf06cf758c9a2d7a8bde5ce67c789d7e299174
"}]
commit_message:
Touch in use image files when they're checked.

It was intended that FLAGS.remove_unused_resized_minimum_age_seconds
would indicate the number of seconds a base file was unused before it
was removed. This however isn't true at the moment. Because instances
are COW mostly, this will be the time since the resize occurred,
which is normally instantly true once the image isn't being used any
more. This small patch corrects that by touching the base image during
check cycles which find it in use. Resolves bug 967845.

Change-Id: I75bf06cf758c9a2d7a8bde5ce67c789d7e299174

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-30 23:49:57.000000000', 'message': "Reduce the image cache manager periodic interval.

When this code was written, I (incorrectly) believed a periodic
task tick was about a second. It turns out that by default they're
between 60 seconds and 120 seconds depending on a random value.
Therefore, reduce the interval to something more reasonable.

Change-Id: Id840c755f954e3e371d7238243f2248e8d402c7b
"}]
commit_message:
Reduce the image cache manager periodic interval.

When this code was written, I (incorrectly) believed a periodic
task tick was about a second. It turns out that by default they're
between 60 seconds and 120 seconds depending on a random value.
Therefore, reduce the interval to something more reasonable.

Change-Id: Id840c755f954e3e371d7238243f2248e8d402c7b

Handle instances being missing while listing floating IPs

listing floating IPs when an instance has gone missing.

in a traceback and a hang. This fixes bug 965225

commit_message:
bug 965335

Resolves unclear formatting of compute extensions documentation at
http://nova.openstack.org/api_ext/index.html

The rst extensions template has been updated to include extension name as
top level hierarchy, and demote all other content.

All existing documentation pages have been reformatted as per the updated
template.

The ext_aggreagates.rst file has also been added to index.rst.

Amendments:
 - Author added to Authors file
 - Typo in ext_volumes.rst fixed

Change-Id: Id67ef91a6e8eaaf4fba46abbd57759c77aaf8991

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-30 13:37:11.000000000', 'message': "Export user id as password to keystone when using noauth

Fixes bug #969208

When using noauth, a user's password is her user id (e.g. in novarc).

When we export to keystone, we should make sure the same credentials
keep working rather than effectively switching all the passwords to
random UUIDs which users would never have seen before.

Change-Id: Ie77c622ce1952d03e836bb64167184022a02e902
"}]
commit_message:
Export user id as password to keystone when using noauth

Fixes bug #969208

When using noauth, a user's password is her user id (e.g. in novarc).

When we export to keystone, we should make sure the same credentials
keep working rather than effectively switching all the passwords to
random UUIDs which users would never have seen before.

Change-Id: Ie77c622ce1952d03e836bb64167184022a02e902

[{'created': '2012-03-29 01:53:25.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure a functional database connection

Allow retrying database connection in get_engine() at an interval.  Resolves
the issue of nova components erroring at startup if a database connection is
unavailable, particularly at boot. Borrowed from a similar commit to glance,
(https://review.openstack.org/#change,5552).

Fixes Bug #959426 for nova.

Change-Id: Id34eda9e0bad6b477a74e9a7d3575e513e6291d5

unavailable, particularly at boot. Borrowed from a similar commit to glance,
(https://review.openstack.org/#change,5552).

commit_message:
Ensure a functional database connection

Allow retrying database connection in get_engine() at an interval.  Resolves
the issue of nova components erroring at startup if a database connection is
unavailable, particularly at boot. Borrowed from a similar commit to glance,
(https://review.openstack.org/#change,5552).

Fixes Bug #959426 for nova.

Update: * Properly return an engine (fixes tests)
        * Setting sql_max_retries to -1 will retry infinitely
        * Bumped options count in nova.conf.sample
        * i18n log warning
        * Add note to flag help about -1 == infinite
        * Pep8 fix

Change-Id: Id34eda9e0bad6b477a74e9a7d3575e513e6291d5

[{'created': '2012-03-30 18:59:56.000000000', 'message': 'Improve 'nova ssh' error message.

Fix bug 969499.

If you ran "nova ssh <name>" and the instance has no public IP
addresses, the output you got was:

    ERROR: 'public'

This patch makes it so you get a friendlier error in this case:

    ERROR: No public addresses found for '<name>'.

Change-Id: I176decf90f472f9b0768e4d0c2bcabd55fe7198a
'}]
commit_message:
Improve 'nova ssh' error message.

Fix bug 969499.

If you ran "nova ssh <name>" and the instance has no public IP
addresses, the output you got was:

    ERROR: 'public'

This patch makes it so you get a friendlier error in this case:

    ERROR: No public addresses found for '<name>'.

Change-Id: I176decf90f472f9b0768e4d0c2bcabd55fe7198a

commit_message:
Check that DescribeInstance works with deleted image

This test checks that even if the image is non-existant, DescribeInstances
returns correctly an answer and does not fails because of ImageNotFound".

This has been the case previously (essex-4), and its now fixed with other
another issue listed in bug #948286, but I wrote a test to be sure of that.

Change-Id: I34df7a3fbc492f4418b2751b2b8bc527a7bbe335
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

[{'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-03-21 02:01:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-03-21 05:35:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I have a follow-on change that adds support for anon access for container sync and permitted referrers (https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/924578).  I chose to keep the two separate, but let me know if I should squash the commits and submit a new patch.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-03-21 06:23:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Please disregard the last comment.  My git/gerrit-fu is clearly lacking.'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-03-21 17:20:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

Maru - the only blocker in this review for me is the manipulation of potentially invalid config options to "fix" them, but I think the second would be a damn good idea.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-03-21 20:30:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

Joe: Comments inline.  I look forward to your feedback.'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-03-22 00:31:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-03-22 01:17:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

Joe: Thank you for the feedback!'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-03-22 02:57:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1420, 'date': '2012-03-22 03:59:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I know its been mentioned before regarding other tests, but is it really a good idea to have unit tests pulling libraries from external resources?  I've already run into an issue with these swift tests and the swift middle-ware attempting to access /dev/log in a constrained build environment.  Coincidentally, AFAICS the try/except+skip import workaround being removed here is the only way to enable this test suite on the Ubuntu builders without patching swift itself."}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-03-22 05:01:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Needs to pass the tests, but to answer Adam's question - yes, it's a good idea - because there is no other integration test suite that we can use to gate and ensure that this code won't get broken as we do additional work towards the future. We don't have to enable it for package building, but we definitely DO want to have this kind of testing in OpenStack. When tempest is ready to gate, I'll happily move everything re: integration into it. Until then..."}, {'account_id': 1420, 'date': '2012-03-22 16:46:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I understand, Joe, just raising my concerns here anyway to be a pain. :)  FWIW, as part of the requirements for any of this stuff to be in Ubuntu's main archive, the upstream test suite needs to be enabled and passing during package build time.  Bug #961871 is a result of trying to get the keystone stuff up and going on the buildd's."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-03-22 19:38:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-03-22 19:44:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Joe: This patch should work - I've added netifaces to test-requires, the only necessary dependency of swift that is not already installed by keystone.

This got me thinking - is there a reason to use checkout_vendor() instead of including swift (either the latest source distribution or a github reference) in test-requires?  It would seem more straightforward to rely on test-requires, especially since the functionality that swift_auth relies on is very much stable (mainly acl/referrer parsing)."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-03-23 22:56:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-03-23 23:24:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-03-23 23:25:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

commit_message:
Improve swift_auth test coverage + Minor fixes

 * Isolates authorize() tests from wsgi tests
 * Adds coverage for authorize()
 * Adds support for a blank reseller_prefix
 * Adds swift_auth test dependencies to tools/test-requires
 * Cleans up authorize()'s use of tenant_id/tenant_name
   (addresses bug 963546)

Change-Id: I603b89ab4fe8559b0f5d72528afd659ee0f0bce1

subject: Acccept metadata ip so packets aren't snatted
messages:
[{'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-03-29 16:47:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

We need a bug or something for this."}, {'account_id': 2634, 'date': '2012-03-29 17:21:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

i install multi node openstack on centos.
the instance on computes would connect to metadata_host for metadata.

ec2_host=192.168.28.6   # public interface of controller
metadata_host=10.9.0.100 #internal interface of controller
my_ip=192.168.28.7  # compute node

the instance can't connect to metadata_host, here is iptables:

-A nova-network-PREROUTING -d 169.254.169.254/32 -p tcp -m tcp --dport 80 -j DNAT --to-destination 10.9.0.100:8775 

-A nova-network-snat -s 10.9.0.0/16 -j SNAT --to-source 192.168.28.7

i modify the ipfilter, and it works:

-A nova-network-snat -s 10.9.0.0/16 -o eth0 -j SNAT --to-source 192.168.28.7"}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-03-29 17:43:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

Awesome! It would be helpful if you made a bug with that and then update the commit message to say that you're fixing the bug :-)"}, {'account_id': 2634, 'date': '2012-03-29 17:51:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2634, 'date': '2012-03-29 17:54:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-03-29 18:00:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-29 18:32:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

There is an option called dmz_cidr to prevent snatting to a certain ip range.  This doesn't seem like a dangerous patch but it also doesn't help if the metadata server is also on the eth0 interface."}, {'account_id': 2634, 'date': '2012-03-30 15:29:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-30 16:17:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

[{'created': '2012-03-30 16:58:30.000000000', 'message': "Ensure that linux-headers-virtual is installed.

Also linux-headers-`uname -r`.  This is needed for the
stable/diablo branch.  And since apt-get doesn't know how to pull
down the running version, dkms builds can fail if this isn't
installed for the specific running version beforehand.  The
unversioned package will install the lastest version, but that
may not be the kernel the image is currently running.

Change-Id: Idb619ed57f6e101001fea3825c328b471d97e092
"}]
commit_message:
Ensure that linux-headers-virtual is installed.

Also linux-headers-`uname -r`.  This is needed for the
stable/diablo branch.  And since apt-get doesn't know how to pull
down the running version, dkms builds can fail if this isn't
installed for the specific running version beforehand.  The
unversioned package will install the lastest version, but that
may not be the kernel the image is currently running.

Change-Id: Idb619ed57f6e101001fea3825c328b471d97e092

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-30 00:54:56.000000000', 'message': "Allow specifying the current version in 'glance-manage version_control'

Fixes bug #966242

The version_control command is a bit useless since you can't actually
specify what version to  use and it defaults to version=0.

Allow the user to specify a version:

  $> glance-manage version_control 9 # set the diablo version

and default to the latest version if none is specified.

Also, allow db_sync to be supplied a version for the case where we're
upgrading an unversioned DB.

Finally, re-work the argument handling in glance-manage to more easily
handle optional args.

The tests are extended to test using db_sync for upgrades and to test
placing an existing database under version control.

Change-Id: I231dc710554198bfd1fdcb82c3c3768963f64bd8
"}]
commit_message:
Allow specifying the current version in 'glance-manage version_control'

Fixes bug #966242

The version_control command is a bit useless since you can't actually
specify what version to  use and it defaults to version=0.

Allow the user to specify a version:

  $> glance-manage version_control 9 # set the diablo version

and default to the latest version if none is specified.

Also, allow db_sync to be supplied a version for the case where we're
upgrading an unversioned DB.

Finally, re-work the argument handling in glance-manage to more easily
handle optional args.

The tests are extended to test using db_sync for upgrades and to test
placing an existing database under version control.

Change-Id: I231dc710554198bfd1fdcb82c3c3768963f64bd8

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-29 00:13:50.000000000', 'message': "Add MySQLPingListener() back

The use of wrap_db() to catch low-level problems in the connection
pool appears to be incompatible with new versions of sqlalchemy
(0.7.4/precise).  This re-instates the use of a event listener to
catch the error of 'mysql has gone away'.  Keeps the wrapping
logic in place for use before the connection pool has been constructed,
specifically to allow glance to retry its initial database connection on
service startup.

Fixes bug 967887

Change-Id: Ia732377d3404104b8acf7fe4ada164ec7ecf705f
"}]
commit_message:
Add MySQLPingListener() back

The use of wrap_db() to catch low-level problems in the connection
pool appears to be incompatible with new versions of sqlalchemy
(0.7.4/precise).  This re-instates the use of a event listener to
catch the error of 'mysql has gone away'.  Keeps the wrapping
logic in place for use before the connection pool has been constructed,
specifically to allow glance to retry its initial database connection on
service startup.

Fixes bug 967887

Change-Id: Ia732377d3404104b8acf7fe4ada164ec7ecf705f

[{'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-30 08:35:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

This method is currently only used by glance for is_public and it looks like this change is only pulling in a recent change to the method in glance

See I593a50117fd339a8ab281a8daad734770ca9960c'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-03-30 08:35:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-03-30 08:35:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I would prefer to see this code go in the other direction and only allow allow one option as true.  IMHO this would make comparing config files easier and reduce confusion.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-03-30 08:35:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

One of the reasons I think this is a good idea is if you run glance show ID you get something like the following:

ane:~> glance show 282d2c01-4b99-48e4-9f3d-7e4dc136d088
URI: http://9.114.219.71:9292/v1/images/282d2c01-4b99-48e4-9f3d-7e4dc136d088
Id: 282d2c01-4b99-48e4-9f3d-7e4dc136d088
Public: No
Protected: No

To which I immediately tried 

glance update 282d2c01-4b99-48e4-9f3d-7e4dc136d088 is_public=yes 

Which did nothing.

We use Yes / No to display some booleans, which I think is a friendly thing to do, so from a useability perspective, I'd suggest taking Yes as True is a good thing.

Otherwise is_public=yes actually means is_public=false, which is something I think that's entirely unexpected."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-30 08:35:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-openstack-common-merge/39/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-30 08:35:32.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
Make 'yes' also a true boolean

Adds yes, Yes, and all other capitalizations as a true boolean.
Updated unit tests to test for these.

Change-Id: I97915f870dd6bba612f74f0ceb78f2399fd81a93

subject: Removed HACKING.rst in favor of openstack-common.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-03-22 20:15:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-22 20:57:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I do not want to see HACKING.rst removed.  Synchronized, yes; removed, no—IMO, there should be a copy in each project so it is easy to find."}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-03-22 21:32:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Do not submit

I don't think there's any justification for removing this file. Code standards should tend toward consistency across projects, but that isn't the case now and won't be in the visible future (swift is wildly out of compliance with the nova standard and vice-versa for instance).

Also, the wiki is the wrong place for this (or similar) document to reside. The ability to edit on the wiki is either wholly open to anyone on the OpenStack team on Launchpad, or it's locked down to administrators. Which means it can be modified at will by anyone without discussion, or it's locked to a handful of "special" users. Keeping the standard with the canonical representation of developer intent (namely the code) means that it can be modified by the existing standards we have for modifying the code itself and forces a discussion should someone desire to modify it.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-30 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-30 06:03:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]

subject: Removed HACKING.rst in favor of openstack-common.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 475, 'name': 'Rick Harris', 'email': 'rick.harris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rconradharris'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 693, 'name': 'Christopher MacGown', 'email': 'chris@pistoncloud.com', 'username': '0x44'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-22 20:17:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

Sorry, there's a good reason that the HACKING.rst is different from Nova: I can't stand the arbitrary style decisions that were made regarding docstrings in Nova."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-22 20:38:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'm all for consistency here despite any nits I might have with some of the guidance.

Once we have consistency, we can debate global style changes easily without having to reference all of the current subtle differences."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-22 20:54:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

I do not want to see HACKING.rst removed.  I do want to see HACKING standards normalized across the projects, but IMO every project should have a copy of it.'}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-03-22 21:33:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I don't think there's any justification for removing this file. Code standards should tend toward consistency across projects, but that isn't the case now and won't be in the visible future (swift is wildly out of compliance with the nova standard and vice-versa for instance).

Also, the wiki is the wrong place for this (or similar) document to reside. The ability to edit on the wiki is either wholly open to anyone on the OpenStack team on Launchpad, or it's locked down to administrators. Which means it can be modified at will by anyone without discussion, or it's locked to a handful of "special" users. Keeping the standard with the canonical representation of developer intent (namely the code) means that it can be modified by the existing standards we have for modifying the code itself and forces a discussion should someone desire to modify it.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-22 22:01:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Kevin: If each has a project has a copy, then, over time, they'll diverge and we'll be right back where we started.

Rather than have a copy of HACKING in each repo, maybe each projects README should just reference the openstack-common version.

Chris: AFAIK the plan is to move HACKING into openstack-common's repo, not the wiki.

Also, I don't think we should be saying that just b/c Swift's style is currently different that it wouldn't be worthwhile to unify the style-guide for the rest of the projects.

If Swift eventually chooses to adopt common's HACKING guidance, that would be awesome, but that shouldn't hold up the other projects which are already 95% similar style-wise."}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-03-22 22:08:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Rick: The email that kicked this off asked why it should go on the wiki. Moving it into openstack-common brings out other problems, though. Unless every -core member of each project is also -core on openstack-common, it doesn't seem like the HACKING document would reflect the actual HACKING conventions across the projects and leaving it to a small subset of developers who might disagree with changes that the larger community desires (or even a single project desires) seems itself wrong.

The fact that swift's style is so wildly divergent, coupled with Jay's personal distaste for the docstring format in the current HACKING implies to me that it's too early to force unity on this subject."}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-03-22 22:09:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Errr…\xa0why it wasn't on the wiki."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-22 22:17:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Rick: The way openstack-common currently functions is that files within the client repositories are synchronized from the version in openstack-common.  If this is regularly synchronized, drift should not be a problem.

Chris: Personally, I think HACKING needs a slightly higher level of review than a regular code commit anyway…by which I mean simply that there should be some discussion of changes to it on the list before simply submitting a change.  That said, changes to HACKING should not be any more difficult than this.  I happen to think a synchronization from openstack-common is sufficient for that purpose, *if* we can agree what elements truly are common across the different projects (which right now might be a big "if"…).'}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-03-22 22:24:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I agree that modifications to HACKING requires more than a regular code-review, but I don't think that the -core members of openstack-common should be the gating reviewers. If there needs to be a committee of reviewers who aren't the -core members of a specific project, we already have one of those…\xa0we call it the PPB (and post-foundation the Technical Board).

I think the PPB/Technical Board are the wrong group of people to be making that decision though, and that the more strenuous review process could be easily handled by making changes to HACKING require a blueprint and discussion at the tech summit. This has the added benefit of preventing flapping."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-30 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-30 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]

[{'created': '2012-03-30 01:04:03.000000000', 'message': "Add preference towards single id for action handling.

When the action handler received both a single id and multiple
object ids (such as when a user checks multiple boxes, then selects
a single row's action), it would previously favor the mutiple
ids, which goes against the intention of the user. This patch
causes it to favor the single id now.

Fixes bug 960866.

Change-Id: I53034589ada5792c22c2fc5144af2aee3b551eb0
"}]
commit_message:
Add preference towards single id for action handling.

When the action handler received both a single id and multiple
object ids (such as when a user checks multiple boxes, then selects
a single row's action), it would previously favor the mutiple
ids, which goes against the intention of the user. This patch
causes it to favor the single id now.

Fixes bug 960866.

Change-Id: I53034589ada5792c22c2fc5144af2aee3b551eb0

'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-03-28 07:32:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Swallowing the expected DatabaseMigrationError on non-initial calls seems reasonable to me (with the explanatory comment).'}, {'account_id': 1420, 'date': '2012-03-29 00:35:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Does this actually fix the issue of running migrations against a database that has auto-created tables?  I was excited it would but appears to simply create the required migrate_repo table, but with a version of 0.   That is, any attempt to upgrade or migrate the database via 'db_sync' still ends in error (tables already exists).  There still exists a split-brain between migrate and sqlalchemy's auto-creation magic.  We really need some way of introspecting the database after auto-creation, and setting version accordingly in migrate_repo but AFAIK migrate does not provide that."}, {'account_id': 1420, 'date': '2012-03-29 00:44:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Nevermind me, I totally missed the patch that this depends on.  With that also applied, this works great.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-03-30 01:18:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

In my opinion Glance has no business auto-creating the DB to begin with... that is what 'glance-manage db sync' is for.

That said, as long as we auto-create the DB we may as well version things correctly."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-30 01:31:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

commit_message:
Run version_control after auto-creating the DB

Fixes bug #966241

Currently, we auto-create an unversioned DB. This makes it awkward to
later upgrade it, especially since our 'glance-manage version_control'
command doesn't support retroactively versiioning it.

This is easily avoided by running version_control() after creating the
DB.

Change-Id: I935c06fcbcd3611c65d464850ca05445129f905f

commit_message:
Fix quantum deps

* Compile linux headers
* Install quantum before libvirt/n-cpu since openvswitch
  complains if bridges are present during installation
* Fixes bug 968424

Rebased

commit_message:
Update KillFilter to handle 'deleted' exe's.

Updates KillFilter so that it handles the case where the executable
linked to by /proc/PID/exe is updated or deleted.

Fixes LP Bug #967931.

Change-Id: I368a01383bf62b64b7579d573b8b84640dec03ae

was auto-abandoned.

Nova database is handled in db migrations; this adds the nova.conf
change noted by Naveed Massjouni in the original proposal.

Connections to quantum and melange DB changed to utf8

References bug 933208.

Change-Id: Ifc4e5cd71cafb719da62214aafc394563ed1aa29

a full stack trace, otherwise it is hard to track down where it happened.

commit_message:
Remove serverId lookup in volume attachments

We had to look for serverId and server_id to properly represent what
server a volume was attached to. We can undo the fix to pass gating now
that the necessary branches have landed.

Change-Id: I97957749ea4dd8a7fb5763f7abc75237d795dd23

subject: Add local.sh support and samples of local.sh and locarc
messages:
[{'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-03-28 16:31:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It would be good to add 'local.sh' to the .gitignore file"}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-03-28 16:32:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

To answer the question from https://review.openstack.org/5405 (what goes in local.sh), mine creates an m1.micro flavor so I can run more instances in my dev VM and adds ssh keys:

 NOVA_MANAGE=$DEST/nova/bin/nova-manage 
 MI_NAME=m1.micro
 # Create micro flavor if not present
 # set in localrc: DEFAULT_INSTANCE_TYPE=m1.micro
 if [[ -z `$NOVA_MANAGE instance_type list | grep $MI_NAME` ]]; then
     $NOVA_MANAGE instance_type create $MI_NAME 128 1 0 0 6 0 1
 fi

 # Add keypair for localhost
 . openrc
 for i in $HOME/.ssh/id_rsa.pub $HOME/.ssh/id_dsa.pub; do
     if [[ -f $i ]]; then
         nova keypair-add --pub_key=$i `hostname`
         break
     fi
 done'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-03-28 18:30:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-03-28 19:30:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

"}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-03-28 20:46:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-03-28 21:00:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

If you end up updating again anyway, it would be good to mention the sample localrc in the commit message as well (or split it into a new patch) since it's not exactly related to adding local.sh."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-03-28 21:06:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-03-28 21:35:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-03-28 23:24:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Agreed, the localrc is slightly non-sequitur for this prop, but I'm ok with it just being referenced in the commit message."}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2012-03-29 22:48:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

[{'created': '2012-03-28 16:24:16.000000000', 'message': 'Add local.sh support

commit_message:
Add local.sh support and samples of local.sh and locarc

Run $TOP_DIR/local.sh at the end of stack.sh if it exists and is executable.
This allows the user to automatically perform local actions on every re-stack,
such as creating custom flavors or specific tenants/users.  Like localrc, this
file is not distributed with DevStack so user modifications will be undisturbed.

Add local.sh to .gitignore

Examples of local.sh and localrc are in the samples/ directory.

Change-Id: I0be6b4d80ce084981cac8a3a8f1dc9bc8c3bbd4e

commit_message:
Handle additional directory structures in image upload

There appear to be multiple forms if AMI archive directory structures
in common use.  Add the one used by the tty-linux so we can get rid of
the special case for it to support UPLOAD_LEGACY_TTY

(new):
image-name/aki-tty/image
image-name/ami-tty/image
image-name/ari-tty/image

and

(existing):
image-name/*.img
image-name/*.initrd
image-name/*.vmlinuz

Change-Id: Ia7d88d53760f571c6a488c3139049502b484d33e

commit_message:
Converts all tables and connections (except Nova) to UTF8.

Nova cannot be converted at this time becuase an auto-generated
key in the nova migrations exceeds MySQL's internal 1000-byte limit
for key names when encoded on the 3-byte UTF8 instead of the 1-byte
latin-1.

References bug 933208.

Change-Id: Ifdbdd1649b7688c5e7fdad421b49437f9df4664e

OK, sounds like a reasonable  approach to coverage of db_sync versus direct calls to upgrade.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-03-29 17:40:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I like the idea of being able to upgrade/downgrade the DB version via 'glance-manage db_sync <version>'.

I'm not sure the ability to set the version explicitly with 'glance-manage version_control' is a good idea however. Seems like if a user *really* wanted to do this they could just do it manually. Actually... what is the point of 'version_control' anyway. Shouldn't it just go away entirely since it is the DB migrations that should set the version right?"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-29 18:28:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

'glance-manage version_control' is only useful at the moment because the DB auto-created by glance on startup isn't version controlled

So, e.g. if glance auto-created a DB in your Diablo install and you upgrade to essex, you need to do:

  $> glance-manage version_control 9
  $> glance-manage db_sync

With my other fix, I make sure that auto-created DBs are version controlled so the command should be less useful in future"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-03-29 22:09:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Thanks for the clarification Mark. Using 'version_control' as a means to upgrade un-versioned DB sounds reasonable. 

Perhaps post-folsom we can deprecate the option..."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-29 22:18:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-python27/207/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-29 22:18:34.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

[{'created': '2012-03-27 14:27:20.000000000', 'message': "Allow specifying the current version in 'glance-manage version_control'

Fixes bug #966242

The version_control command is a bit useless since you can't actually
specify what version to  use and it defaults to version=0.

Allow the user to specify a version:

  $> glance-manage version_control 9 # set the diablo version

and default to the latest version if none is specified.

Also, allow db_sync to be supplied a version for the case where we're
upgrading an unversioned DB.

Finally, re-work the argument handling in glance-manage to more easily
handle optional args.

Change-Id: I231dc710554198bfd1fdcb82c3c3768963f64bd8
"}, {'created': '2012-03-28 06:20:45.000000000', 'message': "Allow specifying the current version in 'glance-manage version_control'

The version_control command is a bit useless since you can't actually
specify what version to  use and it defaults to version=0.

Allow the user to specify a version:

  $> glance-manage version_control 9 # set the diablo version

and default to the latest version if none is specified.

Also, allow db_sync to be supplied a version for the case where we're
upgrading an unversioned DB.

Finally, re-work the argument handling in glance-manage to more easily
handle optional args.

The tests are extended to test using db_sync for upgrades and to test
placing an existing database under version control.

Change-Id: I231dc710554198bfd1fdcb82c3c3768963f64bd8
"}]
commit_message:
Allow specifying the current version in 'glance-manage version_control'

Fixes bug #966242

The version_control command is a bit useless since you can't actually
specify what version to  use and it defaults to version=0.

Allow the user to specify a version:

  $> glance-manage version_control 9 # set the diablo version

and default to the latest version if none is specified.

Also, allow db_sync to be supplied a version for the case where we're
upgrading an unversioned DB.

Finally, re-work the argument handling in glance-manage to more easily
handle optional args.

The tests are extended to test using db_sync for upgrades and to test
placing an existing database under version control.

Change-Id: I231dc710554198bfd1fdcb82c3c3768963f64bd8

Dave - you figured out how stable/diablo is using iso8601 before approving? Care to explain?

James:

  http://www.downforeveryoneorjustme.com/jenkins.openstack.org

  It's not just you! http://jenkins.openstack.org looks down from here."}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2012-03-29 19:00:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

iso8601 is used by glance.

nova.utils.import_class obscures this.  If it didn't, you'd see something like:

  File "/root/nova/nova/utils.py", line 65, in import_class
    __import__(mod_str)
  File "/root/nova/.venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/glance/client.py", line 31, in <module>
    from glance.common import animation
  File "/root/nova/.venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/glance/common/animation.py", line 23, in <module>
    from glance.common import utils
  File "/root/nova/.venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/glance/common/utils.py", line 32, in <module>
    import iso8601
ImportError: No module named iso8601

As far as the error that stopped the test is concerned, iso8601 is a red herring.  The original problem is that python-novaclient 2.6.0 has a syntax error.

Mark, feel free to hop on IRC and maybe we can track down why you can't access Jenkins.  There may be a network problem between you and it.  http://just-ping.com/index.php?vh=50.56.201.241&s=ping'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-29 19:11:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

Ok, that all seems a bit weird - stable/diablo nova requires glance 2011.3.1 which doesn't appear to require iso8601

Since you say this looks like a red herring and I don't think we've gotten to the bottom of it, I'm blocking the patch for now"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-03-29 19:15:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2012-03-29 19:29:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

nova stable/diablo requires an unversioned glance, so Jenkins is getting the latest from its cache:

  Using download cache from /home/jenkins/cache/pip/https%3A%2F%2Flaunchpad.net%2Fglance%2Fessex%2Fessex-rc1%2F%2Bdownload%2Fglance-2012.1%257Erc1.tar.gz'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-29 19:40:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3105/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/2066/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1722/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3455/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-29 19:45:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3106/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/2067/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1723/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3456/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 979, 'date': '2012-03-29 21:47:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Mark, this was discussed with the infra chaps who explained that it was blocking landing of a now disclosed security patch.

The reason it seems to be blocking was because of a floor in the CI process, where an unversioned novaclient is being used from Pypi.  So it doesn't /really/ introduce a new dependency, it's really a dependency of the client.

Not a great situation.

However, since then - it seems novaclient has other issues..  It's being dug into at the moment."}]

commit_message:
Add support for qcow2 images in $IMAGE_URLS.

This patch adds support for loading a qcow2 image and using the 'bare'
container format for all single file images.

I tested this successfully by setting:

IMAGE_URLS="http://berrange.fedorapeople.org/images/2012-02-29/f16-x86_64-openstack-sda.qcow2"

Change-Id: Ia55ffd4957866a3d7b9fd7ba4c62e38663b35080

subject: Added option to disable SQLite db preallocation
messages:
[{'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-21 19:56:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1603, 'date': '2012-03-22 21:03:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-03-26 23:58:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Kind of an ugly way to propagate a configuration setting.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-27 00:15:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Mike -- I agree.

I considered just removing the preallocation completely but it seemed useful on all-on-one storage nodes with high i/o fragmentation.

I also considered passing the configuration all around and eventually into the broker constructors but that actually seemed uglier and more prone to missing one.

Missing just one means disk usage bloat. Our "fancy" ssd account/container servers actually went from almost 90% full to just 13% full without preallocation. Missing just one spot, but called often enough at scale, would bring that bloat back.

All that said, if you can think of a cleaner patch, I'm all for it.'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-03-27 03:12:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Really, 90% to 13%?  That's some expensive slop if you're using SSDs.

I agree it's not worth refactoring the entire world to get this option down where it needs to be.  But if someone can figure out how to get it out of global state later, or at least centralize global configurable options, I wouldn't be unhappy."}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-03-28 21:20:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-28 21:20:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Fails

Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-28 21:45:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-28 21:49:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Added option to disable SQLite db preallocation

Added option to disable SQLite db preallocation. This can be very
useful on pure ssd account/container servers where the extra space is
worth more than the lesser fragmentation.

Change-Id: I8fbb028a9b6143775b25b343e97896497a8b63a9

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-28 10:15:29.000000000', 'message': "Touch in use image files when they're checked.

It was intended that FLAGS.remove_unused_resized_minimum_age_seconds
would indicate the number of seconds a base file was unused before it
was removed. This however isn't true at the moment. Because instances
are COW mostly, this will be the time since the resize occurred,
which is normally instantly true once the image isn't being used any
more. This small patch corrects that by touching the base image during
check cycles which find it in use.

Change-Id: I75bf06cf758c9a2d7a8bde5ce67c789d7e299174
"}, {'created': '2012-03-28 22:50:27.000000000', 'message': "Touch in use image files when they're checked.

It was intended that FLAGS.remove_unused_resized_minimum_age_seconds
would indicate the number of seconds a base file was unused before it
was removed. This however isn't true at the moment. Because instances
are COW mostly, this will be the time since the resize occurred,
which is normally instantly true once the image isn't being used any
more. This small patch corrects that by touching the base image during
check cycles which find it in use. Resolves bug 967845.

Change-Id: I75bf06cf758c9a2d7a8bde5ce67c789d7e299174
"}]
commit_message:
Touch in use image files when they're checked.

It was intended that FLAGS.remove_unused_resized_minimum_age_seconds
would indicate the number of seconds a base file was unused before it
was removed. This however isn't true at the moment. Because instances
are COW mostly, this will be the time since the resize occurred,
which is normally instantly true once the image isn't being used any
more. This small patch corrects that by touching the base image during
check cycles which find it in use. Resolves bug 967845.

Change-Id: I75bf06cf758c9a2d7a8bde5ce67c789d7e299174

subject: Support sql_connection_debug to get SQL diagnostic information
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 144, 'name': 'justinsb', 'email': 'justin@fathomdb.com', 'username': 'justin-fathomdb'}, {'_account_id': 209, 'name': 'Josh Kearney', 'email': 'josh@jk0.org', 'username': 'jk0'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 1849, 'name': 'Joe Gordon', 'email': 'joe.gordon0@gmail.com', 'username': 'jogo'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2271, 'name': 'Michael Still', 'email': 'mikal@stillhq.com', 'username': 'mikalstill'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-26 17:27:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

lgtm.'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-03-26 19:02:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-03-27 20:40:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Why use a number from 1 to 100, instead of just a 1,2,3 for the three different log levels?'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-27 20:50:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Ah ... please check out https://review.openstack.org/#change,5783 for the review when I proposed it against the wrong branch (milestone-proposed vs master).

Here's what I wrote there:

>Finally, I don't much like this being an integer flag with an arbitrary 0-100 range of values >Why not do this? > sqlalchemy_opts = [ > cfg.BoolOpt('sql_connection_verbose'), > cfg.BoolOpt('sql_connection_debug'), > ] >and then > echo = False > if FLAGS.sql_connection_debug: > echo = 'debug' > elif FLAGS.sql_connection_verbose: > echo = True
My thought process was:
1) It is a level, rather than independent booleans. (Verbose is ignored if Debug=True in your example) 2) Using 0,1 or 2 would tie it to SQLAlchemy's implementation. For example, level 100 is a bit too much information - it prints all the returned rows, whereas I can definitely imagine a "1.5" where we want the statement execution time but not the rows. So I chose 0-100, where 100 is 'print all the things', and 0 is nothing. That's not going to happen in Essex though.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-03-28 17:08:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

So you are planning on adding support for more sql_connection_debug in the future?   A range from 1 to 100 still seems excessive, perhaps chose a more realistic range?'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-28 17:14:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The problem with choosing a range of e.g. 1-10 is that once we have a 2 and 3, we're stuck when we want to add something in between.  100 gives us more breathing room.

I guess the correct solution is to have a range of 0 - 1 using real numbers, rather than 0-100 using the integers.  Does Python have a suitable arbitrary precision mathematics library?"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-03-28 18:16:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is there a separate change to describe this config setting side-effect in the admin guide?'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-28 18:19:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Doug: let's not make it part of the OpenStack contract until we're sure it's fully baked."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-03-28 18:38:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

By using any range (real or int), adding new debug levels will force a rebalancing of the values to make the options be spread out evenly along  the range.  So I am not sure using  reals between 0-1 is better.'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-28 18:50:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The values could be spread evenly, but I think it makes more sense to scale them by the volume of logging they produce.  Of course, we can produce an unlimited amount of data, so we should use a scale that can cope with this.

Two ideas that come to mind are to use either a logarithm based function, or 1/(1-x).  I think 1/(1-x) is much more natural for users.  So, 0 would produce 1 unit of logging, which we would define as the current level only, and then 0.5 would produce twice as much, 0.9 would produce 10 times as much, 0.99 would produce 100 times as much, etc.

Of course, we'll need to calibrate this.  I will start writing code that will analyze the number of bytes produced at various log levels.  We will ship with a default model, but then at runtime we will need to dynamically adjust the model based on the actual behaviour, so as to hit the target logging level over the infinite time horizon.

If the volume of natural events is insufficient, we can also inject artificial events to hit the desired rate.

This does mean that logging would be nondeterministic, even over a single execution of the program, but I think this is a small price to pay so that our configuration options can have a strong theoretical underpinning."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-03-28 19:12:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

That sounds like over engineering to me,  but if other people approve I won't object."}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-28 19:18:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Consider though, that any extra logging events we inject could be inspirational.  Here are some ideas:

"I'm OK, you're OK"

"The OpenStack community thanks you for being part of the OpenStack community."

"It looks like you're building a cloud.  Would you like help?"


We'll need a lot more if we're going to be able to sustain an arbitrary rate without too much repetition.'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-03-29 16:51:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-03-29 17:48:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-29 18:26:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3099/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/2060/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1716/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3449/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-29 18:26:46.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

Support sql_connection_debug to get SQL diagnostic information

We've had a few reports of SQL issues; it'll be very helpful to be able to get SQL information
into our log.

Bug #964844

Change-Id: I9d08991a3677bc6cbed45a930ede9271d685cac1

Reject excessively long image names.

Fixes bug 966240

Image names longer than 255 characters are rejected with 400 BadRequest
on creation or update.

messages:
[{'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-03-27 09:28:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

We probably want to have it defaulting to 2.0 as this is how we expect to work in the future. 

Any chance to have the default config file updated (glance-api-paste.ini) with the new variable and a comment?"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-27 16:50:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

Fix looks good, but see inline suggestion on the tests..."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-03-27 17:04:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Another thing to update, we probably want to update the comment on swift_store_auth_address :

17:55:05 FlorianOtel | chmouel, on smth else but related: the format of "swift_store_auth_address" in "glance-api.conf". It says it is
                     | "Address where the Swift authentication service lives". In the config I got from uksysadmin  it actually points
                     | to Keystone service port (i.e. 5000) whereas the default in the source is Swift itself... [11:01:36]
17:55:05     halfss_ | is there anybody know why? [11:01:42]
17:55:05     chmouel | FlorianOtel: feel free to comment on the review so Juerg can update  it [11:02:59]
17:55:05 FlorianOtel | chmouel, Will do. [11:03:28]

By the way, good work! I have tested and it work seamlessly. 

By the way, I think in the future it may be an idea to use auth_token to be able to store image in the tenant/account who's uploading. What do you think Jay?'}, {'account_id': 2036, 'date': '2012-03-28 07:41:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2036, 'date': '2012-03-28 08:29:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-03-28 09:15:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

Thanks for the changes, just a minor comment for me."}, {'account_id': 2036, 'date': '2012-03-28 13:34:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-03-28 16:32:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I believe this need to be the user service (ie: 5000) as we are effectively connecting with a username and password.


You are right about the no need of /tokens but we need to make sure to add a trailing slash at the end. This may need some documentation update as this may becoming a common mistake.'}, {'account_id': 2036, 'date': '2012-03-28 17:27:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Rather than documenting it, we should fix the code to add a trailing slash if it's missing."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-28 22:26:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

thx Juerg, lgtm!'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-03-29 15:16:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I am suggesting to have documentation update as we probably would not be able to have a fix by the time of Essex in swift (and a release).

I really think the port should be 5000 tho

Chmouel.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-03-29 17:26:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

messages:
[{'account_id': 706, 'date': '2012-03-22 18:40:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I was just about ready to say this looks good when I thought of something...

Does a GET on /v2/abc/flavors/detail?limit=1&marker=2 mean you want to start where id=2 or flavorid=2?

Basically, what seems to be happening when I apply this patch is that instance_type models have both "id" and "flavorid" columns so sometimes the marker is set based on the id match and other times it is set on the flavorid match. Does that make any sense? It's hard to explain but long story short there might need to be marker function specifically for using marker with flavorid...

I'll see if I can think of a test to explain what I mean.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-03-22 18:48:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Marker for flavors needs to be using flavorid, and remember, we start *after* the indicated marker.'}, {'account_id': 2383, 'date': '2012-03-26 22:17:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2012-03-27 16:01:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Good workaround for having flavorid and id to deal with. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-03-28 01:20:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-26 20:22:34.000000000', 'message': 'Support timestamps as prefixes for traceback log lines.

Traceback lines in the log are now formatted to match other log
lines. So, instead of getting something like:

2012-03-26 14:53:26 ERROR nova.rpc.common [-] AMQP server on 10.55.58.1:5672 is unreachable: Socket closed. Trying again in 1 secon
ds.
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE: Traceback (most recent call last):
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE:   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/rpc/impl_kombu.py", line 446, in reconnect
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE:     self._connect()
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE:   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/rpc/impl_kombu.py", line 423, in _connect
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE:     self.connection.connect()
[snip]

You would get something like:
