commit_message:
Support timestamps as prefixes for traceback log lines.

Traceback lines in the log are now formatted to match other log
lines. So, instead of getting something like:

2012-03-26 14:53:26 ERROR nova.rpc.common [-] AMQP server on 10.55.58.1:5672 is unreachable: Socket closed. Trying again in 1 secon
ds.
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE: Traceback (most recent call last):
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE:   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/rpc/impl_kombu.py", line 446, in reconnect
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE:     self._connect()
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE:   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/rpc/impl_kombu.py", line 423, in _connect
(nova.rpc.common): TRACE:     self.connection.connect()
[snip]

You would get something like:

2012-03-26 14:53:26 ERROR nova.rpc.common [-] AMQP server on 10.55.58.1:5672 is unreachable: Socket closed. Trying again in 1 secon
ds.
2012-03-26 14:53:26 TRACE nova.rpc.common Traceback (most recent call last):
2012-03-26 14:53:26 TRACE nova.rpc.common   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/rpc/impl_kombu.py", line 446, in reconnect
2012-03-26 14:53:26 TRACE nova.rpc.common     self._connect()
2012-03-26 14:53:26 TRACE nova.rpc.common   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/rpc/impl_kombu.py", line 423, in _connect
2012-03-26 14:53:26 TRACE nova.rpc.common     self.connection.connect()
[snip]

This is tracked by bug 967842.

Change-Id: Ie017317f7e0b636016a220cb21a3543ab569dea5

commit_message:
get_instance_uuids_by_ip_filter to QM

Adding a get_instance_uuids_by_ip_filter to the
QuantumManager. Also adds the supporting calls in
melange_ipam_lib an connector to support this. It
currently only works with Melange, I still need to
add a conditional that falls back on the original
implementation in the FlatManager if not using
Melange.

update: rebase

Change-Id: I9468de130c6cd1e0520f9d92c43f98aa6b36dce6

[{'created': '2012-03-28 20:34:25.000000000', 'message': "Improve performance of safe_log().

This patch addresses a minor performance regression in a recent change
to this function.  This change ensures that the deep copy is only done
if we really need to.  Previously, the deep copy was being done for all
messages that included a 'method', not just messages with a method that
contain an argument to be sanitized.

Change-Id: I190c5963ecaf70b0aea4e12a2fdc19deb5c1fea2
"}]
commit_message:
Improve performance of safe_log().

This patch addresses a minor performance regression in a recent change
to this function.  This change ensures that the deep copy is only done
if we really need to.  Previously, the deep copy was being done for all
messages that included a 'method', not just messages with a method that
contain an argument to be sanitized.

Change-Id: I190c5963ecaf70b0aea4e12a2fdc19deb5c1fea2

Just a couple more things...'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-03-16 11:51:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-03-22 14:30:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (3 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-03-22 15:58:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

John, Apologies, I had not intended for you to implement die_if_not_error, soon after writing that I reworked it into plain ole 'die'.  If you could make that one last change I think we'll be good to go."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-03-22 18:27:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I can't see how I can use the die method in my code. Although I suspect it is just because my brain has stopped working already, because I am on holiday tomorrow.

The issue I have is that the scripts are "set -e" by default, but I want to check a command fails. So before I can do that, I need to do "set +e", then check the return code, then restore "set -e", and exit if required. It seems worth while keeping this in a separate function, rather than littering the code with "set -e".'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-03-22 18:29:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-03-22 18:29:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

I can't see how I can use the die method in my code. Although I suspect it is just because my brain has stopped working already, because I am on holiday tomorrow.

The issue I have is that the scripts are "set -e" by default, but I want to check a command fails. So before I can do that, I need to do "set +e", then check the return code, then restore "set -e", and exit if required. It seems worth while keeping this in a separate function, rather than littering the code with "set -e".'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-03-22 19:49:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

You don't need to touch the errexit (-e) setting at all.  This is the first (I think) case in the exercises of wanting to die on a zero exit code.  So use the logical and instead:

 <successful-command> && die "command succeeded"

And as used in the other exercises, to die on a non-zero exit code:

 <failed-command> || die "command failed"

And of course, to keep executing the script on a non-zero exit code:

 <failed-command> || true'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-03-28 23:07:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Looks good for now - we can tweak the die syntax later'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-03-28 23:22:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-03-28 23:25:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-03-28 23:26:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

John, I went ahead and fixed up the die usage and removed die_if_not_error.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-28 23:35:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3081/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-devstack-merge/267/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-28 23:35:53.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-03-29 07:42:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Awesome thank you. Was on holiday last few days.'}]

commit_message:
WebOb 1.2+ compatibility

Fixes bug 888371. There was only one occurrance of the deprecated str_params, which has been substituted. Also checked for str_GET/str_POST/str_cookies all of which have been also deprecated.

Change-Id: Ic242921de3b6eb562d718db3088019c460422e82

commit_message:
Fix issue with not loading and showing
tenant name in syspanel/instance view

Fixes bug 964739

Patch2: Replaced API calls with _get(),
added unit test

The prefill of tenant_name was missing.
The same code is present in AdminIndexView.
Maybe it would be better to make UpdateRow as
part of the TableView, because they share
almost the same get_data() code...

Change-Id: Ib74f7049625292644bba41ac0ab17279274a8ca3

commit_message:
Handle multiple images and providers.

All of the prerequisites for supporting multiple VM providers should be
in place.  This has been tested with rackspace legacy, rackspace nova,
and hpcloud.

The scripts now use novaclient instead of libcloud.  The old v1_0 code that
was removed from novaclient is added here for as long as we continue to
use rackspace legacy.  It's slightly modified to handle some operational
considerations (such as cache-busting), and to integrate with the current
version of novaclient.  We can remove it when it's no longer needed.

Machines are now generated from snapshot images created from per-provider
base images, this lets us specify, eg, oneiric and precise images from each
provider.  Setup scripts take the provider name as an argument (so each
provider in Jenkins can have its own job for easier monitoring).  The fetch
script takes the base image name (eg, "oneiric") as an argument and gets
the oldest matching node from any provider.

Snapshot images are created from scratch each time; no more long-running
template hosts.

Devstack fixed network set to something that doesn't collide with hpcloud.

Min_ram is now configurable per-base-image (so we can request servers with
a certain amount of ram for each image (in case an image has no swap, or
otherwise needs more ram)).

SKIP_DEVSTACK_GATE_PROJECT added to the gate script to make testing the
script itself during development easier.

More robust detection of image URLs in the image update script.

On a running devstack node, before running devstack, check to see if there
is swap space.  If not, assume we're on HPCloud and unmount /mnt and use
it for swap.

Change-Id: I782e1180424ce0f3c7b69a3042eccc85b2b50389

commit_message:
Don't use $USERNAME in openrc.

Fix bug 967429.

Don't use $USERNAME as a variable in openrc.  It's commonly set by
default and can result in $OS_USERNAME getting set to something else
unexpectedly, resulting in an environment that doesn't work.

Change-Id: I6083a871209d30c81ca6876b1ef6c154aef7f598

commit_message:
Ensure functional db connection in configure_db()

During initial database setup, ensure we can physically connect
to the database and allow a failed connection to make use of the
new retry mechanism instead of registry startup failing outright.

Fixes lp bug #959426.

Change-Id: I1c87b19913c4204465e5d2027f2f184f0f358fd0

subject: object versioning
messages:
[{'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-07 16:50:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

All objects PUTs, POSTs, and DELETEs would now turn into 3 HEADs + the 3 writes for a feature some may not even desire. I think this feature should be configurable."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-07 21:56:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Just as an update for something John and I chatted about in person:

A container-level approach is being considered which might alleviate the extra overhead for non-versioning containers. Meaning, no performance hit for anybody if the feature is not used; only a hit for those containers where it's enabled. Might pan out, might not, but John's thinking on it now. :)"}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-03-14 21:20:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-03-14 23:31:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-03-15 06:34:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-16 00:57:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

There should probably be a note indicating that there can be at most one version per second. Also, saving the .00000 seems unnecessary. Alternatively, you might consider using x-timestamp to get better resolution.

The wording of how older versions are named is confusing. The older versions are named "<versions_container>/<object_name>/<timestamp>". The wording is "named by converting the ``Last-Modified`` header value of the current version to a unix timestamp and appending that timestamp to the ``<container>`` value of the ``X-Versions-Locations`` header on the container followed by the object name and a ``/``" which could be translated as "<versions_container>/<timestamp><object_name>/". Recommend rewording and providing an example.

There isn't an example of retrieving an older version with the "v" query parameter. I'm wondering if this extra feature is really needed. I mean, you'd probably have to do a listing to figure out what to set the "v" parameter to anyway, so why not just grab it yourself at that point? It would simplify the Swift implementation without really encumbering the client any more than they already are.

The "delete and see" example seems incorrect with the "prefix=obj_" part.

In swift/container/server.py the "allow_versions" conf value could be "False" and would be treated as True.

If there's a 5xx in _listing_iter, the user will get a 404 instead of a 5xx like they probaby should.

In _listing_iter, should probably grab the next marker value before yielding, just for extra safety. I seriously doubt anybody would mess with obj['name'], but just in case...

There are conflicts to worry about. If I make a few versions of an object named "first" and a few versions of an object named "first/second", things get screwy.

I'll just stop there for now.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-03-17 19:29:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-03-17 19:32:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Updated to address most of the concerns mentioned by gholt.

Naming conflicts are not addressed in this patch set.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-03-26 08:28:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-03-26 08:29:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

now also addresses naming conflicts (ie DELETE /v1/a/c/o doesn't delete versions of /v1/a/c/o/sub)"}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-26 21:28:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm curious why you didn't choose the lenprefix method I mentioned to
solve the naming conflicts problem? The current solution seems to
work, but seems substandard as it has to parse through things not
even dealing with the object at hand and might not get to its own
versions if there are too many other near-hit names. Granted, they
are just edge cases, but the edge cases could be a bit messy and
easily avoided with lenprefix.

Might mention that the version containers should only be used for one
container or messy conflicts could occur. Or, fix that restriction by
allowing container/prefix instead of just container.

Docs indicate use of Last-Modified header, but that's not true
anymore (or at most it's a fallback that should never happen).

Typo of myobjet instead of myobject. Also, -DELETE typo instead of -X
DELETE.

Nitpick: The curl examples don't follow the same args order and so
might be a little confusing.

Could you reduce the new Listing* exceptions to just three?
ListingIterError(Exception) ListingIterNotFound(ListingIterError) and
ListingIterNotAuthorized(ListingIterError)

Is there a reason for the "lreq.path_info = path" just after creating
lreq with the path? If so, maybe a quick comment as to why.

The status_int handling of lresp seems a bit too assuming. The // 100
== 5 raise Error seems fine, but // 100 == 4 raise NotFound I think
should be just matching 404 and the rest be lumped in with Error. I
think before anything not 2xx was translated as 404, but that was
wrong too.

I'm not sure if I'm reading things right, but it looks like PUTs of
new versions will retain the x-object-meta- of the previous version,
even if new values were specified in the new PUT request. As I
understand object PUT requests, all metadata must be in the PUT or is
discarded (unlike account/container metadata which accumulates).

Inline comment indicates "Prevent (most) user errors". I'm curious
what errors it does not prevent and why they're termed "user errors".

If you're only going to use listing[-1] is there really a need to
keep the whole listing?

Why copy_headers and then creq.headers[x] = y just after? Same could
be said about environ.

The self.container_name = lcontainer, self.object_name =
listing[-1]['name'] lines are repeated.

I see the "new_del_req.path_info = copy_path" just after
"Request.blank(copy_path " pattern again; what am I missing here?'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-03-27 17:56:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-03-27 18:01:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

I'm curious why you didn't choose the lenprefix method I mentioned to solve the naming conflicts problem? The current solution seems to work, but seems substandard as it has to parse through things not even dealing with the object at hand and might not get to its own versions if there are too many other near-hit names. Granted, they are just edge cases, but the edge cases could be a bit messy and easily avoided with lenprefix.

Now using a prefix length (Pascal-style strings). It's a better method.

Might mention that the version containers should only be used for one container or messy conflicts could occur. Or, fix that restriction by allowing container/prefix instead of just container.

mentioned in docs


Docs indicate use of Last-Modified header, but that's not true anymore (or at most it's a fallback that should never happen).

clarified docs


Typo of myobjet instead of myobject. Also, -DELETE typo instead of -X DELETE.
Nitpick: The curl examples don't follow the same args order and so might be a little confusing.

fixed


Could you reduce the new Listing* exceptions to just three? ListingIterError(Exception) ListingIterNotFound(ListingIterError) and ListingIterNotAuthorized(ListingIterError)

I initially thought the 4 exceptions were better, but I'm not tied to it. changed.


Is there a reason for the "lreq.path_info = path" just after creating lreq with the path? If so, maybe a quick comment as to why.

it's needed when the request is set from an existing env


The status_int handling of lresp seems a bit too assuming. The // 100 == 5 raise Error seems fine, but // 100 == 4 raise NotFound I think should be just matching 404 and the rest be lumped in with Error. I think before anything not 2xx was translated as 404, but that was wrong too.

fixed


I'm not sure if I'm reading things right, but it looks like PUTs of new versions will retain the x-object-meta- of the previous version, even if new values were specified in the new PUT request. As I understand object PUT requests, all metadata must be in the PUT or is discarded (unlike account/container metadata which accumulates).

oops. fixed


Inline comment indicates "Prevent (most) user errors". I'm curious what errors it does not prevent and why they're termed "user errors".

addressed with the above changes


If you're only going to use listing[-1] is there really a need to keep the whole listing?

no. changed


Why copy_headers and then creq.headers[x] = y just after? Same could be said about environ.

clarified the code


The self.container_name = lcontainer, self.object_name = listing[-1]['name'] lines are repeated.

because it is changing with the call to self.COPY or self.GET


I see the "new_del_req.path_info = copy_path" just after "Request.blank(copy_path " pattern again; what am I missing here?

addressed above'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-27 18:58:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Cool.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-03-28 19:24:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-03-28 20:20:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-03-28 20:48:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-03-28 20:51:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-07 03:59:46.000000000', 'message': 'object versioning

Object versioning in swift is implemented by using a "version manifest"
object. The version manifest keeps a ``<container>/<prefix>`` reference to
where the older versions of an object. This information is stored in the
``X-Object-Versions`` header of the object.

When data is ``PUT`` to an object with the ``X-Object-Versions`` header set,
the existing data in the file is redirected to a new object and the data in
the ``PUT`` request is saved as the data for the versioned object. The new
object name (for the previous version) is named by converting the
``Last-Modified`` header value of the current version to a unix timestamp and
appending that timestamp to the ``<container>/<prefix>`` value of the
``X-Object-Versions`` header.

Note that versioning large object manifests is not allowed. (However it
is possible to have a large object manifest point to versioned chunks.)

To use this, first, create an object with the ``X-Object-Versions`` header or
add the header to an existing object::

    curl -i -XPUT --data-binary 1 -H "X-Auth-Token: <token>" \
        -H "X-Object-Versions: versions/obj_" \
        http://<storage_url>/container/myobject

Now create a new version of that object::

    curl -i -XPUT --data-binary 2 -H "X-Auth-Token: <token>" \
        http://<storage_url>/container/myobject

Doug Weimer assisted in getting the tests working for this feature.

Change-Id: I4fcd723145e02bbb2ec1d3ad356713f5dea43b8b
'}, {'created': '2012-03-14 21:20:08.000000000', 'message': 'object versioning

Object versioning in swift is implemented by setting a flag on the container
to tell swift to version all objects in the container. The flag is the
``X-Versions-Location`` header on the container, and its value is the
container where the versions are stored.

When data is ``PUT`` into a versioned container (a container with the
versioning flag turned on), the existing data in the file is redirected to a
new object and the data in the ``PUT`` request is saved as the data for the
versioned object. The new object name (for the previous version) is named by
converting the ``Last-Modified`` header value of the current version to a
unix timestamp and appending that timestamp to the ``<container>`` value of
the ``X-Versions-Locations`` header on the container followed by the object
name and a ``/``.

A ``GET`` to a versioned object will return the current version of the object
without having to do any request redirects or metadata lookups.

Change-Id: I4fcd723145e02bbb2ec1d3ad356713f5dea43b8b

commit_message:
object versioning

Object versioning in swift is implemented by setting a flag on the container
to tell swift to version all objects in the container. The flag is the
``X-Versions-Location`` header on the container, and its value is the
container where the versions are stored.

When data is ``PUT`` into a versioned container (a container with the
versioning flag turned on), the existing data in the file is redirected to a
new object and the data in the ``PUT`` request is saved as the data for the
versioned object. The new object name (for the previous version) is
``<versions_container>/<object_name>/<timestamp>``, where the timestamp is
generated by converting the ``Last-Modified`` header value of the current
version to a unix timestamp.

A ``GET`` to a versioned object will return the current version of the object
without having to do any request redirects or metadata lookups.

Change-Id: I4fcd723145e02bbb2ec1d3ad356713f5dea43b8b

Allow yes-like values to be interpreted as bool

* Accept 'YES', 'yes', 'Y' and 'y'
* Remove duplicate function bool_from_header_value
* Fixes bug 965563

commit_message:
Support owner paramater to glance add

Fixes bug 962998

Allow the owner to specified as a first class image attribute
when creating a new image via the CLI, as it is currently for
image update.

Also added a simple fakeauth pipeline to allow the user, tenant
and admin status of API requests to be easily controlled by
functional tests.

Change-Id: I0f83d55d4a96ad3632fb238ad1758ec3f00ed3fd

subject: Add an optional delay to account reaping.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 330, 'name': 'John Dickinson', 'email': 'me@not.mn', 'username': 'notmyname'}, {'_account_id': 794, 'name': 'Marcelo Martins', 'email': 'marcelo.martins@rackspace.com', 'username': 'btorch'}, {'_account_id': 995, 'name': 'David Goetz', 'email': 'david.goetz@rackspace.com', 'username': 'david-goetz'}, {'_account_id': 1009, 'name': 'Greg Lange', 'email': 'greglange@gmail.com', 'username': 'greglange'}, {'_account_id': 1085, 'name': 'Jay Payne', 'email': 'letterj@gmail.com', 'username': 'letterj'}, {'_account_id': 1603, 'name': 'Florian Hines', 'email': 'syn@ronin.io', 'username': 'pandemicsyn'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 794, 'date': '2012-03-16 17:40:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-03-16 18:16:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

(1 inline comment)

I really don't like this patch. It starts adding in "business logic" to the base storage system. The storage system should reliably save and delete data when it is asked to do so. If delays need to be added to account deletion (for the "oops" moments), those need to be higher up in the stack.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-16 18:17:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-16 18:19:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Oops, forgot to update the overview_reaper doc.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-16 18:21:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-16 18:50:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-16 18:52:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

While I was on the same side of the issue as John with "Swift does exactly what you ask it to" there have been occasions where this has bit folks in the ass. The result is one group blaming the other for the problem (one for issuing the delete when they shouldn't have, the other for having no safety net).'}, {'account_id': 794, 'date': '2012-03-16 19:12:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I agree, this is a good safety net. Not everyone may want to have accounts deleted by the reaper right away for several purposes and not just "business".'}, {'account_id': 1085, 'date': '2012-03-19 20:22:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I would test for the delete_timestamp < put_timestamp and log that condition and clear out the delete_timestamp field.'}, {'account_id': 1085, 'date': '2012-03-19 20:37:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Another reason for this change is that by using delete_timestamp you can stager a large number of account deletes so they do not adversely impact the object servers.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-20 20:57:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Jay, I'd like to keep the delete_timestamp value if possible because changing that would make it different than the put_timestamp/delete_timestamp behaviors elsewhere in the system (see container, container_stat, and object tables).

I'm going to make a separate patch to provide an "clear marked-for-deletion" utility; I didn't want to hold up this patch with another one.

With that in mind, is it cool by you to allow this patch?'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-20 21:00:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Eh, I take a bit of that back (I'm misremembering code in Swift with code from another project). The only other code in Swift that does the put/delete_timestamp thing is the container_stat table.

I do think it's useful to keep a record of when the delete_timestamp was changed though."}, {'account_id': 794, 'date': '2012-03-21 15:20:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-21 15:26:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-21 15:27:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Okay, done.

We have to start over on reviews again though. :)

notmyname, can we get at least a neutral from you since this delay is not required and is off by default? In other words, with this patch nothing changes except the ability to do something (you don't like)."}, {'account_id': 794, 'date': '2012-03-21 16:29:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1603, 'date': '2012-03-22 21:09:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I'm ok with it. IMHO this only fall's under the "business process" view if you're a provider like $RAX. If you're using Swift for something else its more like of a safety feature.'}, {'account_id': 995, 'date': '2012-03-22 21:13:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-03-28 17:29:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-28 17:30:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-python26/36/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-python27/36/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-merge/151/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-03-28 17:47:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: No score

I absolutely think this is a bad feature for swift because it changes the "contract" with a client. A storage system should delete data when requested and store data when requested. Adding in an "undo" timeframe to account deletes changes the expectations of what the storage system provides.

All that being said, I will remove my -2 and, if there is a consensus of other core devs, it can be added.'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-03-28 18:09:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Add an optional delay to account reaping.

Normally, the reaper begins deleting account information for deleted
accounts immediately. With this patch you can set it to delay its
work. You set the delay_reaping value in the [account-reaper] section
of the account-server.conf. The value is in seconds; 2592000 = 30
days, for example.

Unfortunately, there are currently zero tests for the account-reaper.
This also needs fixing, but I thought I'd submit this delay patch
alone for consideration.

Change-Id: Ic077df9cdd95c5d3f8949dd3bbe9893cf24c6623

commit_message:
StaticWeb fixes.

The previous staticweb had the silly problem of global state for
concurrent requests. This fixes that.

Also, the WSGI spec indicates start_response might not be called
right away and is only guaranteed to be called just before the first
"chunk" of the output iterator returns. This fixes StaticWeb's
previously incorrect assumption.

A thorough review of this code would be much appreciated; I've
messed it up enough times to not be completely trusted with it.

Change-Id: Ie751c24e21db7a884a83a731fbf2f4309437302c

commit_message:
Allow skipping exercises.

- Catch a special exit signal 55 to notify that we want to skip an
  excercise.
- Move is_enabled_service to functions.
- Fix bug 928390.

Change-Id: Iebf7a6f30a0f305a2a70173fb6b988bc07e34292

commit_message:
Strip auth token from log output.

Fix bug 956777.

This patch updates _safe_log, which is used for rpc debug logs, to not
include auth tokens.

Change-Id: I36bb4233acd356f85b0e6006a6b812a67605b393

subject: Tweak security port validation for ICMP
messages:
[{'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-25 20:51:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Yep, looks like a good bug to have fixed for essex.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-03-26 13:02:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm not a big fan of the silent fix to the UDP port range (65536  -> 65535) that is not mentioned in a bug or in the commit message.

I'm also a bit unsure about allowing type:code others than -1:-1 when the code explicitly limited accepted values to just that (including a test case and a comment saying 'For icmp, only -1:-1 is allowed for type:code')

I'd like to make sure that in both cases, this was not done for a reason, and we would introduce a regression here by "fixing" it. Comments from the original author could help.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-26 21:11:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

looks like this bug may be related:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/965591

I can't replicate on current trunk, so I think this commit fixed it."}, {'account_id': 161, 'date': '2012-03-27 19:49:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

Made a couple of comments in line. The code itself looks fine, but I think we should add additional tests to verify attempting to add and remove rules that aren't in valid ranges."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-03-28 09:11:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This is a milestone-proposed review, not a master review. Added tests are fine, but the idea here is to reject or accept the patch that was submitted to master, not to improve it. Additional tests can be proposed to master and backported here, but we shouldn't submit a different patch here than the one that was pushed to master."}, {'account_id': 161, 'date': '2012-03-28 14:28:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Apologies. Like I said, the patch itself looks good, so I'm changing my vote to +1 :-)"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-28 16:40:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-25 02:40:45.000000000', 'message': 'Tweak security port validation for ICMP

Horizon allows for ICMP to be type:code.
Type and code can be from -1 to 255.

API refers to both EC2 and Nova APIs

This patch attempts to resolve:
1. API code throws exceptations when 0 is passed for either field
2. API code validates type:code like from->to range.  type and code
   are independent
3. Update unit tests for this new set of operations.

A side effect is that the following are allowed type:code.
-1:X
X:-1

The code assumes that -1 is a wildcard for the field.

bug 956967

Change-Id: Ieb6989815afc6986b72e0efc7611c2cc353ab5d8
'}]
commit_message:
Tweak security port validation for ICMP

Horizon allows for ICMP to be type:code.
Type and code can be from -1 to 255.

API refers to both EC2 and Nova APIs

This patch attempts to resolve:
1. API code throws exceptations when 0 is passed for either field
2. API code validates type:code like from->to range.  type and code
   are independent
3. Update unit tests for this new set of operations.

A side effect is that the following are allowed type:code.
-1:X
X:-1

The code assumes that -1 is a wildcard for the field.

bug 956967

Change-Id: Ieb6989815afc6986b72e0efc7611c2cc353ab5d8

subject: Add ability to list roles for calling user/tenant.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-03-14 21:47:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-03-14 21:48:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-03-14 22:10:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I'd like to see something like this (it's obviously useful), but the naming tripped me up, and I realized this makes more sense (to me):

    role-list: all roles in the system

    user-role-list: all roles granted to a user (default=me)

That would circumvent the problem with a default user value on role-list and provide the desired functionality."}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-03-15 17:57:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Dolph - my preference would be to stick with the initial noun verb sequence - so "role-list-user" with a default of the invoking user.'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-03-28 16:14:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-27 22:16:14.000000000', 'message': "Fixed db conn recovery issue. Fixes bug 954971.

This implementation wraps the db method calls and retries the method if an attempt failed due to db connectivity issues. Defines 2 new configuration parameters viz sql_max_retries and sql_retry_interval (values default to 10 and 1 respectively).
This implementation does not have any overhead in the normal case, as opposed to MySQLPingListener implementation, which does a 'select 1' query every time a connection is checkout from the pool.

Change-Id: I24240f22bca445b9ab76a1594631b5eaca393b4d
"}]
commit_message:
Fixed db conn recovery issue. Fixes bug 954971.

This implementation wraps the db method calls and retries the method if an attempt failed due to db connectivity issues. Defines 2 new configuration parameters viz sql_max_retries and sql_retry_interval (values default to 10 and 1 respectively).
This implementation does not have any overhead in the normal case, as opposed to MySQLPingListener implementation, which does a 'select 1' query every time a connection is checkout from the pool.

Change-Id: I24240f22bca445b9ab76a1594631b5eaca393b4d

commit_message:
Use unique per-test S3 bucket name.

Addresses bug 955527

Avoids a race between the S3 testcase body and the bucket clean-out
in the S3 test teardown, running near concurrently in the Jenkins
python26 and python27 builds.

Change-Id: I10f013b02bb74db2cbfc692ed372121d21bca3fb

commit_message:
Add MAX_PASSWORD_LENGTH check in backendutils.

Add a check for max password length to password hash/check
functions in backendutils.

Fixes an issue where large passwords can cause segfaults in
keystone diablo.

Fixes LP Bug #957359.

Change-Id: I24de1a295d5f54a070750315e78db968658898d3

commit_message:
Set content_type for messages in Qpid notifier.

Fix bug 963050.

This patch is the Qpid equivalent for a patch that just went in for the
rabbit/kombu notifier.  Glance encodes the message in json format before
passing it in to the notifier.  Explicitly set the content type for the
messages to 'application/json'.

Change-Id: I2f83f51487541b951f3eca0ae4d160a64f5a3db1

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-27 22:12:51.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid leaking secrets into config logging.

Fixes bug 962385

Configuration option values are logged when debug is enabled,
which is in turn exposed via the glance-logcapture nose plugin
when tests fail in Jenkins.

Allow options to be declared secret so that their value is
obfuscated before logging.

Also proposed to openstack-common as:

  https://review.openstack.org/5694

Change-Id: Ifdd1696f40c069f83c160afb0bf399da21796b8a
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid leaking secrets into config logging.

Fixes bug 962385

Configuration option values are logged when debug is enabled,
which is in turn exposed via the glance-logcapture nose plugin
when tests fail in Jenkins.

Allow options to be declared secret so that their value is
obfuscated before logging.

Also proposed to openstack-common as:

  https://review.openstack.org/5694

Change-Id: Ifdd1696f40c069f83c160afb0bf399da21796b8a

[{'created': '2012-03-27 21:38:45.000000000', 'message': "Re-instate security group delete test case

While fixing lp#956366, we realized that it's fine to delete a security
group referenced by an ingress rule of another security group because
the ingress rule gets deleted.

Re-instate the test for this specific case, but test that the ingress
rule gets deleted rather than an exception being thrown.

Change-Id: I81ad16431f5f8f13561dfcb320213366e1e8864e
"}]
commit_message:
Re-instate security group delete test case

While fixing lp#956366, we realized that it's fine to delete a security
group referenced by an ingress rule of another security group because
the ingress rule gets deleted.

Re-instate the test for this specific case, but test that the ingress
rule gets deleted rather than an exception being thrown.

Change-Id: I81ad16431f5f8f13561dfcb320213366e1e8864e

commit_message:
Specify location when creating s3 bucket.

Fixes bug 961050

Avoids bucket creation failure when a region-specific S3 endpoint
(e.g. s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com) and also bucket create-on-demand
are configured.

Change-Id: Ieba9c535ccb961a1f81bd2632b5ac49c23ac7901

Allow yes-like values to be interpreted as bool

* Accept 'YES', 'yes', 'Y' and 'y'
* Remove duplicate function bool_from_header_value
* Fixes bug 965563

Change-Id: I593a50117fd339a8ab281a8daad734770ca9960c

subject: Tag test cases not compatible with multiprocess
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 191, 'name': 'Trey Morris', 'email': 'trey.morris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'tr3buchet'}, {'_account_id': 385, 'name': 'Jason Kölker', 'email': 'jason@koelker.net', 'username': 'jason-koelker'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2245, 'name': 'Jacky Hu', 'email': 'hudayou@hotmail.com', 'username': 'hudayou'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-03-09 15:12:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Is Bueno!'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-09 17:42:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Would it make more sense to parallelize test suites instead of test cases?

It would likely make it easier to avoid concurrency problems while still getting most of the benefit of using multiple processors.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2012-03-10 11:52:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-03-10 17:37:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-03-13 16:57:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I agree with johannes here: explicitly choosing what to parallelize would probably be clearer than choosing what we can't. Put more simply, it's probably easier and safer to opt-in rather than opt-out."}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2012-03-14 02:00:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I am not sure I understand how should I proceed here,
Do you mean we should give test cases compatible with 
multiprocess a 'mp' attribute?
The intension here is, later test case not compatible with
multiprocess could be solved one by one and the 'sp'  attribute
could be removed in the mean time.

I am not sure it's feasible to parallize by testsuite,
Since a suite is a composite object."}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2012-03-17 06:54:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-03-20 19:25:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

For discussion purposes, there should 4 options:
A) no multiprocess
B) multiprocess suites, single process cases
C) single process suites, multiprocess cases
D) all multiprocess

_A_ obviously sucks.
_B_ feels natural. 10 test suites will operate in 10 processes and all of the test cases will be run in each of those 10. Each suite should get its own db or table in a db. In this case there should be no worry about which test cases are compatible with multiprocess.
_C_ feels a little screwy. 10 test suites with 15 test cases each will be run in 150 processes. Each test case has its own process. Test cases will need to be written with this in mind.
_D_ doesn't really make sense unless considered on a suite by suite basis.

I believe what they are suggesting here is B."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-28 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-28 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]

Give such test case a 'sp'(single process) attribute.

Change-Id: I022f883613ecbe5a55f607878d7f117b0bdbde26

subject: Check for valid task_state before server delete is allowed. Fixes bug 960061
messages:
[{'account_id': 2883, 'date': '2012-03-20 11:52:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-03-20 13:52:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

There are a number of cases where a VM can get "stuck" with a non None task_state.  For example if the compute manager is restarted whilst an action is in progress.

Forcing a check on task_state will mean that the user cannot delete a VM in this state.

I think the level of checking here needs more granularity, for example it should be a check of specifici combinations of vm_state and task_state (as per the orginal code before it was refactored) - and there should be something that allows operations conditionally depending on the time since "updated_at".

So for example it would allow for rules like:

Delete allowed if:

vm_state     task_state      Delta since updated
Active       None            Any
Active       Image_Snapshot  5 minutes'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-20 13:55:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

What Phil said :)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-20 13:56:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Phil, BTW, to get fixed-width formatted comments, just prefix a line with a space...

So, as an example, here is

 some fixed-width code

Best,

-jay'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-03-20 13:58:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

(Reposted with formating)

There are a number of cases where a VM can get "stuck" with a non None task_state. For example if the compute manager is restarted whilst an action is in progress. Forcing a check on task_state will mean that the user cannot delete a VM in this state. I think the level of checking here needs more granularity, for example it should be a check of specifici combinations of vm_state and task_state (as per the orginal code before it was refactored) - and there should be something that allows operations conditionally depending on the time since "updated_at". So for example it would allow for rules like: 

 Delete allowed if: 
 vm_state    task_state      Delta since updated 
 Active      None            Any 
 Active      Image_Snapshot  5 minutes'}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-03-20 15:52:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Phil, this sounds like a pretty good amount of work. I agree that always requiring task state to be None will just be creating more bugs. Perhaps this bug should linger while we propose new functionality for the next release?"}, {'account_id': 2883, 'date': '2012-03-27 10:43:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

This bug is now linked to the blueprint : https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/compute-instance-cleanup-service'}, {'account_id': 2883, 'date': '2012-03-28 05:23:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

This bug needs to be fixed using some cleanup daemon. This is now linked to a blueprint mentioned above.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-20 11:06:37.000000000', 'message': 'Check for valid task_state before server delete is allowed.
Fixes bug 960061

The task_state values were not checked when server is deleted thus
allowing to delete a server in task_state-image_snapshot. This is now
fixed. Only allowed task_state is "None"

Change-Id: Ib49cc3baa71278260420f3eaf622409bfa8b6685
'}, {'created': '2012-03-20 11:52:32.000000000', 'message': 'Check for valid task_state before server delete is allowed.
Fixes bug 960061

The task_state values were not checked when server is deleted thus
allowing to delete a server in task_state-image_snapshot. This is now
fixed. Only allowed task_state is "None"

Added self to Authors file
Change-Id: Ib49cc3baa71278260420f3eaf622409bfa8b6685
'}]
commit_message:
Check for valid task_state before server delete is allowed.
Fixes bug 960061

The task_state values were not checked when server is deleted thus
allowing to delete a server in task_state-image_snapshot. This is now
fixed. Only allowed task_state is "None"

Added self to Authors file
Change-Id: Ib49cc3baa71278260420f3eaf622409bfa8b6685

subject: Remove any duplicate FixedIP id values in FixedIp cleanup
messages:
[{'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-27 19:49:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

hmm.  This seems useful, but It actually looks like the bug might be read_deleted='yes'.  I don't think we need to worry about deleted fixed ips."}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-27 20:58:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Well, that might be _another_ bug in this function Vish:-)  I'd love to see the actual SQL to see if there are any _really_ nasty problems hidden in there also (e.g. locking issues)

I'm going off the bug report here - apparently somehow we were trying to update 1.7 million rows.  The user only has 25k rows in the fixed_ips table, of which ~140 were "allocation=False and instance_id is not null"

Dprince fixed a bug here as well, which might have fixed the problem, but it's difficult to know because it's SQLAlchemy being difficult (the filter causes row duplication).

The fix is hopefully harmless (although it will be pretty slow on 1.7 million entries!) but will at least log a warning if this is still happening.  As with the SQL logging patch, I think we're pretty screwed trying to diagnose problems if we don't have it...'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-27 22:09:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

This is ok i guess.  Definitely strangeness happening here. I would be curious to see how many rows are in the source network table.  It seems like there must be a whole bunch of deleted entries?'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-27 22:51:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Ah i just realized what the problem is here.  FixedIps don't have foreign key relations anymore."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-27 22:58:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Fix is here: https://review.openstack.org/5893'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-27 23:33:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Vish's 5893 is a much better fix"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-27 18:38:00.000000000', 'message': 'Remove any duplicate FixedIP id values in FixedIp cleanup

Bug #965333 showed that a huge number of duplicate FixedIp.id values
were being returned, causing major performance issues in the Python
code.

It may be that the fix for bug 953708 also fixes this, as the problem
looks to have been a SQLAlchemy oddity.  Add logging so that if this
is happening, we can know.  (It looks like the bug reporter had 1.7
million rows being returned for 150 unique values.)

Bug #965333

Change-Id: I2f5cb3d0d665258c14bc6b7bbfcaf751dcff20e4
'}]
commit_message:
Remove any duplicate FixedIP id values in FixedIp cleanup

Bug #965333 showed that a huge number of duplicate FixedIp.id values
were being returned, causing major performance issues in the Python
code.

It may be that the fix for bug 953708 also fixes this, as the problem
looks to have been a SQLAlchemy oddity.  Add logging so that if this
is happening, we can know.  (It looks like the bug reporter had 1.7
million rows being returned for 150 unique values.)

Bug #965333

Change-Id: I2f5cb3d0d665258c14bc6b7bbfcaf751dcff20e4

subject: Ensure functional db connection in configure_db()
messages:
[{'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-03-24 15:57:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

Thanks for the patch Adam,

Just a couple of questions inline to clear up.

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 1420, 'date': '2012-03-26 18:14:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Hmm, having problems getting gerrit to move my in-line reply out of the 'draft' stage, pasting here in the meantime..

Connections seem to only persist when there is a reference to the connection held open. So no, it doesn't leak an explicit call to close() can be certainly be added 'just in case'. I would have also thought wrapping the connect() method during configure_db() would be enough to trigger the wrapper for all sessions that attempt to connect, but it turns out thats not the case. I haven't been able to look at SQLA's internals there, but I believe its doing some stuff internally with its connection pooling and a direct call to connect() is needed to trigger the wrapper at startup."}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-03-27 08:55:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks for the response Adam.

If the connection is definitely not being leaked, then I agree that the lack of an explicit close() shouldn't hold up this patch.

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-27 16:51:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'm cool with this. Waldon, what do you think?"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-03-27 17:25:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-24 01:28:29.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure functional db connection in configure_db()

During initial database setup, ensure we can physically connect
to the database and allow a failed connection to make use of the
new retry mechanism instead of registry startup failing outright.

Fixes lp bug #959426.

Change-Id: I1c87b19913c4204465e5d2027f2f184f0f358fd0
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure functional db connection in configure_db()

During initial database setup, ensure we can physically connect
to the database and allow a failed connection to make use of the
new retry mechanism instead of registry startup failing outright.

Fixes lp bug #959426.

Change-Id: I1c87b19913c4204465e5d2027f2f184f0f358fd0

[{'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2012-03-21 19:45:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'd like to get some other input on this, before I + it.

I think that instead of adding something hacky like this, we should just make another forms.py for syspanel. I know it is code duplication, but I do not think we should be using the standard project dashboard forms in the syspanel."}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-03-25 06:39:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm gonna agree with Jake on that.

The easy way to do it right now is actually to break the affected code out into a separate method on the form class, import the form class into the a forms.py for syspanel, subclass it and override the method, and then pass that new form to the syspanel view.

I've done things like that for other cases in syspanel. That keeps code duplication to a minimum until we have real divergence."}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-25 12:06:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-25 12:10:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
updating image should redirect back to original page

 * fix bug 960448
 * syspanel inherits nova UpdateImage view/form
 * add completion_view to form base object, and get_success_url()
   that reverse the proper url for redirection on success
   handling
 * syspanel AdminEditImage was pointless because it didn't
   override the 'url', now fixed

Change-Id: Ia8f24c7a895b397f11978a59232ab00da3e8813d

[{'created': '2012-03-26 23:13:44.000000000', 'message': "Reduce the image cache manager periodic interval.

When this code was written, I (incorrectly) believed a periodic
task tick was about a second. It turns out that by default they're
between 60 seconds and 120 seconds depending on a random value.
Therefore, reduce the interval to something more reasonable.

Change-Id: Id840c755f954e3e371d7238243f2248e8d402c7b
"}]
commit_message:
Reduce the image cache manager periodic interval.

When this code was written, I (incorrectly) believed a periodic
task tick was about a second. It turns out that by default they're
between 60 seconds and 120 seconds depending on a random value.
Therefore, reduce the interval to something more reasonable.

Change-Id: Id840c755f954e3e371d7238243f2248e8d402c7b

subject: Support owner paramater to glance add
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 91, 'name': 'Alvaro', 'email': 'aloga@ifca.unican.es', 'username': 'aloga'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2284, 'name': 'Eoghan Glynn', 'email': 'eglynn@redhat.com', 'username': 'eglynn'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-23 15:01:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2012-03-23 15:31:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-03-23 15:43:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

We set the owner based on the auth context. I don't want to allow a user to add images to another user's account like this. I wouldn't be against allowing admins to add images with specific owners, but this bug/fix as they stand shouldn't land."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-23 16:06:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

bcwaldon: If a change like this on the client side can cause an image to be assigned to an incorrect owner on the server, then we have a serious security breach.  What the server *should* be doing is checking the submitting user's credentials and, if they do not have administrative privilege or if owner is not present, it should set the owner to the user's project.  That's how I coded this stuff in the first place.

I still have no problem with this patch, and I don't believe it represents the security issue you seem to believe it does."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-23 16:12:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

Agree with Brian. This is a security issue. I believe the bug may be that the owner field is settable during an image update.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-03-23 16:22:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Brian,

Well, we already allow the owner attribute to be settable when the image is created directly via:

  POST /v1/images
  x-image-meta-owner: fred
  ...

and also when the image is updated either via the glance CLI or PUT /v1/images.

So it sounds like what's need instead to disallow the above existing degrees of freedom on create and update, right?

/Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-03-23 16:27:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Eoghan: yep, this is a security bug. We need to lock down owner from being settable through that public interface. I'd be open to just requiring admin rather than locking it down completely if you see a use for that."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-23 16:33:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

Hmmm, interesting; as I originally coded it, setting owner should only have been possible for admin, so this is either a bug in my original coding (and tests, but those have been removed), or some other form of bitrot.

That said, I still see no problems with this patch to the *client*; the *server* is the one that should support the policy, and if we want admins to be able to set owners (necessary for them to set owner = None, i.e., public images—unless that's also vanished or bitrotted), the client will need to support this."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-03-23 16:48:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

You're right, Kevin. It looks like the service does restrict modifying the owner attribute to just admins. However, the service does not return a 403 when a request is made to change the owner field by a non-admin user. Anywho, this patch is clear to land."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-23 17:12:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Yeah, I designed it to silently overwrite the owner field.  I believe other unrecognized fields are treated the same way, so that seemed to be a good solution.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-26 14:59:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

OK, so this is what happens after this patch is applied, right?

a) If the user is an admin, owner is set to whatever the value of owner field in CLI is, or the admin's user ID if not specified

b) If the user is NOT an admin, the owner is set to the value of the user's ID -- and if the user specified "owner=blah" in the CLI, then a custom property called 'owner' will be created?

I think that b) should *not* create a custom property called 'owner' as that is confusing...

Thoughts?
-jay'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-26 15:56:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

a) is correct, except that it's the admin's tenant ID.

b) is almost correct; again, substitute tenant ID, and a custom property 'owner' is not created."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-26 16:25:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Kevin: I believe it is the tenant OR the user ID, depending on the setting of the owner_is_tenant config option, right?

Also, if you take a look at the bug report, you will see that a custom user property was being created. Does this patch change that behaviour in the case of a non-admin user of the glance CLI?

-jay'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-26 16:53:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Jay: Yes, you are right; I was simplifying by saying only what the default action is.

On the server side, what we have is this (glance.registry.api.v1.images:Controller.create):

        # Set up the image owner
        if not req.context.is_admin or 'owner' not in image_data:
            image_data['owner'] = req.context.owner

So, if the image owner is not admin, the image_data['owner'] will be set to that in the context.  Also, if 'owner' is not provided in image_data, it will be set by this code.  The server does not do any transformation on the submitted data to make it into a custom user property.

Looking at the code submitted in this patch, what I see is this: without the patch, "owner" present on the command line will get stuffed into the 'properties' element of image_meta, and thus will result in an 'owner' custom property.  With the patch, because it uses .pop(), 'owner' will never appear in the 'properties' element; it will always go directly into image_meta and be submitted to the server, which will apply the rules described above.

So, without this patch, we have the bug; with this patch, we do not have this bug.  Without this patch, we have no security issue; with this patch, we have no security issue.  I think this patch is good to go :)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-26 17:30:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

OK, I see your point, Kevin (on the pop())

However, I would like to see a test added that verifies that a custom owner property is not created if the user is not an admin.

A test that verifies the bug behaviour is no longer apparent is OK to ask for, right? :)

-jay"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-26 17:34:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yeah :)'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-03-27 12:00:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-03-27 12:06:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Extended test coverage to assert that the expected behaviour occurs for both admin users (owner is set as specified) and non-admin users (owner is set to the tenant ID), also that owner is no longer treated as a custom property.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-27 15:12:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-03-27 15:36:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-27 15:43:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3004/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-merge/503/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-pep8/683/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-python26/195/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-python27/185/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-27 15:43:48.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
Support owner paramater to glance add

Fixes bug 962998

Allow the owner to specified as a first class image attribute
when creating a new image via the CLI, as it is currently for
image update.

Also added a simple fakeauth pipeline to allow the user, tenant
and admin status of API requests to be easily controlled by
functional tests.

Change-Id: I0f83d55d4a96ad3632fb238ad1758ec3f00ed3fd

commit_message:
A missing checksum does not mean the image is corrupt.

This is a logic error in the code. A missing checksum should not
imply that the image is corrupt. Note that corrupt images are only
logged, not removed, so there is no data loss for users with this
bug.

Change-Id: Ic644517d3b8e9646fe943e5cef485c4168ebb5b5

ERROR: string indices must be integers, not str

to:
[root@robinlinux python-novaclient]# nova list
ERROR: 503 Service Unavailable

Unable to obtain admin token

Bug #962454

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-25 21:37:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

The fix looks perfectly fine to me, but I'm confused by the bug report

The reporter saw:

  <resizeNotAllowed code="403" xmlns="http://docs.openstack.org/compute/api/v1.1"><message>You are not authorized to complete this action.
  Details: 401 Unauthorized

  This server could not verify that you are authorized to access the document you requested. Either you supplied the wrong credentials (e.g., bad password), or your browser does not understand how to supply the credentials required.

  Authentication required </message></resizeNotAllowed>

i.e. the error code is 403, but the message is clearly for a 401 error. How did that happen?'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-03-26 13:23:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Would like to get to the bottom of Mark's remark before approving this (and be sure it actually fixes the original bug)."}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-03-26 18:06:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The body of the message comes from glance, and until recently 401 and 403 raised the same client exception (glance_exception.NotAuthorized).  It so happens that nova wraps this exception to a 403, thus the mixed messages.

With this commit glance raises separate exceptions for 401/403: https://github.com/openstack/glance/commit/b0a608c09f0cd83b8ab3cccc8a3851bc3c98733c

It no longer appears possible to repro the exact scenario described in this bug.  However, it looks like nova has not fully digested the glance changes - here is a bug I just found while prodding, for example: https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/965540

Issues related to the glance/nova integration should probably be filed as different bugs as they are reproduced however.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-03-27 09:53:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-03-27 10:07:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-27 10:24:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

column values in table columns on render

Fixes bug 964739

When loading the syspanel instance view, the tenant name
is being added to cache, but before it is instantiated.
After it is being instantiated in the get_data method,

commit_message:
Fix issue with caching of non-existing
column values in table columns on render

Fixes bug 964739

When loading the syspanel instance view, the tenant name
is being added to cache, but before it is instantiated.
After it is being instantiated in the get_data method,
it is being read from cache, but there is the None value
already.

Change-Id: I6d06c8058a05c864dc60cb4c813abf8074456c36

commit_message:
Adds an option for "sticky" tabs.

Uses cookies to store the active tab state for a given user via an
opt-in attribute on the TabGroup.

Fixes bug 964774.

Change-Id: I361942bec6bc789447bd38153d2b1b5ab0fb4b26

commit_message:
Adds PanelGroup class and site customization hook.

  * Adds a PanelGroup class and slightly reworks the way panel
    ordering is handled to fix bug 963550.

  * Adds the option to load a python module containing
    site customizations after the site is fully initialized,
    but before the URLConf is dynamically constructed.
    Fixes bug 965839.

Change-Id: Idc5358f2db6751494bcdfc382ec3bb6af65199b9

commit_message:
User needs to log in messages.

When a user tries to access a page and they are
not logged in, the message needs to be about
authentication, NOT authorization as it was before
this change. Needing to log in has nothing to do
with permissions and the messaging needs to
reflect that.

Fixes Bug #965810

Change-Id: Ic9de135d4d3d8e7b19524cd100a3fe7ea027e1f4

commit_message:
Replacing the caption tag in data tables.

Using a new row in the thead instead now. This is
due to a WebKit bug where the caption element's
size cannot be correctly calculated on tables with
borders.

Fixes Bug #965603

Change-Id: I08962c850061860ed0bd749deb389205c5b731fe

commit_message:
Destroy src and dest instances when deleting in RESIZE_VERIFY

Fixes bug 963630

Since deletes are allowed during RESIZE_VERIFY, we need to ensure that
the original instance is also deleted so we don't leak resources.

Change-Id: Ibfd5ad4e427c247f1cd5fddcf4f43b30839a6c4f

"}, {'created': '2012-03-26 20:35:00.000000000', 'message': 'Clean up the live/block migration shared storage check (#891756)

The shared storage check for live and block migration is currently
very confusing e.g.

  * The mounted_on_same_shared_storage() method raises FileNotFound
    for the caller to catch rather than just returning a boolean to
    indicate whether the hosts share storage

  * mounted_on_same_shared_storage() has a "filename is not None" check
    in its finally clause which doesn't make sense

  * InvalidSharedStorage is not raised in the live migration case,

  * instead
    FileNotFound is raised

Clean all this up by having mounted_on_same_shared_storage() simply
return a boolean and have simple logic to raise InvalidSharedStorage for live
migration where no shared storage is available or for block migration where
shared storage is available.

Change-Id: I96f354fe41d9ce77c4cc98903f0d5a9de99ac4f6
'}, {'created': '2012-03-26 20:36:49.000000000', 'message': 'Clean up the shared storage check (#891756)

The shared storage check for live and block migration is currently
very confusing e.g.

  * The mounted_on_same_shared_storage() method raises FileNotFound
    for the caller to catch rather than just returning a boolean to
    indicate whether the hosts share storage

  * mounted_on_same_shared_storage() has a "filename is not None" check
    in its finally clause which doesn't make sense

  * InvalidSharedStorage is not raised in the live migration case,

  * instead
    FileNotFound is raised

Clean all this up by having mounted_on_same_shared_storage() simply
return a boolean and have simple logic to raise InvalidSharedStorage for live
migration where no shared storage is available or for block migration where
shared storage is available.

Change-Id: I96f354fe41d9ce77c4cc98903f0d5a9de99ac4f6
'}]
commit_message:
Clean up the shared storage check (#891756)

The shared storage check for live and block migration is currently
very confusing e.g.

  * The mounted_on_same_shared_storage() method raises FileNotFound
    for the caller to catch rather than just returning a boolean to
    indicate whether the hosts share storage

  * mounted_on_same_shared_storage() has a "filename is not None" check
    in its finally clause which doesn't make sense

  * InvalidSharedStorage is not raised in the live migration case,

  * instead
    FileNotFound is raised

Clean all this up by having mounted_on_same_shared_storage() simply
return a boolean and have simple logic to raise InvalidSharedStorage for live
migration where no shared storage is available or for block migration where
shared storage is available.

Change-Id: I96f354fe41d9ce77c4cc98903f0d5a9de99ac4f6

commit_message:
Don't set instance ACTIVE until it's really active

Fixes bug 963656

Reverting a resize would end up setting the instance ACTIVE before the
driver had finished all of the work starting up the original instance.
If the instance is deleted quickly after the revert, a race condition
could occur between restarting the original instance and deleting it.

Change-Id: Iba26ad7d1bc1049137f94e13898be86698963fb3

This patch addresses a minor performance regression in a recent change
to this function.  This change ensures that the deep copy is only done
if we really need to.  Previously, the deep copy was being done for all

commit_message:
Improve performance of safe_log().

This patch addresses a minor performance regression in a recent change
to this function.  This change ensures that the deep copy is only done
if we really need to.  Previously, the deep copy was being done for all
messages that included a 'method', not just messages with a method that
contain an argument to be sanitized.

Change-Id: I190c5963ecaf70b0aea4e12a2fdc19deb5c1fea2

commit_message:
Set up the log handler only once.

When the NOVACLIENT_DEBUG environment variable is set, each time
python-novaclient outputs HTTP debugging information, it outputs
n copies of the information, where n is the number of times it has
output debugging information previously.

This is because a logging handler is added each time the log output
rather than only once on initialization.

This patch moves the log handler setup into module level.

Fixes bug 963547.

Change-Id: Icf503e39723d591951810dea0118ffbb41107775

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-25 02:28:41.000000000', 'message': 'Handle correctly QuotaError in EC2 API

Without this patch, EC2 API returns UnknownError when quota is exceeded, see bug #853381

This patch fixes that by handling the exception. Now euca-run-instances returns useful information:

$ euca-run-instances --instance-count 10 --instance-type m1.8gb.2cpus.diskless ami-00000012
QuotaError: Quota exceeded: code=InstanceLimitExceeded

Change-Id: I1f7b381b34d2f538b7cc2d9582a40fd8bf88fbc3
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>
'}]
commit_message:
Handle correctly QuotaError in EC2 API

Without this patch, EC2 API returns UnknownError when quota is exceeded, see bug #853381

This patch fixes that by handling the exception. Now euca-run-instances returns useful information:

$ euca-run-instances --instance-count 10 --instance-type m1.8gb.2cpus.diskless ami-00000012
QuotaError: Quota exceeded: code=InstanceLimitExceeded

Change-Id: I1f7b381b34d2f538b7cc2d9582a40fd8bf88fbc3
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-25 02:01:36.000000000', 'message': 'Fix launching of guests where instances_path is on GlusterFS

The FUSE module does not (currentl) support O_DIRECT on files.
This prevents QEMU from starting guests using 'cache=none' for
their disks located on a GlusterFS filesystem. The same also
applies for a handful of other filesystems (notably tmpfs, or
any other FUSE filesystem).

This patch introduces a startup check in Nova compute service
which tries to create a file $instances_path/.direct_io.test
using the O_DIRECT flag. If this succeeds, then cache=none
will be used for all disks, otherwise it will fallback to
using cache=writethrough. While the latter does not have
performance which is as consistent as cache=none, it is still
host-crash safe and preserves data integrity with migration,
if the filesystem is cache coherant (cluster filesystems like
GlusterFS are, NFS by constrast is not).

By doing the dynamic check for O_DIRECT, we ensure that if
future FUSE modules gain O_DIRECT support, Nova will automatically
do the right thing.

* nova/tests/test_libvirt.py: Stub out os.open in
  the _check_xml_and_disk_driver() to enable testing of
  both O_DIRECT and non-O_DIRECT code paths
* nova/tests/test_virt_drivers.py: Set instances_path to
  the current directory
* nova/virt/libvirt.xml.template: Replace hardcoded 'none'
  string with the '$cachemode' variable for all disks.
  Add missing 'cache' attribute for the config disk
* nova/virt/libvirt/connection.py: Check whether O_DIRECT
  is supported on the "FLAGS.instances_path" directory
  and use 'none' for cachemode if it is, 'writethrough'
  otherwise

Bug: 959637
Change-Id: I60cbff1c3ad8299fe2aa37099390f9235f6724d0
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix launching of guests where instances_path is on GlusterFS

The FUSE module does not (currentl) support O_DIRECT on files.
This prevents QEMU from starting guests using 'cache=none' for
their disks located on a GlusterFS filesystem. The same also
applies for a handful of other filesystems (notably tmpfs, or
any other FUSE filesystem).

This patch introduces a startup check in Nova compute service
which tries to create a file $instances_path/.direct_io.test
using the O_DIRECT flag. If this succeeds, then cache=none
will be used for all disks, otherwise it will fallback to
using cache=writethrough. While the latter does not have
performance which is as consistent as cache=none, it is still
host-crash safe and preserves data integrity with migration,
if the filesystem is cache coherant (cluster filesystems like
GlusterFS are, NFS by constrast is not).

By doing the dynamic check for O_DIRECT, we ensure that if
future FUSE modules gain O_DIRECT support, Nova will automatically
do the right thing.

* nova/tests/test_libvirt.py: Stub out os.open in
  the _check_xml_and_disk_driver() to enable testing of
  both O_DIRECT and non-O_DIRECT code paths
* nova/tests/test_virt_drivers.py: Set instances_path to
  the current directory
* nova/virt/libvirt.xml.template: Replace hardcoded 'none'
  string with the '$cachemode' variable for all disks.
  Add missing 'cache' attribute for the config disk
* nova/virt/libvirt/connection.py: Check whether O_DIRECT
  is supported on the "FLAGS.instances_path" directory
  and use 'none' for cachemode if it is, 'writethrough'
  otherwise

Bug: 959637
Change-Id: I60cbff1c3ad8299fe2aa37099390f9235f6724d0
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

 * If there is more than one volume host, snapshots need to be
   created on the host that has the volume.  Sending the request
   through the scheduler means that the snapshot will sometimes
   be created on the wrong host and fail.
 * Fixes bug 960437

"}]
commit_message:
Don't send snapshot requests through the scheduler

 * If there is more than one volume host, snapshots need to be
   created on the host that has the volume.  Sending the request
   through the scheduler means that the snapshot will sometimes
   be created on the wrong host and fail.
 * Fixes bug 960437

Change-Id: If8562bd533226cf9aee1d3be522f799d233581a9
