revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-25 02:37:33.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes bug 949038

Make the api calls better fit the standard pattern where
read_deleted can be changed using context.read_deleted

I have retained the ability to pass read_deleted
explicitly. If that is not specified, it uses the value in
the context.

Note: read_deleted defaults to "no" in the context.

The two exceptions are:
 aggregate_host_get_all
 aggregate_get_all

In this case, it is better for read_deleted=yes to be the default
So in this case the context cannot be used, as that would default
to read_deleted=no. In this case you must explicity override
read_deleted, the context is totally ignored, as before.

Change-Id: Idb048a592d8c6b788651d131a3345e70989c0ec4
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes bug 949038

Make the api calls better fit the standard pattern where
read_deleted can be changed using context.read_deleted

I have retained the ability to pass read_deleted
explicitly. If that is not specified, it uses the value in
the context.

Note: read_deleted defaults to "no" in the context.

The two exceptions are:
 aggregate_host_get_all
 aggregate_get_all

In this case, it is better for read_deleted=yes to be the default
So in this case the context cannot be used, as that would default
to read_deleted=no. In this case you must explicity override
read_deleted, the context is totally ignored, as before.

Change-Id: Idb048a592d8c6b788651d131a3345e70989c0ec4

commit_message:
Delete all allocatable_ips on ip_block delete

* Calls the delete method on the ip generator to clear the block of any
  allocatable_ips so the FK doesn't fail the constraint on block delete
* Fixes LP963396

Change-Id: Iaa1915e79adde23970ad7405477e8d82467a8a58

subject: Support sql_connection_debug to get SQL diagnostic information
messages:
[{'account_id': 2634, 'date': '2012-03-25 16:09:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-25 21:56:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

This needs to go into master before milestone-proposed'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-25 21:59:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Ah - I guessed the procedure and looks like I guessed wrong.

Is the procedure written up anywhere?

I guess it is:

1) Submit patch to master (i.e. normal git review)
2) Wait for it to be approved
3) Then "git cherry-pick <SHA>" from master to a new branch from milestone-proposed, and "git review milestone-proposed" that?'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-25 22:03:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Also, please declare the option in nova/db/sqlalchemy/session.py e.g.

  FLAGS = flags.FLAGS
  sqlalchemy_opts = [
      cfg.IntOpt('sql_connection_debug',
                 ...),
  ]

It might be no harm to move the sql_idle_timeout flag there too

Finally, I don't much like this being an integer flag with an arbitrary 0-100 range of values

Why not do this?

  sqlalchemy_opts = [
      cfg.BoolOpt('sql_connection_verbose'),
      cfg.BoolOpt('sql_connection_debug'),

  ]

and then

   echo = False
   if FLAGS.sql_connection_debug:
       echo = 'debug'
   elif FLAGS.sql_connection_verbose:
       echo = True"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-25 22:06:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think the procedure is to file a bug, tag it with essex-rc-potential and submit the fix against master. If it gets merged and the PTL feels it is indeed suitable for essex, it will get cherry-picked.'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-25 22:32:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

>Also, please declare the option in nova/db/sqlalchemy/session.py e.g.
>  FLAGS = flags.FLAGS
>  sqlalchemy_opts = [
>      cfg.IntOpt('sql_connection_debug',
>                 ...),
>  ]

I though it made more sense to put it right by the sql_connection flag.  Is there a guide to FLAG placement?  I think putting it by a flag when they should always be used together makes more sense to me ("co-used flags should be co-located").  I know we should add logging to other uses of sql connection, but I'm trying to keep this minimal for Essex.
 
> It might be no harm to move the sql_idle_timeout flag there too

This is (hopefully) going in to Essex, so I'd like to keep it very minimal.

>Finally, I don't much like this being an integer flag with an arbitrary 0-100 range of values
>Why not do this?
>  sqlalchemy_opts = [
>      cfg.BoolOpt('sql_connection_verbose'),
>      cfg.BoolOpt('sql_connection_debug'),
>  ]
>and then
>   echo = False
>   if FLAGS.sql_connection_debug:
>       echo = 'debug'
>   elif FLAGS.sql_connection_verbose:
>       echo = True

My thought process was:

1) It is a level, rather than independent booleans.  (Verbose is ignored if Debug=True in your example)
2) Using 0,1 or 2 would tie it to SQLAlchemy's implementation.  For example, level 100 is a bit too much information - it prints all the returned rows, whereas I can definitely imagine a "1.5" where we want the statement execution time but not the rows.  So I chose 0-100, where 100 is 'print all the things', and 0 is nothing.  That's not going to happen in Essex though.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-03-26 11:56:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

Mark summed up the process well. Abandoning this one.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-03-26 11:57:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Please link to bug and propose to master first.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-25 15:27:43.000000000', 'message': "Support sql_connection_debug to get SQL diagnostic information

We've had a few reports of SQL issues; it'll be very helpful to be able to get SQL information
into our log.

Change-Id: I667de1452e4077bf70dc33cf3ae3a8cc3c5aff5a
"}]
commit_message:
Support sql_connection_debug to get SQL diagnostic information

We've had a few reports of SQL issues; it'll be very helpful to be able to get SQL information
into our log.

Change-Id: I667de1452e4077bf70dc33cf3ae3a8cc3c5aff5a

commit_message:
Reordered the alphabet.

Just putting this out there... I'm pretty sure that

   import nova.flags

comes after

   from nova.endpoint import cloud

Unless I'm totally misunderstanding how this is supposed to work,
which is likely.

Change-Id: I51096ab25dbca42d73a593872b83b25f2c451210

commit_message:
Fix libvirt global name 'xml_info' is not defined.

Remove a line setting a stale xml_info variable.

This caused failures when performing a rebuild w/ libvirt.

Fixes LP Bug #964843.

Change-Id: If8cbdb3198742d488325153c50d90a2ece67a3af

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-21 14:23:10.000000000', 'message': 'Introduce a set of classes for storing libvirt guest configuration

With the current Cheetah template based approach to XML
generation, there is never any canonical representation
of the guest configuration. When generating XML, a hash
is filled in with parameters to be used to generate XML,
an even some pre-built XML snippets. When reading XML,
typically XPath is used, but sometimes manual DOM traversal
is used.

This change introduces a set of classes for explicitly
representing the guest configuration. They are intended
to allow the guest config to be read/written using normal
programatic APIs, avoiding the need for any code to know
about XML.

This first impl though, only supports writing of XML.
The code to parse an existing XML doc is not yet written.
The class hierarchy is as follows

  LibvirtConfigObject
   |
   + LibvirtConfigGuest
   + LibvirtConfigGuestDevice
      |
      +- LibvirtConfigGuestDisk
      +- LibvirtConfigGuestFilesys
      +- LibvirtConfigGuestInterface
      +- LibvirtConfigGuestInput
      +- LibvirtConfigGuestGraphics
      +- LibvirtConfigGuestChar
          |
          +- LibvirtConfigGuestSerial
          +- LibvirtConfigGuestConsole

The base LibvirtConfigObject class provides some generic
boilerplate code. Subclasses need to override the "format_dom"
method for generating XML DOMS, and "parse_dom" for reading XML
DOMs. The conversion from DOM <-> XML String is handled by
the base class. The DOMs are based on the lxml.etree.Element
class.

Change-Id: I0474b6640b47ad0e5bb74503a5ff99a8a41bcdc4
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Introduce a set of classes for storing libvirt guest configuration

With the current Cheetah template based approach to XML
generation, there is never any canonical representation
of the guest configuration. When generating XML, a hash
is filled in with parameters to be used to generate XML,
an even some pre-built XML snippets. When reading XML,
typically XPath is used, but sometimes manual DOM traversal
is used.

This change introduces a set of classes for explicitly
representing the guest configuration. They are intended
to allow the guest config to be read/written using normal
programatic APIs, avoiding the need for any code to know
about XML.

This first impl though, only supports writing of XML.
The code to parse an existing XML doc is not yet written.
The class hierarchy is as follows

  LibvirtConfigObject
   |
   + LibvirtConfigGuest
   + LibvirtConfigGuestDevice
      |
      +- LibvirtConfigGuestDisk
      +- LibvirtConfigGuestFilesys
      +- LibvirtConfigGuestInterface
      +- LibvirtConfigGuestInput
      +- LibvirtConfigGuestGraphics
      +- LibvirtConfigGuestChar
          |
          +- LibvirtConfigGuestSerial
          +- LibvirtConfigGuestConsole

The base LibvirtConfigObject class provides some generic
boilerplate code. Subclasses need to override the "format_dom"
method for generating XML DOMS, and "parse_dom" for reading XML
DOMs. The conversion from DOM <-> XML String is handled by
the base class. The DOMs are based on the lxml.etree.Element
class.

 * nova/tests/test_libvirt_config.py: Test cases for XML formatting
   of all config object classes
 * nova/virt/libvirt/config.py: Config object classes for libvirt
   guest XML schema

blueprint libvirt-xml-config-apis
Change-Id: I0474b6640b47ad0e5bb74503a5ff99a8a41bcdc4
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

each ajax complete instead of removing it on valid row update

commit_message:
".modal" style only applied to modals now.

The ".static_page" style now handles all static styling and
looks more "static" than it did before.

Removed a couple dead and/or extraneous templates.

Updated translation files.

Fixed bug 963482.

Change-Id: I8b6af12f0752e844192db3fc6caa1fc389b0cddc

messages:
[{'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-22 10:35:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

isn't this redundant? what else can you execute this with?"}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-03-22 10:36:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

bash:

$ ./setup.py 
./setup.py: line 23: from: command not found
./setup.py: line 24: from: command not found
./setup.py: line 27: syntax error near unexpected token `('
./setup.py: line 27: `ROOT = os.path.dirname(__file__)'"}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-22 10:38:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

python ./setup.py'}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-22 10:39:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

but i agree it's better if this script shebang is available, but most setup.py i've encounter don't have it, maybe there's a reason for that, maybe someone else can tell us"}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-03-22 10:39:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Sure, but putting that line in the script means you don't have to repeat it every time you run the script, so you just do:

./setup.py"}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-03-22 10:41:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Urgh, my previous comment was in answer to Comment #3.

Maybe the setup.py's you've found were on windows?"}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-22 10:44:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

a lot of pip stuff are without it, maybe they didn't expect manual execution"}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-03-22 13:41:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This patch is cool, but it'd be better to have it on all Openstack projects. Currently only glance and swift have this line in setup.py, and the others - do not have it. We should strive for more consistency in the project code."}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2012-03-22 17:06:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I thought the standard was to do 'python setup.py install' - it's been this way for every python project i've encountered, I'll change my vote after we get feedback from the nebula guys."}, {'account_id': 2458, 'date': '2012-03-23 19:03:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I would say this is a fine change, I have seen plenty of scripts like this have this header to tell the shell what to use to execute it with. This doesn't prevent one from still using "python x.py" it just provides a shortcut for those that don't want to type "python"...'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-03-25 06:23:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I don't feel strongly about it. Basically any instructions you see will say to type python setup.py install, but that's functionally equivalent to the hashbang with user/bin/env python at the top of the file. It's not gonna harm anything."}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2012-03-25 19:18:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

subject: Make a general filter
messages:
[{'account_id': 2230, 'date': '2012-03-23 22:55:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I think the intended goal here was to use some more comprehensive server-side filtering to allow searches. The javascript filtering won't scale particularly well, and doesn't allow you to filter more than a page worth of items. The right approach to this might be to integrate one of the python-search backends, probably natively as part of whichever backend is providing the objects to be filtered. Then this can be used in the client by horizon.

So I don't think this is the right approach for FilterAction, sorry."}, {'account_id': 1943, 'date': '2012-03-25 14:29:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

The wrong implement.'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-21 19:55:42.000000000', 'message': "Removed max_length from username/password fields in login page

Fixes bug 959179

The field validation on the login page may lead
to security issues - it should accept any input,
without validation. Not to tell hackers what range to probe..
The validation should be only on create/update User page.

Added the password validation message as a hint
in create/update form.

Note: I didn't make the user name configurable for length,
as mentioned in the bug. Isn't it better to leave that
thing to the auth backend(i.e. Keystone), to raise
validation exceptions? Otherwise it might come to
the situation where Dashboard is more or less restrictive
than the backend?

Change-Id: Ib3bc72a024fe3e39e06bf948c6aaca8f2b1e60ee
"}, {'created': '2012-03-21 21:24:20.000000000', 'message': "Removed max_length from username/password fields in login page

Fixes bug 959179

The field validation on the login page may lead
to security issues - it should accept any input,
without validation. Not to tell hackers what range to probe..
The validation should be only on create/update User page.

Note: I didn't make the user name configurable for length,
as mentioned in the bug. Isn't it better to leave that
thing to the auth backend(i.e. Keystone), to raise
validation exceptions? Otherwise it might come to
the situation where Dashboard is more or less restrictive
than the backend?

Patch 2: reverted the default regex, removed the hint
for password field, as it depends on the regex,
and might lead to i18n problems during customization..

Change-Id: Ib3bc72a024fe3e39e06bf948c6aaca8f2b1e60ee
"}, {'created': '2012-03-23 23:27:59.000000000', 'message': "Removed max_length from username/password fields in login page

commit_message:
Removed max_length from username/password fields in login page

Fixes bug 959179

The field validation on the login page may lead
to security issues - it should accept any input,
without validation. Not to tell hackers what range to probe..
The validation should be only on create/update User page.

Updates the translation files for the new strings.

Change-Id: Ib3bc72a024fe3e39e06bf948c6aaca8f2b1e60ee

subject: Proxy NovaTestRunner to MultiProcessTestRunner
messages:
[{'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-03-09 15:32:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I love this, but I'm not sure of the legality of distributing the multiprocess.py module from nose, its LGPL and we're apache. I think at the very least there should be a header on it describing where it came from and that it is licensed separately from the rest of nova.

I'm having issues with TimeOuts on some of the modules in this checkout. I'm wondering if it should be configurable, or something really high like 60s. Also it looks like tests run through multiprocessing are not getting decorated with the openstack style output.

On a not-completely unrelated side-note, Monty has been working on getting the tests to run under nosetests directly so we can remove the runner.py stuff and just use the nose plugins for stuff. I'm not saying one way or the other, but it might be better to focus on fixing the few tests that still block under nosetests and then just use the multiprocessing plugin in setup.cfg."}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2012-03-10 11:52:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2012-03-10 12:08:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The original multiprocess code shipped with nose 1.1.2
does not work.
And the one in nose development branch does not seem
to be working and have significant changes.
So I fixed two bugs base on the multiprocess code of
nose 1.1.2 and borrowed in.
Hopefully people interested could have a better base to work
with.

Here are the changes I have done:
http://paste.openstack.org/show/8101/
http://paste.openstack.org/show/8102/
http://paste.openstack.org/show/8103/

Here is the list of problems I know about:
http://paste.openstack.org/show/8116/

Don't know the timeout you mentioned is the one in 8116
or not.

With current implementation of multiprocess,
the raw result decoration is much easier to deal with.

Anyway, it could be changed in the future.

I hope the work on the test cases not compatible with
multiprocess could be divide and conquered."}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-03-10 17:46:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Well smokestacked passed without issues so that's good! ;) I'll dig into what's different with my checkout."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-03-13 18:08:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'm also concerned with the legality of just pulling in the file, but I'm also not a lawyer. On technical merit, the patch seems fine. I'll let someone more knowledgeable decide."}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2012-03-17 06:54:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-17 17:18:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

Hi Hu, would you mind documenting in the copied plugin where the bug is that you fixed in relation to upstream as well as a link the upstream bug (so we can track and eventually deprecate when upstream is fixed and the plugin is available in all target distros)?

Thanks!
-jay"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-25 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-25 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]

commit_message:
Adds support for tabs + tables.

Creates new TableTab and TabbedTableView classes to support
the complex logic involved in processing both table and tab
actions in a single view.

Fixes bug 964214.

Change-Id: I3f70d77975593773bf783d31de06d2b724aad2d5

commit_message:
Use ugettext_lazy for verbose_texts instead of unicode.

 * Fix bug 962417
 * Change the ugettext to ugettext_lazy
 * Unicode the verbose_name while the 
   DataTableOption is initialize will 
   make the translation fixed.
 * Similar scenario in Column class and Action class.

Change-Id: I69ce9f89b0f0c2afb32b26e15ea8db84828d840f

commit_message:
Add periodic_fuzzy_delay option.

Fixes bug 962665

This random delay is intended to reduce the stampeding behavior
associated with periodic tasks when compute workers are restarted in
unison across a cluster.

Change-Id: Ie3771d94af29049061c129b8ea562ee447a61771

commit_message:
Convert libvirt connection class to use config APIs for CPU comparisons

Currently the libvirt connection class uses a Cheetah template to
build up the CPU XML document, for doing host CPU comparisons.
Remove this template and replace it with use of the new config
API LibvirtConfigCPU

The nova 'cpu_xml_template' configuration parameter is also removed since
it is now obsolete

blueprint libvirt-xml-config-apis
Change-Id: I1d608f5f9d77302a9e08486f67ad3a39b224e9d5
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Install quantumclient from git before quantum.

There is an issue with installing git dependency_links via
setuptools develop command. We're working on it generally,
but for now this will make quantum happier with devstack.

Change-Id: I8df88f4bca9f2b43b1d56fc7e77e26793b4c4b9f

commit_message:
Convert libvirt connection class to use config APIs for guests

Remove the entire Cheetah XML template for libvirt guests
and make the libvirt connection class use LibvirtConfingGuest
classes instead

The nova 'libvirt_xml_template' config parameter is now obsolete
and removed.

blueprint libvirt-xml-config-apis
Change-Id: I5ff4ed7cbc69c8c141db840f4d6fc368a13f7f7a
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Move NIC devices back after disk devices

Originally the NIC devices were listed in the XML after the
disk devices. Restore that order, simply for consistency.
No functional change.

blueprint libvirt-xml-config-apis
Change-Id: If62446292850d58e133b0c4cc42ca83018e1fca1
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Convert libvirt connection class to use config APIs for disk devices

Remove all the <disk> elements from the Cheetah XML template
and make the libvirt connection class use the LibvirtConfigGuestDisk
class for them instead

blueprint libvirt-xml-config-apis
Change-Id: I0f09a86e72e5e34bbd780b31177a65eb40fb5419
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

subject: Convert libvirt connection class to use config APIs for filesystem devices
messages:
[{'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-03-21 16:17:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-22 20:22:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

As I progress through reviewing all of these different merges, it's starting to get more difficult to keep straight which patch does what where and why.  Is there a reason they were submitted as separate patches?"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-03-23 11:52:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Changing the XML generation is a change of complexity such that there is non-trivial scope for causing regressions. If this was all one big patch it would be significantly more difficult to compare the before & after code to ensure it operates in the same way. Splitting up the conversion into small, self-contained steps allows you to clearly verify correctness of each individual step. It also allows you to effectively run 'git bisect' should problems be detected later. As a matter of general coding practice, all non-trivial patches should be split up into series where ever they contain changes that can be considered independent.

Gerrit's poor design means you can't take full advantage of the use of patch series when reviewing online, but it is unquestionably better for reviewing the GIT history directly."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-03-23 14:37:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-23 15:36:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Heh.  I don't disagree with you; I have a preference for microcommits in my own code, and this is one of the things I have against Gerrit."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-23 15:36:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-23 15:52:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-23 17:06:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

"}]
commit_message:
Delete all allocatable_ips on ip_block delete

* Calls the delete method on the ip generator to clear the block of any
  allocatable_ips so the FK doesn't fail the constraint on block delete
* Fixes LP963396

Change-Id: Iaa1915e79adde23970ad7405477e8d82467a8a58

commit_message:
Convert libvirt vif classes over to use config API

The classes in the libvirt/vif.py file build up dictionaries
and partial XML snippets, which are then passed onto Cheetah
templating for XML generation. Instead of building up
dictionaries of parameters, return LibvirtConfigGuestInterface
object instances instead

blueprint libvirt-xml-config-apis
Change-Id: I4e977225e21219f408dd729ac280dcbfc6b8ba8f
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Convert libvirt volume classes over to use config API

The classes in the libvirt/volume.py file build up XML
strings using printf style substitutions. Convert this
over to use the LibvirtConfigGuestDisk config class
instead

blueprint libvirt-xml-config-apis
Change-Id: Ied1fad47db6fb23b74edc4405015768c764a4d10
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fixing an issue where a unique id was not being returned for the overview table, causing the same information to be rendered for instances with the same name but differing stats. Fixes bug #959489

Change-Id: I78050462903e1b971d0a219805d19c5f728e23f7

commit_message:
Remove usage of glance auth-context filter.

This glance commit breaks devstack:

  https://github.com/openstack/glance/commit/5bd453b1

causing the glance services to fail to launch with the old
devstack pre-canned glance *-paste.ini files.

Change-Id: I57ea773d410b60bd5147b64689bd39a6fe75e69e

messages:
[{'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-03-21 12:03:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-03-21 13:13:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

nit about _(...) inline'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-03-21 13:27:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-03-21 13:49:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-21 14:32:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Holy linked patch series, Batman :)

Will take some time to get through all these!

For the libvirt guestfile object series, do you have a blueprint or bug you've been working from, Daniel?

Thanks!

-jay"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-03-21 14:55:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

NB, this patch is separate the large XML config series - I just happened to rebase my XML series on top of this one'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-22 07:31:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Looks good, but I think we should add a variant of _check_xml_and_disk_driver() to test for cache=writethrough and also make sure the tests pass even if you're running the tests on a filesystem which doesn't support O_DIRECT

You can stubout os.open and control how it handles O_DIRECT:

  import errno
  import os
  import stubout

  os_open = os.open
  directio_supported = True

  def os_open_stub(path, flags, *args, **kwargs):
      if flags & os.O_DIRECT:
          if not directio_supported:
              raise OSError(errno.EINVAL,
                           '%s: %s' % (os.strerror(errno.EINVAL), path))
          flags &= ~os.O_DIRECT
      return os_open(path, flags, *args, **kwargs)

  stubs = stubout.StubOutForTesting()
  stubs.Set(os, 'open', os_open_stub)

  def test(flags):
      f = os.open('/proc/uptime', flags)
      print os.read(f, 100)
      os.close(f)

  test(os.O_RDONLY)
  test(os.O_RDONLY|os.O_DIRECT)

  stubs.UnsetAll()

  test(os.O_RDONLY)
  test(os.O_RDONLY|os.O_DIRECT)"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-03-23 11:06:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-23 11:34:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Coolness'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-23 15:18:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-03-23 15:29:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-23 15:41:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Do not submit

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-03-23 16:43:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-03-23 16:44:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-23 16:50:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Moving the check out of the constructor and making the error handling more specific both seem like sane improvements to me.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-23 16:52:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

It looks like the code handles the two expected scenarios correctly, success and errno == EINVAL.

Any other scenario *should* raise an exception, right?

I'm trying to understand what exception was being thrown in __init__ that shouldn't be."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-03-23 18:41:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Consider the case where 'instance_paths' points to a directory which is correct, but not yet mounted at the time the Nova compute service is started. If we raise an exception in the constructor, the compute service will abort at startup with a critical error. This is bad, because starting the service should be robust against the path not yet existing, otherwise you could well race during OS startup. We should only mandate existance of the instances_path directory when we actually need to start creating storage volumes, or starting guests."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-23 18:56:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Makes sense. Thanks for the changes'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-23 19:08:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/2924/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/1998/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1654/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3379/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-23 19:08:56.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-21 11:39:37.000000000', 'message': "Fix launching of guests where instances_path is on GlusterFS

The FUSE module does not (currentl) support O_DIRECT on files.
This prevents QEMU from starting guests using 'cache=none' for
their disks located on a GlusterFS filesystem. The same also
applies for a handful of other filesystems (notably tmpfs, or
any other FUSE filesystem).

This patch introduces a startup check in Nova compute service
which tries to create a file $instances_path/.direct_io.test
using the O_DIRECT flag. If this succeeds, then cache=none
will be used for all disks, otherwise it will fallback to
using cache=writethrough. While the latter does not have
performance which is as consistent as cache=none, it is still
host-crash safe and preserves data integrity with migration,
if the filesystem is cache coherant (cluster filesystems like
GlusterFS are, NFS by constrast is not).

By doing the dynamic check for O_DIRECT, we ensure that if
future FUSE modules gain O_DIRECT support, Nova will automatically
do the right thing.

Bug: 959637
Change-Id: I60cbff1c3ad8299fe2aa37099390f9235f6724d0
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix launching of guests where instances_path is on GlusterFS

The FUSE module does not (currentl) support O_DIRECT on files.
This prevents QEMU from starting guests using 'cache=none' for
their disks located on a GlusterFS filesystem. The same also
applies for a handful of other filesystems (notably tmpfs, or
any other FUSE filesystem).

This patch introduces a startup check in Nova compute service
which tries to create a file $instances_path/.direct_io.test
using the O_DIRECT flag. If this succeeds, then cache=none
will be used for all disks, otherwise it will fallback to
using cache=writethrough. While the latter does not have
performance which is as consistent as cache=none, it is still
host-crash safe and preserves data integrity with migration,
if the filesystem is cache coherant (cluster filesystems like
GlusterFS are, NFS by constrast is not).

By doing the dynamic check for O_DIRECT, we ensure that if
future FUSE modules gain O_DIRECT support, Nova will automatically
do the right thing.

* nova/tests/test_libvirt.py: Stub out os.open in
  the _check_xml_and_disk_driver() to enable testing of
  both O_DIRECT and non-O_DIRECT code paths
* nova/tests/test_virt_drivers.py: Set instances_path to
  the current directory
* nova/virt/libvirt.xml.template: Replace hardcoded 'none'
  string with the '$cachemode' variable for all disks.
  Add missing 'cache' attribute for the config disk
* nova/virt/libvirt/connection.py: Check whether O_DIRECT
  is supported on the "FLAGS.instances_path" directory
  and use 'none' for cachemode if it is, 'writethrough'
  otherwise

Bug: 959637
Change-Id: I60cbff1c3ad8299fe2aa37099390f9235f6724d0
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

only substantial migration). This commit keeps from setting up the DB before

commit_message:
Fixing initial migration

The last commit broke the initial migration(which is worse, because it was the
only substantial migration). This commit keeps from setting up the DB before
running migrations. If any future migrations need to read from the DB they
will need to do the same dance that's in 002.

Change-Id: Icedf99d95b538cb24cccccc4d47ef68bdf225b4c

 * Fixes bug 949444

commit_message:
Use key in locals() that actually exists

Fixes bug 963263

Also, fix whitespace so we don't end up with two almost identical
strings to internationalize

S3 tokens cleanups.

- Cleanups.
- Remove reference about config admin_username/password/token.
- Return proper http error on errors.
- Add unittests (skip them for now when swift is not installed).
- Fixes bug 956983.

commit_message:
Set content_type for messages in Qpid notifier.

Fix bug 963050.

This patch is the Qpid equivalent for a patch that just went in for the
rabbit/kombu notifier.  Glance encodes the message in json format before
passing it in to the notifier.  Explicitly set the content type for the
messages to 'application/json'.

Change-Id: I2f83f51487541b951f3eca0ae4d160a64f5a3db1

subject: Config file compatability changes.
messages:
[{'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-03-23 13:43:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

As far as I understand there is no requirement in Tempest that you have to use 'nonadmin' users.

It may be a good idea to do that... but naming the config file entries as such seems to step a bit over the line in my opinion."}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2012-03-23 15:40:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Actually there is Dan. Specifically with authorization tests, the expected result is that the request will succeed. However, for normal users (which this test is checking), these actions should never be allowed. I believe someone else also added some flavor manipulation tests, which I believe are admin only actions.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-03-23 16:12:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

One complaint here is the Tempest config file changes on a weekly basis. The changes aren't that hard to follow (and I'm happy to make these updates)... but this one doesn't make sense to me. At some point it would be nice to have backwards compatability be a priority. If we add new features... Great! But don't break my scripts that run Tempest.

As a baseline it would like to see the following in the config file:

user=XXXX
password=XXXX
tenant_name=XXXX

If we need extra configuration parameters for explicit Admin and/or non-admin users then so be it... but to me those should be extra and hopefully optional. The majority of the OSAPI tests can be made with either an Admin or non-admin user account so the test suite shouldn't force you one way or the other. In this regard I see the test suite as a tool which I can choose to use with either an admin account or a non-admin account."}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2012-03-23 16:22:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I understand your frustration with the config changes Dan. I'm always hesitant to make anything that could be a "breaking" change. However, to get things to a point of comfort from a stability standpoint for the community, some modifications have to happen. I could drop all the changes I'd like to make into a single submission, but my feeling is that it would be even more painful to other users. Instead I've opted for small incremental changes that move this code closer and closer the desired state, which gives everyone a chance to bring up feedback how things develop. My hope is that after the Design Conference, we'll have enough feedback to begin to lock down modifications on certain parts of the code, including configuration.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-23 16:22:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hey guys, I think you're both right in different ways. Why don't we have a chat about this on IRC.

I think using new sections of the config file we can get to a place where we have some backwards compatibility as well as the needs Daryl mentions..."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-03-23 17:04:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-23 13:37:50.000000000', 'message': "Config file compatability changes.

Reverts some recently changed config file settings for compatability.

 *Rename nonadmin_user1 settings => user/password/tenant
 *Rename nonadmin_user2 settings => alt_user/alt_password/etc.

We seem to already make use of 'alt' for some of the other settings
in the config file (images and flavors for example) so we might
as well follow this naming scheme for users as well.

Change-Id: I043bdbe81e235dea271589f4cb04b0a3bf991ec3
"}]
commit_message:
Config file compatability changes.

Reverts some recently changed config file settings for compatability.

 *Rename nonadmin_user1 settings => user/password/tenant
 *Rename nonadmin_user2 settings => alt_user/alt_password/etc.

We seem to already make use of 'alt' for some of the other settings
in the config file (images and flavors for example) so we might
as well follow this naming scheme for users as well.

Change-Id: I043bdbe81e235dea271589f4cb04b0a3bf991ec3

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-16 13:52:23.000000000', 'message': 'Tweak security port validation for ICMP

Horizon allows for ICMP to be type:code.
Type and code can be from -1 to 255.

API refers to both EC2 and Nova APIs

This patch attempts to resolve:
1. API code throws exceptations when 0 is passed for either field
2. API code validates type:code like from->to range.  type and code
   are independent
3. Update unit tests for this new set of operations.

A side effect is that the following are allowed type:code.
-1:X
X:-1

The code assumes that -1 is a wildcard for the field.

bug 956967

Change-Id: Ieb6989815afc6986b72e0efc7611c2cc353ab5d8
'}]
commit_message:
Tweak security port validation for ICMP

Horizon allows for ICMP to be type:code.
Type and code can be from -1 to 255.

API refers to both EC2 and Nova APIs

This patch attempts to resolve:
1. API code throws exceptations when 0 is passed for either field
2. API code validates type:code like from->to range.  type and code
   are independent
3. Update unit tests for this new set of operations.

A side effect is that the following are allowed type:code.
-1:X
X:-1

The code assumes that -1 is a wildcard for the field.

bug 956967

Change-Id: Ieb6989815afc6986b72e0efc7611c2cc353ab5d8

subject: WIP - Allow SPICE protocol to be used instead of VNC
messages:
[{'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-14 04:33:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2012-03-14 04:35:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

let's hold off on this until folsom opens?"}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-14 04:36:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Obviously we probably don't want to merge this at this stage, but...

1) The flag names are very tied to VNC.  Do we want to rename these for Essex to be less protocol specific?  Were they in Diablo?

2) There was a question on the mailing list as to whether SPICE works.  It certainly seems to work!"}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2012-03-14 04:42:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

sounds good - perhaps change the first line to "WIP - Allow ..."

while working on it?'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-14 04:44:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-14 04:45:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Changed the title to WIP (although it does actually work well enough for evaluating SPICE).

I do think we should consider changing any flag names that weren't in Diablo.  I didn't find any here:
http://docs.openstack.org/diablo/openstack-compute/admin/content/reference-for-flags-in-nova-conf.html

But maybe that isn't the right source?"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-03-14 09:04:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(6 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-14 17:05:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

is there a reason we can't modify the existing vncproxy to use spice? It has its own token based security."}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-14 17:12:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I think for Essex we should focus on whether we want to rename any of the flags - as Daniel pointed out above it gets super-awkward.

But...

I believe the VNC proxy we have is protocol aware, and the SPICE and VNC protocols aren't the same.  For a SPICE proxy, I think we want to intercept the first packet where it sends the password, and use that to map to a backend, resending the password and then switching to simple relaying.  I believe that's possible based on my reading of the SPICE protocol.

My intention here was to evaluate whether SPICE lives up to the hype though, before we get into building proxies etc.  With this patch, SPICE gets exposed and you can connect to it if you have access to the 'host machine' network.  That should be just enough for evaluation purposes!"}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-03-14 17:12:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

The vnc proxies are actually protocol specific (though they talk to a shared auth component).  There is one for websockets (novnc) and a separate on for "xvp."  It would probably be easy to add an additional proxy for spice though.  Not sure if we would have to tweak a spice client for protocol compatibility.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-03-14 17:14:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I imagine adapting the noVNC proxy itself to also work with SPICE shouldn't be too hard since, IIUC, the proxy itself doesn't need to actually understand the VNC/SPICE protocol at all.

The hard bit would the client - writing a pure HTML5 based SPICE client, as an alternative to the HTML5 noVNC client, would be an enormous amount of work. Adapting the existing SPICE-GTK C client library to cope with SPICE-over-WebSockets is likely a bit more viable."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-03-14 17:20:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@sleepsonthefloor  if we did need to enhance the SPICE protocol to allow auto-switching between different VMs through a proxy, it'd be worth while taking OpenStacks' requirements directly to the upstream SPICE community. We don't want the SPICE protocol impls to become wildly fragmented as has happened with VNC where everyone just does their own thing."}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-14 18:01:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@DanielBerrange: I think we might be able to get away with not changing the protocol.  I think maybe this is an appropriate discussion topic for the design summit!'}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2012-03-14 18:08:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

justinsb, do you know if anyone has implemented something like noVNC?'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-14 18:13:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I'm very new to SPICE, so I think the RedHat guys should know better than me (I just thought it looked like something we should check out, and then I noticed that we might want to change the keynames)!

If you mean the JavaScript client aspect, not that I could find.  I think it would be more interesting to tweak the SPICE C client to run under NativeClient.

If you mean the gateway aspect, I think there are some commercial solutions out there, but I couldn't find an open source one."}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2012-03-14 18:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

agree with native client :)'}, {'account_id': 2812, 'date': '2012-03-15 16:13:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I have tried the method as in https://review.openstack.org/5319 , 
but it called the same error as before.
(nova.rpc): TRACE:     domain.createWithFlags(launch_flags)
(nova.rpc): TRACE:   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/libvirt.py",
line 372, in createWithFlags
(nova.rpc): TRACE:     if ret == -1: raise libvirtError
('virDomainCreateWithFlags() failed', dom=self)
(nova.rpc): TRACE: libvirtError: internal error Process exited while 
reading console log output: char device redirected to /dev/pts/12
(nova.rpc): TRACE: do_spice_init: starting 0.8.1
(nova.rpc): TRACE: do_spice_init: statistics shm_open failed, 
Permission denied
(nova.rpc): TRACE: 
(nova.rpc): TRACE:

 The version of my openstack is Diablo'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-15 18:09:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-15 18:10:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@wangsuyi640 Looks like there might be permissions issues - we'll have to keep an eye out for them as this patch develops - thanks!"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-23 06:03:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-23 06:03:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]

We will need a front-end proxy for production use; right now this is horribly insecure.

Change-Id: I9b35be84da08b2dcf1dcf692ca6e02c6ba806f86
'}]
commit_message:
WIP - Allow SPICE protocol to be used instead of VNC

SPICE is supposed to be a lot better than VNC.  Add just enough support to allow us to evaluate it.
We will need a front-end proxy for production use; right now this is horribly insecure.

Change-Id: I9b35be84da08b2dcf1dcf692ca6e02c6ba806f86

[{'created': '2012-03-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'message': "A quantum plugin to handle layer 2 and layer 3.

We are using quantum to handle our network and ports and we wrote this
plugin to be able to control our switches and firewalls and dhcps via
quantum.

Agents are running on dhcps and firewalls to execute the proper work
dictated by quantum via amqp.

Workers are made to execute commands on the local server based on the
current driver.

We've added a hook for Xenserver's vif activation and deactivation
to activate/deactivate networks.

Change-Id: I88b009639b4126485a8e70029ce8c4245eb5d0f9
"}]
commit_message:
A quantum plugin to handle layer 2 and layer 3.

We are using quantum to handle our network and ports and we wrote this
plugin to be able to control our switches and firewalls and dhcps via
quantum.

Agents are running on dhcps and firewalls to execute the proper work
dictated by quantum via amqp.

Workers are made to execute commands on the local server based on the
current driver.

We've added a hook for Xenserver's vif activation and deactivation
to activate/deactivate networks.

Change-Id: I88b009639b4126485a8e70029ce8c4245eb5d0f9

subject: set denied resp on requests to '/' in tempauth
messages:
[{'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-19 22:33:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-03-20 10:19:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Any reasons for that? I am wondering if I should reproduce this behaviour for keystone middleware.'}, {'account_id': 995, 'date': '2012-03-20 18:59:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So the reason for it is:

I am working on adding some origin middleware that will need to be able to respond to requests to '/' for static web.  This middleware will be after the auth middleware in the pipeline so basically I need auth to allow requests to '/' to continue on down the pipe instead of returning a 404 immediately.  The proxy server will return a 404 if it gets that far so there should be no change in existing behavior."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-03-20 19:10:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

David, thanks for the explanation!'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-03-23 03:49:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Rework translation for panel and dashboard names. Marked more strings.

Uses ugettext_lazy to delay translation; reworks the __repr__
method to avoid using the translated form; and changes the
unicode method of the HorizonComponent class to actually return a
string coerced to unicode rather than a proxy object.

In the process, many more strings which had been missed have been
marked for translation.

Fixes bug 910297.

Change-Id: Ie8d10a928b0419313e6c54b0eff7a3a37299ca83

Hi Matt,

TestRabbitNotifier.test_warn is still failing with an incorrect number of paramaters.

Looking at the intent of the test and the stub-out for RabbitStrategy._send_message(), I think you need to specify the content_type *outside* of that method, otherwise the logic to set 'application/json' will be overridden when _send_message() is replaced in the unit test.

Something like http://paste.openstack.org/show/11911/ will do the job.

Also one question, is a similar change required for glance.notifier.notify_qpid.QpidStrategy?

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-03-22 15:10:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Yes, the same type of change is needed in the Qpid notifier, as well.  Here is what it should look like:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/11982/

My mox skills are failing me at the moment, so the unit test usage of mox.IgnoreArg() isn't ideal."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-03-22 15:11:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

TBH, I've had issues getting the tests to even run on two separate machines, so I've been eye balling what needs to happen :-/ I'll get it fixed shortly."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-03-22 15:23:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Fixes lp959670

Manually sets the content_type in the notification message body. This allows any
tools dependent on the content_type to function correctly.

Change-Id: I496c005b84df5f4aa2c18ab2b3a4ab136b840111

subject: Clean up volume api attribute formatting
messages:
[{'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-22 17:59:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2012-03-22 18:07:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Maybe it's just me, but supporting both _ and lower camel case seems horrible. This doesn't seem like a bug, but rather an alignment? Wouldn't it make more sense to leave this for Essex and just support lower camel case for Folsom? I see the opening of a new release line as the perfect time to make code 'right'.

Is this causing a problem right now, or could we compromise by saying this patch can go into Essex but then put a branch into Folsom which only supports lower camel case?"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-22 18:11:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I would also prefer only lowerCamelCase but there are two reasons why it is best to leave the compatibility in for now:

a) gating.  We at least temporarily need to support both syntaxes until the corresponding branch to novaclient lands

b) not breaking.  I don't know if this has happened, but if anyone has written to the existing code, it would be nice if we didn't break them.

The compatibility code can disappear in a subsequent patch, and we can only backport the first to essex.

-1 ing because the types resource needs to be updated as well."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-22 18:47:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Looks good to me…'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-03-22 21:41:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Taking the opposite approach. New branch coming.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-22 17:46:17.000000000', 'message': 'Clean up volume api attribute formatting

* Change volume/snapshot create to expect lower camel-case attributes
* Support old underscore formats for compatibility
* Fixes bug 943053

Change-Id: I9706c8a15ea4dc277734666fa49ebaa4e7bc9d1e
'}]
commit_message:
Clean up volume api attribute formatting

* Change volume/snapshot create to expect lower camel-case attributes
* Support old underscore formats for compatibility
* Fixes bug 943053

Change-Id: I9706c8a15ea4dc277734666fa49ebaa4e7bc9d1e

[{'created': '2012-03-16 02:58:39.000000000', 'message': "Re-instate security group delete test case

While fixing lp#956366, we realized that it's fine to delete a security
group referenced by an ingress rule of another security group because
the ingress rule gets deleted.

Re-instate the test for this specific case, but test that the ingress
rule gets deleted rather than an exception being thrown.

Change-Id: I81ad16431f5f8f13561dfcb320213366e1e8864e
"}]
commit_message:
Re-instate security group delete test case

While fixing lp#956366, we realized that it's fine to delete a security
group referenced by an ingress rule of another security group because
the ingress rule gets deleted.

Re-instate the test for this specific case, but test that the ingress
rule gets deleted rather than an exception being thrown.

Change-Id: I81ad16431f5f8f13561dfcb320213366e1e8864e

subject: Allow image name up to 255 characters
messages:
[{'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-03-22 14:20:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Do we need a max_length here? If there is no restriction - then the backend service will be responsible to validate the length, and to raise exceptions if needed.'}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-22 14:31:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

But isn't it better to intercept such error as early as possible, so that it shows clearer error message?"}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-03-22 15:25:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Having max_length=255 is close to not having a limit at all. It is quite oddly someone to use names 255+ characters long. But what if the backend supports max_length=60? Then this limitation is useless. And what if backend supports max_length=500? This validation will restrict the name without a reason... 
Maybe there could be a reason if longer names break the Dashboard design, and we want to limit it for UI's sake. But 255 doesn't seem to solve this problem."}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-22 15:27:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

truth to be told, i just follow the suggestion on the bug ticket, 255 is a reasonable limit, do you suggest we just remove the max_length altogether?'}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2012-03-22 16:58:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I think this is fine, it is significantly better than a limit of 25.'}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2012-03-22 19:43:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-22 20:05:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/2873/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-unittests/371/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-merge/367/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-pep8/526/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-22 20:05:26.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
Added a universal style-guide for all OS projects.

Pursuant to a recent mailing list discussion, this file contains
the union of all style recommendations from varions openstack
projects.  The file will be removed from individual projects.

Change-Id: I79c118ff749d7c89d7d88302279ec8cb1530868d

commit_message:
Fix AJAX form posting that work incorrectly if get() in base views
is overridden by subclass, e.g. EditRulesView and EditAttachmentsView
if they don't add X-Horizon-Location custom headers if redirect is
used. This mucking is probably the cleanest way to fix this in
the meantime.

 * fix bug 961863

Change-Id: I213e23a150b4afaba1249584e8cb3b376095533e

commit_message:
LaunchAction button enabled only if image
is in 'active' state

Fixes bug 959705. Affects snapshot images,
that can currently be launched when still in
queued status.

Change-Id: I07233242ac79fc05fafa792d28a2fb08f82b1d5c

I looked at using one ConfigParser per config file but it will only allow one use of the flag per config file. That's an improvement over the current code which is one use for all config files, but it still doesn't support my use case of multiple uses per config file.

I'm trying to figure out a way to continue using ConfigParser but without needing to dig into the internals but I can't figure out a way yet given the implementation of ConfigParser.

Are we attached to using ConfigParser?"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-22 18:53:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Because of the Python 2.7 issues for now"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-22 18:53:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-22 18:53:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I took an alternative approach and just wrote an INI parser. Turned out to be pretty simple and straight forward.

My first attempt at this ended up rewriting a bunch of cfg.py to clean things up. However, I decided to minimize the changes in this version since we're so late in the essex release cycle.

Future work could simplify and bring config file parsing closer to CLI parsing. Perhaps even convert config file options into a CLI style args list for optparse to deal with."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-22 18:53:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

Thnx'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-22 18:53:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

Thanks for taking this on Johannes!

I was about to approve this, but it looks like the tests fail on python 2.7 - a quick look at the ConfigParser diff between 2.6 and 2.7 and it looks like it's way the multi-line values are handled now is the issue

To me, that's just a sign that we shouldn't be hacking around the innards of ConfigParser like this

I was thinking of implementing this by using a ConfigParser for each config file and iterating over the parsers when the value is fetched? What do you think?"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-22 18:53:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(9 inline comments)

Ok, I'm not jumping for joy that we're bringing another .ini file parser into the world ... but this is very nice work!

I'll assume you looked at other options like iniparse and move swiftly along :)

Some fairly small comments inline. Only other comment I'd make is that the test coverage for iniparse is only 80%. It'd be nice to get that higher. See "tox -e cover"'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-03-22 18:53:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Finish implementing MultiStrOpt

Fixes bug 955308

Previously only multiple string options from the CLI were supported.
This change adds support for config files too and merges the results
from both CLI and config files.

Change-Id: I642408c03ed295fac050105fd4380940e876f228

commit_message:
Avoid leaking secrets into config logging.

Fixes bug 962385

Configuration option values are logged when debug is enabled,
which is in turn exposed via the glance-logcapture nose plugin
when tests fail in Jenkins.

Allow options to be declared secret so that their value is
obfuscated before logging.

Also proposed to openstack-common as:

  https://review.openstack.org/5694

Change-Id: Ifdd1696f40c069f83c160afb0bf399da21796b8a

commit_message:
Avoid leaking secrets into config logging.

Implements bp cfg-password-options

Allow options to be declared secret so that their value is
obfuscated before logging.

Change-Id: Ie2168d218b029d9c12fa5b48342cd5b17b2cc77a

subject: Capture SIGTERM and Shut down python services cleanly.
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-22 14:19:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not sure I understand why this is necessary? The problem doesn't appear to be stopping on SIGTERM, the default handler will take already stop the process."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-22 14:58:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Maybe it isn't *necessary*, but explicit is better than implicit, IMO.  And really, this would be the foundation of something that would perform a cleaner shutdown…"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-22 15:07:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

I think I can make the argument that designing for a clean shutdown is overly optimistic and ignores the real world where unclean shutdowns happen all too often. Do we just bury our heads and complain that the hardware didn't play along with our assumptions that all shutdowns are clean?

But I'll save the rest of that argument for the design summit since it's much bigger than this change."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-22 15:18:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/2851/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/1958/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1614/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3339/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-22 15:18:28.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-03-22 16:12:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi,  

I was going to suggest service mgmt as a design summit topic, so looks like a good discussion in the offering:

I was thinking that a good shutdown sequence would be something like:

- Update the timestamp (or a new status field) in the services table to show we're stopping
- Stop processing new messages from the queue
- Wait for the running eventlet count to reach 0
- If it doesn't reach 0 in XXX seconds, halt anyway"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-22 18:44:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

It would make a good discussion, but it probably should be discussed on the mail list rather than in a review; not all interested parties would see it here.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-22 14:10:38.000000000', 'message': 'Capture SIGTERM and Shut down python services cleanly.

This is the first step in clean shut downs. Does not yet support eventlet threads.

Change-Id: Ibcd26ed61cf56947a8bdbe291d87cb211fc1ccd8
'}]
commit_message:
Capture SIGTERM and Shut down python services cleanly.

This is the first step in clean shut downs. Does not yet support eventlet threads.

Change-Id: Ibcd26ed61cf56947a8bdbe291d87cb211fc1ccd8

[{'created': '2012-03-22 17:55:29.000000000', 'message': "Change mycloud.com to example.com (RFC2606).

From RFC2606:
   To reduce the likelihood of conflict and confusion, a few top level
   domain names are reserved for use in private testing, as examples in
   documentation, and the like.

Currently the documentation contains URLs that point to mycloud.com,
which is registered and not affiliated with OpenStack.  It's better
to use example.com which exists for this purpose.

Change-Id: I7ebd9b2c0d650f15e5924798cc54611d47961f8f
"}]
commit_message:
Change mycloud.com to example.com (RFC2606).

From RFC2606:
   To reduce the likelihood of conflict and confusion, a few top level
   domain names are reserved for use in private testing, as examples in
   documentation, and the like.

Currently the documentation contains URLs that point to mycloud.com,
which is registered and not affiliated with OpenStack.  It's better
to use example.com which exists for this purpose.

Change-Id: I7ebd9b2c0d650f15e5924798cc54611d47961f8f

This function provides a constant-time string comparison.  Its primary
use case is for authentication to avoid timing vulnerabilities.  Similar
functions currently exist in keystone, nova, and swift.  The three
diverged in slight ways immediately after going in.  This version comes
from keystone, which I consider the "best" version to promote to
openstack-common.

Change-Id: I39537a21be8a402e34e526466f6b90188344a35d
'}]
commit_message:
Add auth_str_equal() to common utils.

This function provides a constant-time string comparison.  Its primary
use case is for authentication to avoid timing vulnerabilities.  Similar
functions currently exist in keystone, nova, and swift.  The three
diverged in slight ways immediately after going in.  This version comes
from keystone, which I consider the "best" version to promote to
openstack-common.

Change-Id: I39537a21be8a402e34e526466f6b90188344a35d

[{'created': '2012-03-22 15:45:21.000000000', 'message': 'Handle correctly QuotaError in EC2 API

Without this patch, EC2 API returns UnknownError when quota is exceeded, see bug #853381

This patch fixes that by handling the exception. Now euca-run-instances returns useful information:

$ euca-run-instances --instance-count 10 --instance-type m1.8gb.2cpus.diskless ami-00000012
QuotaError: Quota exceeded: code=InstanceLimitExceeded

Change-Id: I1f7b381b34d2f538b7cc2d9582a40fd8bf88fbc3
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>
'}, {'created': '2012-03-22 16:49:15.000000000', 'message': 'Handle correctly QuotaError in EC2 API

Without this patch, EC2 API returns UnknownError when quota is exceeded, see bug #853381

This patch fixes that by handling the exception. Now euca-run-instances returns useful information:

$ euca-run-instances --instance-count 10 --instance-type m1.8gb.2cpus.diskless ami-00000012
QuotaError: Quota exceeded: code=InstanceLimitExceeded

Change-Id: I1f7b381b34d2f538b7cc2d9582a40fd8bf88fbc3
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>
'}]
commit_message:
Handle correctly QuotaError in EC2 API

Without this patch, EC2 API returns UnknownError when quota is exceeded, see bug #853381

This patch fixes that by handling the exception. Now euca-run-instances returns useful information:

$ euca-run-instances --instance-count 10 --instance-type m1.8gb.2cpus.diskless ami-00000012
QuotaError: Quota exceeded: code=InstanceLimitExceeded

Change-Id: I1f7b381b34d2f538b7cc2d9582a40fd8bf88fbc3
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
Avoid unplugging VBDs for rescue instances

Fixes bug 961524

Unplugging can only happen if the instance is running and that might
not be the case. So instead of unplugging the root disk VBD, just
ignore it when it comes to deleting VDIs.

Change-Id: Id6c01527befed7775fdd7a4d30d0d3bee1178c51

Answered the inline questions.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-03-21 12:25:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Approved

Thanks for the responses, sounds reasonable.

BTW one small note for the future ...

'I will submit another patch for this.'

... instead of putting minor changes like the above in a seperate review, you can just push an updated patch set for the current review. As long as the Change-Id stays the same, gerrit will treat the updated patch as a mod to the current review as opposed to kicking off a fresh one.

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-21 12:32:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-20 06:37:21.000000000', 'message': "Fixed db conn recovery issue. Fixes bug 954971.

This implementation wraps the db method calls and retries the method if an attempt failed due to db connectivity issues. Defines 2 new configuration parameters viz sql_max_retries and sql_retry_interval (values default to 10 and 1 respectively).
This implementation does not have any overhead in the normal case, as opposed to MySQLPingListener implementation, which does a 'select 1' query every time a connection is checkout from the pool.

Change-Id: I24240f22bca445b9ab76a1594631b5eaca393b4d
"}]
commit_message:
Fixed db conn recovery issue. Fixes bug 954971.

This implementation wraps the db method calls and retries the method if an attempt failed due to db connectivity issues. Defines 2 new configuration parameters viz sql_max_retries and sql_retry_interval (values default to 10 and 1 respectively).
This implementation does not have any overhead in the normal case, as opposed to MySQLPingListener implementation, which does a 'select 1' query every time a connection is checkout from the pool.

Change-Id: I24240f22bca445b9ab76a1594631b5eaca393b4d

commit_message:
Strip auth token from log output.

Fix bug 956777.

This patch updates _safe_log, which is used for rpc debug logs, to not
include auth tokens.

Change-Id: I36bb4233acd356f85b0e6006a6b812a67605b393

subject: fix container creation with nginx. adds content-length header to swift cli container create methods. fixes bug 951155
messages:
[{'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-03-09 22:17:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks good, but consider using headers.setdefault() instead.'}, {'account_id': 1603, 'date': '2012-03-11 00:56:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-03-14 15:06:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Minor quibble, but we like keep PEP8 as best we can:

bin/swift:506:7: E111 indentation is not a multiple of four

bin/swift:536:7: E111 indentation is not a multiple of four

swift/common/client.py:411:7: E111 indentation is not a multiple of four

swift/common/client.py:441:7: E111 indentation is not a multiple of four

Not going to reject the patch just because of that. We can fix is post merge if need be.

However, Content-Length is checked for in a case-sensitive way, which could cause problems. Perhaps the "easiest" solution to this is to do:

if not 'content-length' in (k.lower() for k in d):

Lame, but hey, it works.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-22 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

fix container creation with nginx.
adds content-length header to swift cli container create methods.
fixes bug 951155

Change-Id: I446b3d0cb64698499fea00f2e3a8f2dfc7704cfa

this might be too aggreesive?'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-03-06 03:09:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-03-06 03:11:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Updated as per Jesse's comments. Now a non-admin user can only update their email and password specifically."}, {'account_id': 543, 'date': '2012-03-06 03:14:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

update_user is an admin api call, so i don't know how a user would even get to it, and I think this patch should wait until at least after https://review.openstack.org/#change,4659"}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-03-06 22:56:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

In principle I agree with the reasoning on this being a call to an admin endpoint, but I would argue it was a mistake in the keystone API to have the "update" part of the user CRUD be an admin-only API call.

This was an attempt to rectify that in the Essex timeframe without changing the API. If that's not possible, so be it.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-03-07 14:30:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

commit_message:
Allows users to update their own information (password, email, etc)

NOTE: This is implemented within the confines of the current API
definition. Ideally a non-admin user would not make an API call
to the admin endpoint, but for now this is the only place the
user CRUD is connected. Correcting this would alter the API, which
is more of a Folsom cycle task.

Change-Id: I5b72b5f497fa1794615e9bb77c54b0635f9ce1f0

* Updates the dashboard screenshot to Essex dash
* Updates tutorial to use TryStack
* Adds docbook conversion of API Programming Guide

subject: Implements AJAX form posting.
messages:
[{'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-14 03:06:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-14 07:58:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-17 04:57:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-17 04:58:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

rebased to lastest master to avoid merge conflict'}, {'account_id': 543, 'date': '2012-03-20 17:43:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

Had some comments on the fictional 333 status code."}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-03-20 21:13:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Do not submit

Changing response types and mucking with the codes for all AJAX in the middleware is gonna break lots of things. Let's hold off on AJAX form handling/validation until Folsom and have a real blueprint where we can discuss the implementation before we commit to something."}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-21 02:31:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

have you guys tried running with this change?
it's not mucking with all ajax, it's just ajax with redirect 302, which is not handled by the ajax on client side anyway, it's handled by the browser
this just added another layer of indirection, please tell me why is there any problem with this"}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-21 02:58:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-21 04:08:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I have changed the 333 custom http status code to a more expectable 200 with custom header, hope this is acceptable'}, {'account_id': 2458, 'date': '2012-03-21 21:03:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

So, overall I think this approach is not the correct way to go about this. A middleware solution should not be involved at all. It is too assumptive to add headers to AJAX responses. (Also "REDIRECT_URL" is not a valid header value, you COULD use x- header values for custom header fields, but that is besides my main point.) The correct way to do this is simply to capture the submit event on the form, AJAX the serialized form to the server, prevent the form from submitting by the default browser action, have the controllers respond accordingly, and handle the response in the modal itself (which would typically be communication errors with the server, validation issues with the submitted form, or success responses.)'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-03-21 23:39:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 2458, 'date': '2012-03-21 23:56:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 543, 'date': '2012-03-21 23:58:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2458, 'date': '2012-03-22 00:00:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Andy, FYI I created this blueprint for the larger discussion to be had here: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/horizon/+spec/global-ajax-communication'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-03-22 00:36:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Approved

Pushing to Jenkins.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-22 00:46:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/2845/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-unittests/362/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-merge/358/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-pep8/517/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-03-22 01:34:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-03-22 01:34:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Pushed back to Jenkins with a fixed unit test.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-22 01:40:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/2846/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-unittests/363/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-merge/359/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-pep8/518/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-22 01:40:53.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
Implements AJAX form posting.

This is somewhat of a hack for Essex, since the long-term solution
is a reworking of the way AJAX is handled. But it solves problems
in the interim and provides a significantly better experience.

Thanks to Andy Chong for pushing forward with the initial attempts
which lead to this patch.

Fixes bug 943518.

Change-Id: Ia65d926d3d406b07301e23b4c87de60c66ddec75

commit_message:
Use unique per-test S3 bucket name.

Addresses bug 955527

Avoids a race between the S3 testcase body and the bucket clean-out
in the S3 test teardown, running near concurrently in the Jenkins
python26 and python27 builds.

Change-Id: I10f013b02bb74db2cbfc692ed372121d21bca3fb
