[{'created': '2012-03-20 20:53:33.000000000', 'message': 'Handle custom column classes; inherit from HTMLElement.

  * Fixes bug 960588, allowing custom (and mixed) column classes
    to be handled appropriately in the table metaclass.
  * Reworks Column and Cell to inherit from HTMLElement, making
    them both more consistent and easier to customize.
    Fixes bug 960590.

Change-Id: I88ec6d8d66703f11c508b4c10af439e3b732b3ce
'}]
commit_message:
Handle custom column classes; inherit from HTMLElement.

  * Fixes bug 960588, allowing custom (and mixed) column classes
    to be handled appropriately in the table metaclass.
  * Reworks Column and Cell to inherit from HTMLElement, making
    them both more consistent and easier to customize.
    Fixes bug 960590.

Change-Id: I88ec6d8d66703f11c508b4c10af439e3b732b3ce

messages:

Actually a2ensite handles the default case differently. From the man page:


The default site is handled specially: The resulting symlink will be called 000-default in order to be loaded first.


So making it default in available turns it into 000-default in enabled'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-03-20 19:37:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

nice.. thanks.'}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2012-03-20 22:39:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Jesse, agreed.  I did all of this in the fedora16 branch but we can do it here:
* rename files/000-default.template to files/apache-horizon-template
* copy the template file to sites-available/horizon

commit_message:
Install horizon apache config to sites-available instead of just sites-enabled

Fixes bug 915063.

Instead of directly writing to sites-enabled, write the horizon apache config to
sites-available/default then call a2ensite to build the links to sites-enabled.

Change-Id: Ie271186a0dcb5af30fd6654ea4e01fc2d6e59495

commit_message:
Implement quota classes.

Nova's quota class support allows entire classes of quotas to be
associated with projects, which makes it easier to set specific
quotas across multiple projects.  This change adds client-side
support for manipulating quota classes.

Change-Id: I7ee14d16aa51957dcdc1ea5c7a9d5b6bd1656f33

[{'created': '2012-03-20 18:34:43.000000000', 'message': "Don't send snapshot requests through the scheduler

 * If there is more than one volume host, snapshots need to be
   created on the host that has the volume.  Sending the request
   through the scheduler means that the snapshot will sometimes
   be created on the wrong host and fail.
 * Fixes bug 960437

Change-Id: If8562bd533226cf9aee1d3be522f799d233581a9
"}]
commit_message:
Don't send snapshot requests through the scheduler

 * If there is more than one volume host, snapshots need to be
   created on the host that has the volume.  Sending the request
   through the scheduler means that the snapshot will sometimes
   be created on the wrong host and fail.
 * Fixes bug 960437

Change-Id: If8562bd533226cf9aee1d3be522f799d233581a9

commit_message:
Wrapped unexpected exceptions (bug 955411)

- Replaced all webob.exc's (outside of middleware) with
  keystone.exception's
- Raised 409 Conflict when creating/updating existing
  user/tenant ID/names (bug 955464)
- Raised 501 Not Implemented for user-role-add w/o tenant_id
  (bug 955548)

Change-Id: I9f16cac502c20dd35a6b8da778e85bf3d9cfae49

messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-13 22:17:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

Note: WIP until trunk reopens for Folsom.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-03-14 19:59:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I wonder if it is possible/desirable to move away entirely from having the configured defaults for quotas, choosing instead to rely exclusively on the defaults in the quota classes.

Its always seemed a bit dangerous to me that I must rely on the local configuration to ensure I don't mess up system resources."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-14 20:07:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I can see your point, but we have to have some kind of default come in from somewhere.  (I don't think just setting everything to "unlimited" is tenable, either…)  Also, this patch as currently written doesn't solve the problem of how to *assign* a quota class to a specific project; it assumes the authentication middleware sets it up, or that some other middleware changes the 'quota_class' attribute of the context (the approach I'm taking for an internal use of quota classes).

On the other hand, I suppose it would be possible to alter the migration to set up an initial quota class of 'default' with the existing command-line/configuration values for those options, then use 'default' for the default quota class rather than None…'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-15 14:58:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-16 20:05:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-19 15:01:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-20 15:38:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

Folsom is now open…'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-20 15:43:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 236, 'date': '2012-03-20 22:29:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Looks good. Obviously, this is somewhat of a hook, where some additional middleware, such as turnstile or keystone's integration middleware can actually set the quota class on the context.  We should probably put up a page on the wiki documenting these sorts of integration points."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-03-21 16:18:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-21 16:29:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified

commit_message:
Implement quota classes.

Allows entire classes of quotas to be associated with projects, which
makes it easier to set specific quotas across multiple projects.

TODO:

* (?) Adding a mapping between projects and quota classes

Change-Id: I6b6477481187d16af225d33c1989430e4071d5a8

commit_message:
Specify location when creating s3 bucket.

Fixes bug 961050

Avoids bucket creation failure when a region-specific S3 endpoint
(e.g. s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com) and also bucket create-on-demand
are configured.

Change-Id: Ieba9c535ccb961a1f81bd2632b5ac49c23ac7901

commit_message:
Fix unplug_vbd to retry a configurable number of times

Fixes bug 960655

A previous cleanup ended up changing the exception raised by unplug_vbd
which caused vbd_unplug_with_retry to fail to retry. Since it's common
to retry, bake that functionality straight into unplug_vbd for other
users too.

Change-Id: I3370c560a1997459ab37b9d5f1181464fa5b0f0c

commit_message:
Bug #883218: No documentation for installing OpenStack Compute with XenServer as hypervisor
Bug #938408: Possible typo in a relevant technical term

Added <?dbhtml stop-chunking?> processing instruction so the introduction appears as a single page.
Add an introduction to Xen, XCP, and XenServer, with explanation of the
variety of technical terms.  This is included as part of the Installing
OpenStack Compute and Image Service chapter in the installation manual, and
the Hypervisors chapter of the compute admin manual.

Change-Id: I381e9b8ec19638ba90a8436fdcb6b5059f3ff963

subject: Allow hard reboot of a rebooting instance
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 177, 'name': 'Alex Meade', 'email': 'mr.alex.meade@gmail.com', 'username': 'alex-meade'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2383, 'name': 'Philip Knouff', 'email': 'philip.knouff@gmail.com', 'username': 'philip-knouff'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-08 18:48:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(3 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 2383, 'date': '2012-03-08 18:58:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-03-08 20:52:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

Need a little info, see inline"}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-03-08 21:08:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

kk we're good.

This change allows hard reboots during a soft reboot and during a hard reboot. I agree with that, however, we may want to update the docs."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-08 22:20:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm a little concerned about this.  There is a fallback in libvirt to switch to hard reboot if the soft-reboot hasn't succeeded in 60 seconds.  I think there is a similar fallback in xen with a periodic task that converts soft reboots into hard.

I think in the current case we could have some odd problems if someone tries to hard reboot when we are in the middle of this."}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-03-08 22:30:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score

Vish: I'm not even sure if the bug this fixes is valid either. Why would someone need to reboot back to back? And I agree that it's probably safer to not allow rebooting during reboots, as long as we know it can't get stuck in REBOOT. But I guess that's a different issue."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-03-13 16:36:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I agree with the sentiment that we shouldn't allow redundant hard reboots during a hard reboot. I can see the need for a hard reboot during a hung soft reboot, however."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-21 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-21 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]

commit_message:
Rename tokenauth to authtoken.

- Avoid confusing by using the authtoken name for auth_token middleware.
- Improve swift_auth middleware doc.

Change-Id: I287860eba067b99a1d89f8f17200820340836ff9

commit_message:
unique role name constraint

  For SQL identity backend, add unique constraint with column definition;
for kvs and ldap backend, use python code to apply this constraint.
Test cases test_create_duplicate_role_name_fails and test_rename_duplicate_role_name_fails are added to guard it.
python run_tests.py test_backend_ldap test_backend_kvs test_backend_sql pass.

bug 932258.

Change-Id: I990f17a270e84d35c078f215c587a81d6784c192

subject: fix useexisting deprecation warnings
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 24, 'name': 'Chuck Short', 'email': 'charles.short@windriver.com', 'username': 'zulcss'}, {'_account_id': 191, 'name': 'Trey Morris', 'email': 'trey.morris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'tr3buchet'}, {'_account_id': 385, 'name': 'Jason Kölker', 'email': 'jason@koelker.net', 'username': 'jason-koelker'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1812, 'name': 'p-draigbrady', 'email': 'P@draigBrady.com', 'username': 'p-draigbrady'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-08 16:39:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-03-08 17:02:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

This will break on devstack which uses the native packages for Ubuntu which are still <0.7.x. As long as devstack is fixed to honor the pip-requires version, then this is ok, but until then is a no bueno."}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-03-08 20:23:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for the info.

We should fix up pip-requires to have the correct requirements then I think. I.E. add sqlalchemy >= 0.6.?
or whatever is the lowest tested and working version.

Note https://review.openstack.org/#change,5031 went into glance, which may need to be reverted so?'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-03-13 14:54:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Jason could you reconsider the sqlalchemy 0.6 dependency as I don't think it's valid. See https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/928637 for example"}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-03-13 15:08:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I would love to really drop support for 0.6.x, but the problem is this file in devstack:

https://github.com/openstack-dev/devstack/blob/master/files/apts/nova

Since it installs the package version (and devstack "officially" only supports oneric) it installs 0.6.8 and it never gets updated via pip or anything to what is in the requires.

Before this goes in, we need to make devstack install 0.7.x. (I only know this because I got hit with it before ;).'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-03-13 20:36:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

echo'ing Koelker"}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-03-19 15:30:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

chuck@homer:~/work/server/openstack/git/keystone/keystone$ dpkg -l | grep sqlal
ii  python-sqlalchemy                   0.7.4-1                                 SQL toolkit and Object Relational Mapper for Python
ii  python-sqlalchemy-ext               0.7.4-1                                 SQL toolkit and Object Relational Mapper for Python - C extension

Im running devstack on precise with 0.7.4 without any significant problems.'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-03-19 16:46:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Have the precise packages been backported to oneiric? According to http://devstack.org/ that is what we tell people to install.'}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-03-20 16:26:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

"}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-03-20 23:27:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Here are some issues summarised related to this patch
https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg08634.html'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-14 20:58:12.000000000', 'message': "Support PyPAM in keystone.identity.backends.pam.

Fix bug 938801.

This bug pointed out that some distros don't have the same pam Python
module packaged that this backend was expecting.  In my case, on Fedora,
it's PAM and the API is not compatible with the pam module that was
used.  This patch makes the backend support PyPAM, as well as the
original pam module that was used.

Change-Id: I74144f4e63b6830c8224bc87e1662eb5df8728a0
"}, {'created': '2012-03-15 14:53:33.000000000', 'message': "Support PyPAM in pam backend, update to latest API.

module packaged that this backend was expecting.  In my case, on Fedora,
it's PAM and the API is not compatible with the pam module that was
used.  This patch makes the backend support PyPAM, as well as the
original pam module that was used.

In order to test this, I updated the pam backend to the latest backend
API.  Even though the base class will raise NotImplementedError, I
included all functions here to make it more clear all of the things
this backend does not do.

Change-Id: I74144f4e63b6830c8224bc87e1662eb5df8728a0

commit_message:
Support PyPAM in pam backend, update to latest API

Fix bug 938801.

This bug pointed out that some distros don't have the same pam Python
module packaged that this backend was expecting.  In my case, on Fedora,
it's PAM and the API is not compatible with the pam module that was
used.  This patch makes the backend support PyPAM, as well as the
original pam module that was used.

In order to test this, I updated the pam backend to the latest backend
API.  Even though the base class will raise NotImplementedError, I
included all functions here to make it more clear all of the things
this backend does not do.

Change-Id: I74144f4e63b6830c8224bc87e1662eb5df8728a0

commit_message:
Ensure all unauthorized reponses return 403

* Clean up authorization vs authentication failures internally
* Remove ambiguous exception.NotAuthorized in favour of exception.Forbidden for authorization failures
* Add exception.NotAuthenticated to make authentication failures more clear
* Fixes bug 956206

Change-Id: I39ce0fcd77d4f06273040a2aa4913a9be911ceab

commit_message:
Clean up of Compute Admin guide

* Rearranges configuration, moving "post install config" to config chapter.
* Removes cactus-to-diablo section.
* Adds basic image management chaper.
* Needs more info about configuring ec2, configuring nova-api, understanding policy.json.
* Fixes date formatting problem that prevented builds from working.

Change-Id: I7af2b426140a262f7a9b4ec62e7307925b1b0101

commit_message:
Add 'publicize_image' policy

* Allow deployers apply RBAC rules to setting the is_public image attribute to True
* Add docs for publicize_image and manage_image_cache policies
* Fixes bug 960261

Change-Id: I100a6c93377617cc0e774b6ee3a69e857a05c260

WorkInProgress - and not working very well. Using SQL Identity backend,
getting errors that are returning as a 500 response, but not getting
logged.

Attempted to add logging wrapper to SQLAlchemy session methods, but that
doesn't appear to be captureing and logging the errors.

Added a wrapper at the Identity back-end manager (for SQL) to see how
that works.

* Working on bug 951958

Change-Id: I32e2dfef0b474b045cc9808ee4ba171c52dbdbe5
"}]
commit_message:
catching SQL errors and logging them

WorkInProgress - and not working very well. Using SQL Identity backend,
getting errors that are returning as a 500 response, but not getting
logged.

Attempted to add logging wrapper to SQLAlchemy session methods, but that
doesn't appear to be captureing and logging the errors.

Added a wrapper at the Identity back-end manager (for SQL) to see how
that works.

* Working on bug 951958

Change-Id: I32e2dfef0b474b045cc9808ee4ba171c52dbdbe5

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-15 15:00:11.000000000', 'message': "Fixes bug 949038

Makes most of the api calls follow the standard pattern for
read_deleted, i.e. allowing the context to specify the value.

I have retained the ability to pass the read_deleted
explicitly, but if you don't specifiy it, it uses the context.

Other calls default to read_deleted=yes, so you can only override
those explicity. They make more sense with yes as the default, so
can't follow the standard pattern, as the context leaves the
default as yes.

Change-Id: Idb048a592d8c6b788651d131a3345e70989c0ec4
"}, {'created': '2012-03-16 10:23:21.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes bug 949038

Make the api calls better fit the standard pattern where
read_deleted can be changed using context.read_deleted

I have retained the ability to pass read_deleted
explicitly. If that is not specified, it uses the value in
the context.

Note: read_deleted defaults to "no" in the context.

The two exceptions are:
 aggregate_host_get_all
 aggregate_get_all

In this case, it is better for read_deleted=yes to be the default
So in this case the context cannot be used, as that would default
to read_deleted=no. In this case you must explicity override
read_deleted, the context is totally ignored, as before.

Change-Id: Idb048a592d8c6b788651d131a3345e70989c0ec4
'}, {'created': '2012-03-16 10:36:28.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes bug 949038

I have retained the ability to pass read_deleted
explicitly. If that is not specified, it uses the value in

Note: read_deleted defaults to "no" in the context.

The two exceptions are:
 aggregate_host_get_all
 aggregate_get_all

In this case, it is better for read_deleted=yes to be the default
So in this case the context cannot be used, as that would default
to read_deleted=no. In this case you must explicity override
read_deleted, the context is totally ignored, as before.

Change-Id: Idb048a592d8c6b788651d131a3345e70989c0ec4
'}, {'created': '2012-03-20 10:45:13.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes bug 949038

explicitly. If that is not specified, it uses the value in

The two exceptions are:
 aggregate_host_get_all
 aggregate_get_all

In this case, it is better for read_deleted=yes to be the default
So in this case the context cannot be used, as that would default
to read_deleted=no. In this case you must explicity override

Change-Id: Idb048a592d8c6b788651d131a3345e70989c0ec4
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes bug 949038

Make the api calls better fit the standard pattern where
read_deleted can be changed using context.read_deleted

I have retained the ability to pass read_deleted
explicitly. If that is not specified, it uses the value in
the context.

Note: read_deleted defaults to "no" in the context.

The two exceptions are:
 aggregate_host_get_all
 aggregate_get_all

In this case, it is better for read_deleted=yes to be the default
So in this case the context cannot be used, as that would default
to read_deleted=no. In this case you must explicity override
read_deleted, the context is totally ignored, as before.

Change-Id: Idb048a592d8c6b788651d131a3345e70989c0ec4

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-19 18:41:26.000000000', 'message': 'tox tests with run_tests.sh instead of nosetests

In order to ensure the glance-logcapture plugin is loaded dynamically,
we configure tox to drive tests with the run_tests.sh script intead of
calling nosetests directly.

This is intended as a temporary measure, pending promotion of the

commit_message:
tox tests with run_tests.sh instead of nosetests

In order to ensure the glance-logcapture plugin is loaded dynamically,
we configure tox to drive tests with the run_tests.sh script intead of
calling nosetests directly.

This is intended as a temporary measure, pending promotion of the
glance-logcapture plugin to openstack-nose.

Change-Id: I556c751f4c2d31c1cbacd42d835ab436fb8f6988

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-19 18:51:35.000000000', 'message': "Refactor non-global config (in one giant patch)

Remove cfg wrappers from keystone.config

    The idea with the cfg module is that we can have all projects using not
    only the same code for config, but using similar idioms that will be
    familiar to anyone working on OpenStack.

    The register_*() wrappers don't add much in the way of convenience, but
    if we really want them, we can add them to cfg itself.

    Subsequent commits in this series remove the global CONF object and
    move option definitions closer to where the option is used. The end
    result is worth considering as well as this initial baby step.

Refactor password utils into separate module

    The code is so self-contained, it seems a shame to have it lumped into
    a generic utils module.

    We make hash_password() use a supplied conf instance rather than CONF
    to help us remove CONF completely in subsequent commits where the conf
    instance will be an attribute of the identity drivers.

    A default value for crypt_strength is also added to keystone.conf.

Refactor sql options avoid using CONF

    Pass a conf instance to many of the sql functions so that CONF can
    be completely removed in subsequent commits.

    Move the option definitions into a sql.opts module since both sql.core
    and sql.migration rely on the same options. In theory, this could make
    it easier for someone to copy and re-use either of those modules
    individually.

    Also remove sql.min_pool_size, sql.max_pool_size and sql.pool_timeout
    since they are unused.

memcache token backend refactoring

    A trivial refactoring to isolate the memcache.servers option in the
    memcache.Token class.

    In a subsequent commit, the conf instance will be an attribute of
    token.Driver and the lameness of using using config.CONF will be
    removed.

    Also add a default value for it in keystone.conf.

Refactor ldap identity backend options

    Move the options definitions closer to where they are used, add default
    values to the option definitions and rely on them, reconcile defaults
    in the code with defaults in the config file.

Re-factor how service driver options are handled

    Define the {catalog,ec2,identity,policy,token}.driver options in
    the manager class which use them. The base manager class registers
    them.

    Also supply a conf instance to the constructor of each of these
    manager classes so that the global CONF variable can be removed in
    a subsequent commit.

Refactor admin_token handling

    Move the admin_token option definition to the AdminTokenAuthMiddleware
    class where it is used.

    Also, explicitly set the admin_token value in the tests to make things
    more clear.

Refactor port options

    The admin_port and public_port options are only used in the tests and
    in keystone-all. Move their definitions to the wsgi module and add
    a helper method for registering them.

    The compute port option is only used in the templated catalog backend,
    so move its definition there.

Refactor policy rules driver to avoid global CONF

    Move the options related to this driver into the driver class and only
    use them within the class.

    Add a new class to encapsulate the logic of the policy cache and use
    helper methods to interact with the global instance of that cache.

    This refactoring has a nice side-effect of cleaning up the unit tests
    fairly significantly. No need for teardown methods to reset state and
    more easily disable loading the policy file by stubbing out the
    load_policy function.

Remove use of global CONF in service drivers

    Make each of the service drivers take a conf instance paramater to its
    constructor and use that instead of CONF.

    The use of super(..., self).__init__() is avoided because of the mess
    it causes with multiple inheritance in e.g. kvs.Identity where you
    want identity.Driver to be supplied a conf instance from the preceeding
    constructor in the MRO (i.e. kvs.Base).

Pass conf instance to sql.Base constructor

    Removes use of CONF from common.sql completely.

Pass conf instance to WSGI app constructors

    So that we can remove all CONF references from our WSGI apps, pass a
    conf instance to their constructors. We need to make sure that e.g.
    add_routes() is only called on a router app after its base class
    constructor has been called and its conf attribute set.

Eliminate a bunch of CONF usage in cli and tests

    This is a fairly random collection of changes, but it weanes the code
    off CONF usage some more.

Add generic PasteDeploy factories from glance

    PasteDeploy has no way of passing parameters to an app or filter
    factory constructor except through options in the config file.

    We want to pass a conf instance to these constructors, so we do a
    lame trick where we stuff a conf instance into a global variable
    before the factory is run and have the factory pass it on to the
    constructor. Rather than duplicate the lame hack in a bunch of
    places we have a single generic set of factories and do it there.

    This code is copied straight from glance. It should eventually live
    in openstack-common.

Remove last few uses of CONF

    Only a few refernences to CONF exist at this point in the cli code
    and tests.

    Also, the need for ConfigMixin is pretty much eliminated at this
    point since we can just pass the default config files list to the
    ConfigOpts constructor.

Change-Id: I2da18110247a8d06f4c8e485ab877ffe133175bf

    so move its definition there.

Refactor policy rules driver to avoid global CONF

    Move the options related to this driver into the driver class and only
    use them within the class.

    Add a new class to encapsulate the logic of the policy cache and use
    helper methods to interact with the global instance of that cache.

    This refactoring has a nice side-effect of cleaning up the unit tests
    fairly significantly. No need for teardown methods to reset state and
    more easily disable loading the policy file by stubbing out the
    load_policy function.

Remove use of global CONF in service drivers

    Make each of the service drivers take a conf instance paramater to its
    constructor and use that instead of CONF.

    The use of super(..., self).__init__() is avoided because of the mess
    it causes with multiple inheritance in e.g. kvs.Identity where you
    want identity.Driver to be supplied a conf instance from the preceeding

Pass conf instance to sql.Base constructor

Pass conf instance to WSGI app constructors

    constructor has been called and its conf attribute set.

Eliminate a bunch of CONF usage in cli and tests

    This is a fairly random collection of changes, but it weanes the code
    off CONF usage some more.

Add generic PasteDeploy factories from glance

    PasteDeploy has no way of passing parameters to an app or filter
    factory constructor except through options in the config file.

    We want to pass a conf instance to these constructors, so we do a
    lame trick where we stuff a conf instance into a global variable
    before the factory is run and have the factory pass it on to the
    constructor. Rather than duplicate the lame hack in a bunch of
    places we have a single generic set of factories and do it there.

    This code is copied straight from glance. It should eventually live
    in openstack-common.

Remove last few uses of CONF

    Only a few refernences to CONF exist at this point in the cli code
    and tests.

    Also, the need for ConfigMixin is pretty much eliminated at this
    point since we can just pass the default config files list to the
    ConfigOpts constructor.

Change-Id: I2da18110247a8d06f4c8e485ab877ffe133175bf
"}]
commit_message:
Refactor non-global config (in one giant patch)

Remove cfg wrappers from keystone.config

    The idea with the cfg module is that we can have all projects using not
    only the same code for config, but using similar idioms that will be
    familiar to anyone working on OpenStack.

    The register_*() wrappers don't add much in the way of convenience, but
    if we really want them, we can add them to cfg itself.

    Subsequent commits in this series remove the global CONF object and
    move option definitions closer to where the option is used. The end
    result is worth considering as well as this initial baby step.

Refactor password utils into separate module

    The code is so self-contained, it seems a shame to have it lumped into
    a generic utils module.

    We make hash_password() use a supplied conf instance rather than CONF
    to help us remove CONF completely in subsequent commits where the conf
    instance will be an attribute of the identity drivers.

    A default value for crypt_strength is also added to keystone.conf.

Refactor sql options avoid using CONF

    Pass a conf instance to many of the sql functions so that CONF can
    be completely removed in subsequent commits.

    Move the option definitions into a sql.opts module since both sql.core
    and sql.migration rely on the same options. In theory, this could make
    it easier for someone to copy and re-use either of those modules
    individually.

    Also remove sql.min_pool_size, sql.max_pool_size and sql.pool_timeout
    since they are unused.

memcache token backend refactoring

    A trivial refactoring to isolate the memcache.servers option in the
    memcache.Token class.

    In a subsequent commit, the conf instance will be an attribute of
    token.Driver and the lameness of using using config.CONF will be
    removed.

    Also add a default value for it in keystone.conf.

Refactor ldap identity backend options

    Move the options definitions closer to where they are used, add default
    values to the option definitions and rely on them, reconcile defaults
    in the code with defaults in the config file.

Re-factor how service driver options are handled

    Define the {catalog,ec2,identity,policy,token}.driver options in
    the manager class which use them. The base manager class registers
    them.

    Also supply a conf instance to the constructor of each of these
    manager classes so that the global CONF variable can be removed in
    a subsequent commit.

Refactor admin_token handling

    Move the admin_token option definition to the AdminTokenAuthMiddleware
    class where it is used.

    Also, explicitly set the admin_token value in the tests to make things
    more clear.

Refactor port options

    The admin_port and public_port options are only used in the tests and
    in keystone-all. Move their definitions to the wsgi module and add
    a helper method for registering them.

    The compute port option is only used in the templated catalog backend,
    so move its definition there.

Refactor policy rules driver to avoid global CONF

    Move the options related to this driver into the driver class and only
    use them within the class.

    Add a new class to encapsulate the logic of the policy cache and use
    helper methods to interact with the global instance of that cache.

    This refactoring has a nice side-effect of cleaning up the unit tests
    fairly significantly. No need for teardown methods to reset state and
    more easily disable loading the policy file by stubbing out the
    load_policy function.

Remove use of global CONF in service drivers

    Make each of the service drivers take a conf instance paramater to its
    constructor and use that instead of CONF.

    The use of super(..., self).__init__() is avoided because of the mess
    it causes with multiple inheritance in e.g. kvs.Identity where you
    want identity.Driver to be supplied a conf instance from the preceeding
    constructor in the MRO (i.e. kvs.Base).

Pass conf instance to sql.Base constructor

    Removes use of CONF from common.sql completely.

Pass conf instance to WSGI app constructors

    So that we can remove all CONF references from our WSGI apps, pass a
    conf instance to their constructors. We need to make sure that e.g.
    add_routes() is only called on a router app after its base class
    constructor has been called and its conf attribute set.

Eliminate a bunch of CONF usage in cli and tests

    This is a fairly random collection of changes, but it weanes the code
    off CONF usage some more.

Add generic PasteDeploy factories from glance

    PasteDeploy has no way of passing parameters to an app or filter
    factory constructor except through options in the config file.

    We want to pass a conf instance to these constructors, so we do a
    lame trick where we stuff a conf instance into a global variable
    before the factory is run and have the factory pass it on to the
    constructor. Rather than duplicate the lame hack in a bunch of
    places we have a single generic set of factories and do it there.

    This code is copied straight from glance. It should eventually live
    in openstack-common.

Remove last few uses of CONF

    Only a few refernences to CONF exist at this point in the cli code
    and tests.

    Also, the need for ConfigMixin is pretty much eliminated at this
    point since we can just pass the default config files list to the
    ConfigOpts constructor.

Change-Id: I2da18110247a8d06f4c8e485ab877ffe133175bf

subject: Remove python-keystoneclient checkout.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 4, 'name': 'Dolph Mathews', 'email': 'dolph.mathews@gmail.com', 'username': 'dolph'}, {'_account_id': 6, 'name': 'Joe Heck', 'email': 'heckj@mac.com', 'username': 'heckj'}, {'_account_id': 112, 'name': 'Jesse Andrews', 'email': 'anotherjesse@gmail.com', 'username': 'anotherjesse'}, {'_account_id': 494, 'name': 'termie', 'email': 'termie@openstack.org', 'username': 'termie'}, {'_account_id': 518, 'name': 'Soren Hansen', 'email': 'soren@linux2go.dk', 'username': 'soren'}, {'_account_id': 979, 'name': 'Dave Walker', 'email': 'email@daviey.com', 'username': 'davewalker'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 979, 'date': '2012-03-05 15:53:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Good catch, how a test which defaults to grabbing external dependencies landed is unfortunate.'}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2012-03-05 21:01:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

this exists explicitly to test multiple versions of the client library to make sure we maintain legacy compatibility'}, {'account_id': 979, 'date': '2012-03-05 21:17:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@termie, you have to be kidding?  A unit test cloning another repository (let alone, by default)? It's not really cricket."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-03-05 21:21:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

@Dave, it's not a unit test"}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2012-03-05 21:38:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

So... Is there a way to avoid running these "not unit tests"? Ubuntu and Debian buildd's don't allow outbound network connections (to ensure they're reproducable regardless of what goes on on the internet at any given time), so we need a way to avoid stuff like this.'}, {'account_id': 979, 'date': '2012-03-05 22:08:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

These non-unit tests, surely belong in tempest if they are to validate integration?

Note, that this would seem to be a special case for keystone.  No other openstack project has an external network retrieved dependency, when ./run_tests -N is performed.

Why does keystone require this in core, but the other openstack projects have avoided this?'}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2012-03-06 18:26:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

dave: keystone has this code because none of the other projects have explicitly paid attention to multi-version compatibility resulting in plenty of breakages all the time.

as far as moving this type of test into something else, I am fine with the idea, but in practice using different versions of libraries require different code (see the two different tests there and the different style for adding roles in the keystone library) so it will require some additional semantics for describing that.

soren: towards disabling these tests in ubuntu's builds, you have a couple options off the top of my head, 1) we can add some option to skip the non-master tests and ignore teh checkout for the master tests, and hope that whatever package you have installed is appropriate, 2) you can check out those libraries beforehand to the appropriate spots"}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-03-06 22:09:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

per IRC convo with Soren and Daviey, I've just logged https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/948495 to get you guys something to allow you to package."}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-03-10 07:32:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

please try out https://review.openstack.org/#change,5192 and see if this does the trick for your needs. Wouldn't mind a review on it too. :-)"}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2012-03-11 01:15:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

now that 5192 has been merged I think this can be abandon'd"}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-03-20 12:03:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Remove python-keystoneclient checkout.

Dont try to checkout python-keysotneclient when
running the tests it should already be installed.

Change-Id: Ibdc6c71198558c8e6a74181990ddaecd2e4b1153
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

subject: enables run_test option to skip integration
messages:

Chuck, 

I think this option (./run_tests.sh -xintegration) will enable exactly what you want (i.e. no offline requirement for running a core set of unit tests). It's perhaps a little brittle, but the only external tests are related to the keystoneclient codebase."}, {'account_id': 979, 'date': '2012-03-10 09:32:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks Joe, this certainly unblocks us.. Thanks!

Although, i still feel that the test framework should be repeatable in the past, which means that if this testing is to continue.. I do think it should at least store the hash of the external deps it was merged with.

[{'created': '2012-03-20 10:57:59.000000000', 'message': "Prune stale remote branches.

Because milestone-proposed branches have a limited existence,
it's possible for a devstack run triggered by a milestone-proposed
branch in one project to have problems because it will pick up an old
milestone-proposed branch from its local repo.

Change-Id: I42cc93dc8aa64fcdfb374938aa91506a85b50cde
"}]
commit_message:
Prune stale remote branches.

Because milestone-proposed branches have a limited existence,
it's possible for a devstack run triggered by a milestone-proposed
branch in one project to have problems because it will pick up an old
milestone-proposed branch from its local repo.

Change-Id: I42cc93dc8aa64fcdfb374938aa91506a85b50cde

subject: Fixes the nova-manage script to log exceptions
messages:
[{'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-03-12 17:29:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is the wrong number of arguments worth logging a stack trace for?  I was under the impression that the end user should only see stack traces (in log files) when something goes very wrong, and not providing the necessary parameters is just a simple, and easily fixable, user error.'}, {'account_id': 1814, 'date': '2012-03-12 17:46:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Traces on the terminal screen during cmd execution gives a wrong impression to a user/admin that something might have broken down in the system. So if needed we could replace logging the whole trace with a simpler msg but raising it on the terminal is certainly not a good idea IMHO. Also sometimes, traces get too long on the screen.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-03-12 17:53:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Agreed.  How about only logging whole stack trace in logs when in verbose mode, with a small comment above explaining what just happened.  And when not in verbose mode, just displaying  and/or logging a simpler message.'}, {'account_id': 1814, 'date': '2012-03-12 18:39:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Isn't the idea of 'verbose mode' is to be verbose on the screen, not sure if it also includes the logs. Doing this will not increase the verbosity on the screen for sure. If you still think it to be fine, I have no problem doing that way."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-03-12 21:07:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

It looks like the stack trace is already only thrown in verbose mode (as per nova.conf), and this is already logged.  Try running a devstack instance with and without 'verbose=True'"}, {'account_id': 1814, 'date': '2012-03-13 03:50:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Verified it. Thanks Joe for pointing that out. I will mark the bug as invalid.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-20 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-20 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]

subject: Implements blueprint zeromq-rpc-driver
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 159, 'name': 'Eric Windisch', 'email': 'ewindisch@docker.com', 'username': 'ewindisch'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 693, 'name': 'Christopher MacGown', 'email': 'chris@pistoncloud.com', 'username': '0x44'}, {'_account_id': 1561, 'name': 'Russell Bryant', 'email': 'rbryant@redhat.com', 'username': 'russellb'}, {'_account_id': 1801, 'name': 'Duncan McGreggor', 'email': 'duncan.mcgreggor@rackspace.com', 'username': 'oubiwann'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-09 05:46:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I still feel the code could use some tidying, but it works and passes the unit tests. I have modified nova/tests/rpc/common.py to allow changing the topics used by the common tests; I can drop this change if it is too hard on the FFE.

Not expecting this to go through on the first try.

Yes, I need to remove/change the gflags usage...'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-09 06:01:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(6 inline comments)

A number of problems."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-09 06:10:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

test changes seem fine.  Curious about the need for a separate binary.  Is it the broker? You will need to modify setup.py to include it so it can be packaged.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-09 06:17:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Thanks Vish. I'll have to update setup.py.

Yes, the new service is the broker. It listens for messages on the following topics:

Whatever the following resolve to:
FLAGS.compute_topic
FLAGS.console_topic
FLAGS.scheduler_topic
FLAGS.volume_topic
FLAGS.network_topic
FLAGS.ajax_console_proxy_topic
FLAGS.vsa_topic

Plus:
'test'
'nested'

Any topic ending in ".<hostname>" will NOT go through the broker, but will be sent directly to <hostname> (requiring DNS resolution).'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-09 08:16:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(19 inline comments)

A couple more comments:

1) Could you write up some documentation on how to use this?

2) I didn't see any reconnection handling in the code.  What will happen if a connection is lost?"}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-09 16:05:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for the feedback.

ZeroMQ will automatically reconnect a socket if the peer disappears and comes back. There are some patterns where manual reconnection is necessary, such as when there is a registration involved, but it shouldn't be required here.

I can provide documentation, this is something I'm working on anyway as I'm preparing to speak on this.

In a single node, you can run with the standard options. For multi-node, you need to set the IP address of the machine running bin/nova-rpc-zmq via nova.conf.  You also need each node's hostname to be resolvable.  This is handled by the hosts file on a single node.  With a 2-10 machine cluster you could potentially manage a hosts file, but beyond that you'll really itch to get DNS resolution. Windows/Samba hosts could just use their NetBIOS names. This implementation is name-resolution independent."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-02-09 18:09:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(8 inline comments)

Some inline comments. Also, I got a test failure, and a bunch of PEP8 errors: http://paste.openstack.org/show/4745/ and http://paste.openstack.org/show/4746/

I would also *love* some documentation on how this works. I still only have a vague idea of what ZeroMQ actually does, unfortunately.

Finally, can you work on cleaning up some of those debug messages? They're a bit inconsistent and at times hard to grasp what they mean."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-09 18:14:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I've been working exclusively on documentation today. I should have a new patch-set tomorrow to address many of these concerns.

Thanks everyone for the feedback."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-09 19:24:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-09 22:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-11 19:28:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-11 19:30:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Still not working with pep8. Likely other HACKING violations, haven't run the tool...

Might/probably fails the "new" test. Russell identified new methods this driver should implement, marked as a TODO.  Still uses gflags.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-11 19:35:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Per recommendation, I dropped the 'import eventlet' to match HACKING requirements. However, this was intentionally breaking HACKING because other nova- binaries do the same and I was following their example. I expected this was probably due to how monkey_patch() works, but I had not confirmed."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-11 20:44:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (5 inline comments)

Inline comments.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-12 01:55:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-12 22:29:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-12 23:07:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-02-14 21:19:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-16 20:07:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I was just talking to Vish and Chris Behrens about some rpc topics.  We were discussing standardizing on json as the serialization format for all of the rpc implementations.  Could you switch from pickle to json in your patch?  It's pretty close to a search a replace, luckily.  You just don't pass a protocol arg to json.dumps().

An example for why json would be better than pickle is if someone needs to write something in a language other than Python, json is a format that is easily accessible from other languages."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-16 22:19:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm perfectly happy with having this use JSON, and I myself had just had this conversation with MacGown last night.  The only reason I submitted this with Pickle was because it was that way when I inherited this code from Zed, and it was one of the few things that actually worked well and didn't really need me to look at it, so I let it be. There are several good reasons for why I agree JSON is better here, I just didn't bother to break something that was working (but as you say, its easy enough to swap)."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-16 23:34:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Do not submit

Just marking this donot submit for now until we see the new code :)'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-21 04:59:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-21 05:02:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-21 05:13:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: (6 inline comments)

Marked some inline comments.

I've reverted to using cPickle, because some types cannot be serialized as JSON.

Cleaned for pep8.

Functional/smoke tests are working well, but unit tests hang."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-21 14:38:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-21 14:45:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-21 14:47:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Feeling confident about this one. The code fails the timeout test, but the Timeout exception *is* raised, so I'm not sure what is wrong here. It is possible to skip the test...

Missing messages do seem to happen on occasion, but I'd like that we look at that as a bug fix."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-21 14:56:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Regarding the pickle vs. json issue, I'd like to fix whatever types can not be serialized by json.  If any of those types are used in unit tests, the tests will fail due to a recent change to impl_fake.  Can you record the errors you hit in bug reports?  They can usually be resolved with usage of nova.utils.to_primitive() on them before passing into rpc."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-21 15:28:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

The most visible is datetime.datetime, which is an object.  To serialize over JSON, we should call and pass the result of timetuple or strftime.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-21 15:37:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-21 15:39:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

You mentioned that you were working on documentation in an earlier comment.  Did anything come out of that?  It would be great to have something to point people to about how to use this.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-21 16:00:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-21 16:00:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

We have documentation, but it will need to be updated for the refactoring that took place this past week.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-21 17:00:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

I've updated the deployment and architecture docs. I could potentially add the architecture docs to this patch, but since having spoken with Anne, I have the impression that the deployment documentation should go into the openstack-manuals project and will pursue that."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-21 18:55:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-21 19:22:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-21 19:25:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Addresses the i18n issues. Puts the IPC socket into /var/run/nova.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-21 20:01:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-21 20:03:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Skips tests if zmq is not installed. Removed zeromq from pip-requires for this release.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-21 20:18:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-21 20:19:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Just a spurious newline'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-21 20:34:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: (2 inline comments)

Last couple tweaks, and then it'll be +1 from me.  Since this is self contained, I think we can continue to work on it in the tree as needed.

I think we should revisit using json, but that's not necessarily specific to this patch.  That affects all rpc drivers.  Since pickle is Python specific, I don't think we should plan on using that long term."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-02-21 20:40:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-21 20:42:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

As noted in last comment:

"Since this is self contained, I think we can continue to work on it in the tree as needed.

I think we should revisit using json, but that's not necessarily specific to this patch. That affects all rpc drivers. Since pickle is Python specific, I don't think we should plan on using that long term."'}, {'account_id': 1801, 'date': '2012-03-05 21:48:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Adding Console Log to CLI

  * Fixes bug 957518
  * Command is as follows: nova console-log <serverid> --length=20
  * Also updated the readme with new cli output.

commit_message:
Fixes LP #954089 - Service list templated catalog

* Adds missing test cases for the TemplatedCatalog
* Adds a base CatalogTest that different backends
  can use
* Updates kvs.Catalog to raise ServiceNotFound where
  appropriate
* Updates the tests.test_keystoneclient_sql to actually
  test the SQL catalog backend
* Removes old test for incorrect endpoints listing
* Removes the keystone.catalog.core.Driver.service_exists
  method since it was only implemented in the SQL driver
  and wasn't required now that get_service and delete_service
  properly raise ServiceNotFound exception.

Change-Id: I35690cc147e56007be27bacf94eeff360e727e5d
